column10: Stomping zombies is fun.

Let me preface this by saying that I've played this game since the 360 days, but I'll mostly talk about my experiences from my recent return. I'd label this game "middle of the road" something to get when it's on sale. At it's core, Dead Island isn't a bad game, but it's definitely showing its age. it's a game that consists of fetch quests from point A to point B in the most absolute mundane way possible. The gameplay loop just isn't fun and it's very outdated. the zombie encounters are very repetitive and they offer very little strategy, apart from just bashing it or throwing things at it. Weapons feel very clunky and the motion blur is horrendous. nothing sets weapons apart and they all feel clunky and the same with very little nuance. this is a game that I WOULD recommend, but only if it's on sale.

PROS
-Beautiful graphics that aged nicely
-5 characters to choose from with unique strengths
-Soundtrack is serene (albeit unfitting for an apocalypse.)
-Price is usually dirt cheap on sales
-the physics are very good
-weapon upgrade system that allows for creative choices.

CONS
-Repetitive gameplay that devolves into nothing but glorified fetch quests.
-Weapons feel bad, especially guns that have terrible sway
-The skill tree is very bad, with most skills not even directly applying to the character that you choose, but you're forced to buy them anyway to advance to the next tier.
-Looter shooter aspects, weapons are color coded and have grades. If you aren't a fan of that and you have ADHD or OCD, it will drive you crazy.

It's a mid game and that's okay, nothing spectacular but nothing egregious. it's a solid 5/10, pick up on sale.

Here is how I am starting the series. Playing as GIRLS from the series the POWER. Using one punch mode on a voluntary friendly ironman run playing as different girls in each title. Then once I have completed my blind first play of each I will switch girls and take one punch mode OFF. Enjoying both CoOp and all the other wonderful experiences these games offer. I own every zombie FPS out there. These are some VERY high quality games from TechLand IMO :) Pretty close to perfection in a myriad of ways!

This game is a masterpiece.
Every character breathes life into the story with their dead eyes and emotionless face, rivaling even something like Red Dead Redemption 2. They make nonsensical decisions in a cutscene that was activated by them walking through one door and into a room full of people who they just met. With Sam B screaming about the voodoo night of the living dead shit currently going down, Purna talking about helping people and then shooting random people she just met, Logan not knowing which accent he should use throughout the game, and Xian sitting in the corner never speaking. The main characters are really just carrying the whole game story on their back. While also allowing you to empathize and relate with their moral compass, as well as understand their thought process.
The side characters really pull their weight as they tell you to grab them 5 flowers in a monotone voice. They tell their daughters to remember them how they are now, as they both violently stare open eyed into each others faces. With one making noises that could be compared to crying but without the proper facial animations, you'll never really know. 
The music blares in your speakers or headphones with the most over the top sad tones you could imagine. As you think of the stock music site that they probably stole it from, you're being told to go help Frank find his wife. Who is two bungalows over begging for more and more alcohol. 
The gameplay is absolutely stunning. There's never a moment in which you're fighting zombies where you're enjoying yourself. Either you're swiping cobwebs from your faces, or you're blasting at other survivors with your pistol with the auto aim function which they transferred onto PC for some reason. The guns feel like you're shooting people with rubber bullets, whether it's a human or a zombie. Either way you're doing at most, like 10 damage. Same goes for the weapons, with every enemy taking up to 10 hits with a machete. You're never going to get bored of fighting in this game. You'll probably just get fed up and run through as many as you possibly can.
And the graphics.. MAMA MIA. They need to go back into the oven because they are not fucking done.

All in all it has a little something for everyone. Without ever having a moment where you're free from bugs, you'll always be having fun. 10/10, best game I've played in the last 5 years. I want my money back.

I can say fore sure that this game is the part of my child hood from many other games of that time.

For me this game, along with all the others I played in my childhood will be in a special place.

Weird thing to recommend a ten year old game in this day and age; but its pretty much lightning in a bottle.  

The premise is awesome, a bunch of hedonistic Aussies on not-Bali cope with the apocalypse; arguably the environment turning around and vampirising them back, hehe.  All of the survival tropes are here, sure... but the feel is exquisite as you pelt, hammer, smash and burn your way through the walking hordes in tropical paradise. The definitive edition is still super pretty, and while the world may not be as destructible as one has come to expect in the 2020's; the action is still compelling. If you can pick this up on supersale, do it; its a compelling little world of its own; reminiscent of the Italian Zombiesploitation films of the 1980's in one of the most atmospheric games I've ever played.

[h1]So freaking cheesy its my guilty pleasure[/h1]

So, Dead Island pulls out all of the "Zombie Apocalypse" stereotypes including
-Idyllic island beach resort
-people being immune to zombie virus
-secret military base on beach island that creates the virus
-the fight between the main characters and looters, pillagers, and rioters
-insane reaction between military and said virus even though they created the virus
-indigenous people being able to "control" said virus
-the one person you least expect to die/hope for the best for them dies horribly.

That is why I call it cheesy, and I admit even though I usually hate these kind of things it was entertaining for me

Some may say it's repetitive, but in this case it's not a bad thing as I enjoy the combat enough to have played multiple playthroughs. So I have always adored this game ever since it was originally released.
Does it have its flaws? Yes, Several glaring ones.
But do those flaws take away from the game itself? Simply, no, no it doesn't.

Dead Island, despite its flaws, is just one of those games that you can pick up and turn your brain off for a few hours while you do the story, kill some zed's, find that bigger number stick and just chill.

If you can over look the flaws that are there, then you will understand why so many people had been waiting for the sequel for 12 years.

Dead island in my opinion is "Ok" at best. I wouldn't say its ground breaking at all but that said it's certainly not bad.

A decent little Weapon Crafting system and some decent areas to explore.

To say its open world is a bet far fetched as these are different areas you can move to and progress through the story.

The story as far as it goes again is "ok" didn't personally grip me rather than the progressive side quests and such that I actually enjoyed more so. 

There were a few parts I found buggy and the npc system is a bit off putting as alot of the time characters on escort missions will simply run off whilst your trying to keep them safe and kill the straggling zombies at the same time.

In all its good fun with friends and even playing solo its all good, the character building and progression was more interesting than the actual story line

In all 6/10

Game overall is just ok. Remember having a blast playing this game when it came out, but replying it all recently, It all just felt so repetitive. Escort missions with constant Infected type zombies just running at you. Protection missions with constant infected zombies running at you. Needing to get somewhere with constant infected type zombies running at you, trapped in a pit where you're tasked to fight a tribe's "warriors", well guess what they're all just infected type zombies running at you. Even in the final fight, it's just you shooting the final man with infected type zombies running at you. The game starts off pretty fun, and shows promise, but as you progress it gets obvious the game was rushed progression wise, story wise, and gameplay wise.
I still recommend it because their still is some fun to be have, even if it is repetitive.

Bought the game expecting a story related game, instead got a very boring and repetitive experience.

This game works nearly the same as borderlands but without the cool loot part of the game and comedy. The story doesn't actually mean anything and neither does 90% of dialogue. The combat is also annoying, with you having no choice but to lose health by getting hit on those tall zombies. 

If you want to play the game solo, then don't expect much as this game is more made for co-op, which I did not expect. It makes the game 10x harder than usual, so if you don't have friends to play the game with, then don't buy this game as you'll find yourself quitting early.

You bet that most of the missions are worthless missions making you grab something for someone or one of those typical rescue missions that are stupid and everyone hates.

Overall, try it out if you have 2-4 people to play with. If you don't, the game is very frustrating and gets very very boring. Kind of unfortunate because the atmosphere can be cool as well as the zombies sometimes actually being scary.

Oh, and "definitive edition" means nothing.
the game is a pain to play

Enemy scaling is a great way to suck all the fun out of progression. After all, why even bother getting stronger, if you're facing enemies of the same relative strength anyway? On the other side, the combat is quite something! It does require a hefty dose of reaction, as well as situational awareness, you know, m4d g4m0r sk1llz. Different enemy types, hit zones, the latter coming with gratiutous gore. Holy hell, the gore! The core gameplay loop is that of a shlocky B-grade zombie movie with the desperation & hopelessness of the actual survivors providing but a contrast to your own carnage. Breaking weapons don't add much in terms of survival, rather serving as some additional source of depth.

Overall, clearly on the repetative/dull side of things, the tropical backdrop as well as depth in combat do a lot to make it fun.

Dead Island had awful performance on PC when I played it with an Nvdia 960 and movement felt delayed. I researched it after buying, turns out people did have a problem with PC optimization from consoles, so buyer beware.

 Honestly, the main draw to this game for me was nostalgia watching Youtubers play it back around 2011, and the unique tropical island theme (which slowly falls off after the first beach level). The story was super forgettable, I played it to the end solo, but it was pretty mediocre. The settings were cool, and the combat was simple but fair given the initial release date. Once you find a gun, it really shows its age. It’s pretty janky all things considered.

If you have no nostalgia for Dead Island, I think your time/money is better off with another game. Otherwise, I say consider buying on a sale because by the end of the game, I was getting tired of the gameplay loop and sub-par performance that I didn’t want to sit through the Riptide sequel.

More thoroughly thoughts: Overall, a downgrade....

Huge performance hog noticeable even on a vastly superior computer than the one I've played Classic

Chairs and every other prop that went flying with kicks, explosions and whatever are now "ghost" props... meh.

EVERY NPC used to talk something as the quests and rep went on, but now they are just dumb manequins.

The minimap seems inferior, is somewhat buggy, and it is no longer possible to keep NORTH UP. Its pathing is also buggier and will disappear more frenquelty (IE, player/quest pathing is buggier)

[h1]Dead Island[/h1]

[h1]"Welcome to Paradise."[/h1]

[h1]Introduction:[/h1]
By far the first Zombie game that I liked that changed the entire Zombie genre for me. Before Dead Island, there were so many different Zombies games but none of them had long playability or longevity of any kind, as in you would play it once and then forget about it and maybe replay it in a few years if you get nostalgic enough. 

But Dead Island was different from the beginning. I picked it up years ago on a sale for the Xbox 360 and the amount of fun I had was unlike any other for a zombie game. Now that I got to revisit it years later I can tell you that the game still holds up today. Sure there are better zombie games like Dying Light for an instance. [b](Made by the same developers.)[/b] But the game is still loads of fun if you pick it up for a cheap price. 

[h1]The Story:[/h1]
4 people from four different backgrounds find themselves on Banoi Island. An island country inspired by Papua New Guinea. When the outbreak begins by unknown methods those 4 people find themselves to be immune to the virus and they band together hoping for a way off the island. [b](I know this sounds really basic but trust me this game doesn't really have a good story, to begin with. It's the gameplay that defines it.)[/b]

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
● 4 player CO-OP
● Loads of Zombies everywhere
● Steam trading cards
● Steam Achievements
● Lite RPG mechanics
● 4 unique player characters [b]~ Sam B, Logan, Xian Mei, and Purna. They all have unique playstyles and preferences.[/b]

● Unique zombies [b]~ Thug, Ram, and Butcher just to name a few, I will let you figure out what they do or what they look like.[/b]

● Graphics [b]~ They still hold up today and even more so if you can get a ReShade on your hands.[/b]

● Gameplay [b]~ It's not as great as Dying Light per se but it still holds up today and it is fun nonetheless[/b]

● Gore & Ragdoll system [b]~ You can hack off limbs, break bones and send enemies flying with the awesome gore and ragdoll system Dead Island has.[/b]

● Weapons [b]~ From the firearms to the melee weapons. Dead Island strived for having a really good melee system. There are tons of bladed, blunt, unarmed and other types of weapons featured.[/b]

● Various locations [b]~ From the paradise island itself to the city slums to even the deep jungle island. There are many diverse locations featured.[/b]

● Atmospheric and scary locations [b]~ Deep jungles, swamps, sewers, and other locations have a certain eeriness to it and I love it personally.[/b]

● Decent optimization [b]~ Runs great and it has quite a bunch of options for the player. Although it misses basic features like FOV slider or AF. Although it can be easily fixed.[/b]

● Game time [b]~ It will take you quite some time to finish the game. 30+ or 50+ hours at the very least.[/b]

● Excellent price [b]~ For £11.99 you will easily get loads of game time in this game if you like exploring and finishing side quests.[/b]

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
● Clunky movement [b]~ The movement is very clunky and old. As in you can't grab ledges or vault. The walking method is always rather awkward to handle and control. You get used to it after some time but that doesn't excuse the game. There should've been some update to this so-called "Definitive Edition."[/b]

● Clunky vehicle controls [b]~ The driving itself isn't bad. It's the sensitivity when looking around. There is no way to change it anywhere so you're stuck with a PowerPoint level of speed when wanting to look around or behind you.[/b]

● Melee range [b]~ The melee system is still good in this game, one problem though is the fact that you have to be right up in the zombies face in order to get a hit and this literally applies to every weapon no matter the type. Batons, axes, Kanabō will all require you to be in face range in order for you to get a successful hit. It sucks.[/b]

● No blocking [b]~ There is no blocking with your weapons. You may only jump away from the enemies' blow but just like the movement, it is rather clunky. A block system even a basic one would have been so much better than this lackluster dodge system but alas we have to make do with what we got.[/b]

● Melee weapon condition [b]~ I have no idea whose idea this was but literally EVERY single melee weapon. Doesn't matter if it's a common variant or a legendary variant will degrade faster than a piece of paper.[/b]

● NPC escorts [b]~ They suck alright? I should be the one ensuring that the NPC I am escorting survives the trip. But these idiots will literally rush ahead of me and 99% of the time get themselves killed. I was escorting a Russian NPC and there was a huge zombie crowd ahead of him so I did what anyone else would do and threw a Molotov. Only for the re*ard to jump down into the fire and get himself killed. Seriously!?[/b]

● Weapon blueprints [b]~ There is a LOT of weapon blueprints in the game. When you discover one and read the name of the blueprint you will get excited because it sounds like it could be a deadly weapon. That is when you learn that about 80% of the weapon blueprints are rehashed copies of one another.[/b]

● Lip syncing [b]~ I know this game is old but the lip-syncing was awful back then and it still is awful today. There were many games that came out in 2011 with much much better lip-syncing than this. Clearly this game was made with a budget.[/b]

● The story [b]~ The story is awful. The survivors in the cutscenes take so many unnecessary, stupid, and risky moves that you will be pulling the hair out of your head. The only survivors with some sense of intelligence are Sam B and Logan. But the rest of them especially the girls are just plain dumb. They think with emotions instead of their heads. They need to look out for themselves yet they think that everyone can be saved. In these situations, not everyone can be saved. Sam B and Logan know it yet the rest of them don't. Jin is by far the worst offender. She is told multiple times to not do this specific thing yet she does it anyway and it is up to the player, in the end, to save her from the trouble. She is dumb, annoying, naive, and inexperienced for the world ahead of you. The fact that you have to travel with her all the way to the end is another annoyance. If it was up to me I would have just left her with some group of survivors and let her be their problem.[/b]

● Clunky shooting [b]~ The shooting is God awful. They seem to only be effective against human enemies. But zombies just seem to be bulletproof even if shot in the head. The shotgun which is obtained only at the end of the game is practically useless against the zombies. On top of that, the recoil and handling of it just feels strange and awkward.[/b]

● Zombie throwable weapons [b]~ Normal zombies can sometimes be seen carrying weapons. If there was an enemy stronger than all of the zombies in the game then it would be those zombies. As they can literally throw a small piece of wood at you from the continent of Africa and directly impact you. These hits will literally kill you in one hit or reduce your health to nothing. For me, it was the latter 99% of the time. This death was the biggest loss of money for me almost the entire time. It is such a bullsh*t mechanic. Whoever implemented this deserves an African slap across the face.[/b]

[h1]Conclusion:[/h1]
Overall Dead Island is still a good game. Despite the numerous cons, the game was still a fun adventure. All zombie lovers should give this a go as it is very cheap even when not on a discount. The combat is bloody and gruesome, the zombie variants are impressive and the world is huge and expansive.

[h1]Overall rating 6.5/10[/h1]

I believe this is the fourth time I've attempted to play Dead Island. I always end up losing interest and being irritated by the bugs before I even finish Act II.

I had hoped that the Definitive Edition would fix the things that were stupid--a list too long to go into here--but it didn't. I'm not really sure why the Definitive Edition even needs to exist. It seems to have no purpose other than to bait suckers like me into buying it in the hopes that the awesome game that Dead Island could have and SHOULD have been had finally been released.

I can't think of another game that seems like it could be awesome, and would be awesome if not for stupid bugs and dumb design choices--NEVER auto-equip items to a player's hotbar--holding it back from you actually enjoying the game.

I think people love to hate Dead Island because we see that it could be awesome, but the game-breaking design flaws and completely-ignored bugs show a group of developers who rushed a great idea and didn't care to go back and correct their mistakes.

Not only do I not recommend this game if you've played the original--because it's the same damn game--I don't recommend it if you've never played it. I got it on sale for about $3, if I recall correctly, and I guess if you want to pay that much just to see what everyone hates about it, I can understand.

Dead Island is infamous, and for bad reason. It deserves that infamy, but don't hold it against Dying Light (the spiritual sequel to it). Dying Light is the sequel to what Dead Island could have been.

EDIT: 5th's time the charm, I guess. I gave it a go on my Steam Deck and finally beat the game. I just rushed through Acts 3 and 4, though. Still the same game, but I did finally beat it. Don't recommend it.

Achievements: 
The game has a total of 57 achievements to unlock. Some of them are easy to get, while others require more effort and time. You’ll need to play with different characters and complete various quests to get them all.

Characters: 
The game features four playable characters: Sam B., Logan, Purna, and Xian Mei. Each character has unique abilities and skills that make them suitable for different playstyles. For example, Sam B. is a tank, while Purna is a support character. Choosing the right character can make a big difference in how you experience the game.

Story: 
The game takes place on the island of Banoi, which has been overrun by zombies. You play as one of the four survivors who must fight their way through hordes of zombies to escape the island. The story is engaging and keeps you hooked until the end.

Missions: 
The game has a variety of missions that you can complete. Some of them are part of the main story, while others are side quests. The missions are well-designed and offer a good mix of combat, exploration, and puzzle-solving.

General rating: 
Overall, Dead Island Definitive Edition is a great game that offers a lot of content and replayability. The game has a good mix of action, horror, and RPG elements that make it a unique experience. The game’s graphics and sound design are also top-notch. I would highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys zombie games or action RPGs.

[h1]  So bad, it's bad! [/h1]

I remember the trailer for this during the zombie revival of the late-2000's - early-2010's. It's probably still one of the best trailers for a video game ever made, in the sense that it got a lot of people (including myself) to fully buy into an otherwise mediocre game. Back then I wasn't as conditioned against the hype train like I am now, to the point of any and all hype potentially being a turn off and having the opposite of its intended effect. The opening scene is just as bad as I remember from the first time I played the game, and the cliches and stereotypes that were bad back then have only aged like fine milk. The writing and dialogue has to be some of the worst I've ever seen. It's not even fun in like a campy, "so bad it's good" kind of way... it's just bad. Now that they've re-released this on a newer-ish engine (8 years old at the time of me writing this) you'd expect it to look and perform really well, but it does neither. It's very buggy and the frame rate somehow struggles on a machine that can run games that look a million times better than this just fine. I was getting achievement popups for stuff I hadn't done yet, like I'd kill a zombie with a melee weapon and it would pop up "Killed 10 Zombies with a melee weapon." Very little effort went into making sure this was actually a good port, so I'd say paying $3 for this might be overpaying, given that it's a bad port of a bad game. Maybe there is some fun to be had here if you can rope some friends into playing, which is what a lot of the positive reviews seem to be, but it seems like a bad waste of time. My only regret is I played this outside the refund window.

I wanted to wait until I finished the entire game to write a review, to maybe give it some sort of 
chance, but end of act 2/beginning of act 3 is enough for me to say this game is not good. 

[h1]Repetitiveness[/h1]
It starts out fun, as you learn the combat, and the first few quests are fine in terms of your goals, and the process of achieving them. Once you get used to the combat, though, is when you start getting bored of it as it just becomes a repetitive tedious task which you try to avoid at all costs.

[h1]Weapon Customization[/h1]
The weapon customization the game seems to boast about is quite unbalanced, uninspired, lacking and limited. Even if there is a seemingly gimmicky customization, it just adds some sort of thing to your weapon, but swings the same, and might do something else in terms of the visible damage to the zombies, but nothing more. 

[h1]Driving[/h1]
The driving in the game is horrible in so many ways. The drivable vehicle models are very few (only 3, including the mandatory mission van, 11h in, after 2 acts). The driving itself is really clunky and badly done, and sometimes the steering wheel doesn't turn if you press the forwards and direction key too quickly one after the other. The terrain which you drive on can sometimes be really annoying and you end up crashing a lot of times or just being unable to move through, having to get out and fight the hordes of zombies to get to your destination.

[h1]Characters[/h1]
The characters and story are unmemorable (although I doubt the game tries to make them be), the writing is not very good, the voice acting is mediocre, and the game features several poor attempts at making you feel emotional for a character. I'm 12 hours in and I only know the name of 2 characters in the game, and that's only because I've heard their name get repeated dozens of times.

[h1]Why I decided to rate it early[/h1]

[b]CONTAINS MINOR SPOILERS[/b]

As you are finishing act 2, your crew finally establishes contact with a radio guy they've been trying to contact for the entirety of the game! Great news, except for some reason, you, and most of your crew are suspicious of the guy because he is situated on a prison on an island, which doesn't make any sense. So, they start fighting with him over the radio over nothing, then just breaking the line for no apparent reason after all that trying? Nonetheless, at the start of act 3, they talk with him again, and again, they are suspicious for no apparent reason and decide to yell at him again and break contact once again, all while doing it in the most ignorant annoying way possible. This, on top of all the previous bad parts about this game, made me close it and immediately go write a negative review.

[h1]Should you get the game?[/h1]
If you're looking for a realistic, engaging, and story rich zombie survival game, you should not get it even on sale for 4 euros, as all you'll be getting [b]maybe[/b] 3h of fun followed by suffering which will make you regret ever purchasing the game in the first place.

If the reason you want to buy the game is just to kill some zombies, you should buy the game on sale, but still don't expect to have fun the whole time.

[b]TL;DR:[/b] Don't buy it unless you enjoy playing bad games, or are just looking to buy it to decorate your steam game collection.

[i]I will still attempt to finish the whole game, and update the review if necessary.[/i]

Dead Island Definitive Edition: Where Vacation Means Business... Zombie Business! 💼🧟‍♂️

Forget the typical beachside activities; this game upgrades your holiday to a corporate-level undead takeover. Board meetings with zombies? Check. Water cooler gossip about the latest zombie fashion trends? You bet. It's the ultimate office retreat – just replace the stapler with a spiked baseball bat. Clock in for the zombie grind, 9 to undead! 🏝️💀

The Dead Island Definitive Edition held a special place in my gaming aspirations, even though I missed its initial release. I used to peep into my older brother's room and see him playing it and thought, "Wow that shit looks sick, it's like a first-person Dead Rising". However, upon playing it myself, my perspective shifted. While it might have been considered innovative and fresh during its time, my experience unveiled a game dominated by an extensive and convoluted fetch quest structure, interspersed with enjoyable open-world exploration in Acts 1-3 and passable combat.

A notable drawback lies in the absence of a proper dodge mechanic, despite a makeshift jump + direction key combo that fails to impress. This absence contributes to a perceived slowness in combat. On the flip side, the weapons in the game feel weighty and impactful, particularly the kick and most of the larger-bladed weapons!

The story in Dead Island Definitive Edition moves towards cliché, with missions often boiling down to three archetypal fetch-quest scenarios: go to location A and retrieve/activate something, collect five of a specific object, or protect someone while they perform a task. Unfortunately, the quests become monotonous and repetitive after the initial ten hours, though the brevity of the game at around 15 hours somewhat mitigates this issue.

However, Act 4 of the game feels notably rushed, lacking the depth and polish found in the earlier acts. The missions seem hastily put together, and the pacing becomes erratic. This hurried feel culminates in a final boss battle that is disappointingly uninspired and fails to evoke the excitement one would expect from a climactic encounter. It's a missed opportunity for a memorable conclusion that leaves players underwhelmed.

In hindsight, revisiting Dead Island might not be the most enjoyable experience for someone who last played it on the 360/PS3, as it hasn't aged gracefully. However, for those intrigued by the Dying Light franchise and curious about its spiritual predecessor, grabbing Dead Island Definitive Edition on sale isn't a regrettable decision!

Dead Island - 6/10

I had initially planned to embark on an achievement run in this game, but truth be told, I find it challenging to muster the motivation to persevere through the gameplay. My youth holds cherished memories of this game, where the excitement of exploring the resort and battling zombies was truly exhilarating. Undoubtedly, the resort remains the highlight of the game; however, the rest of the gameplay is marred by significant flaws and can be downright irksome at times.

From the inconsistent and buggy combat mechanics to the shockingly poor human AI, the protection missions in the city are nothing short of horrendous. Battling the gangs is an even more of a horrendous experience, reaching a point where it makes the enemies in Dying Light seem like geniuses. While the gunplay is passable, the frustration peaks when shooting a zombie in the head doesn't result in an instant kill, making the firearms feel more like pellet shooters than effective weapons.

The story is acceptable, neither particularly noteworthy nor terrible. The characters, for the most part, are forgettable. While the locations are decent, numerous obstacles like chairs and bags obstruct the pathways, rendering the running segments of gameplay rather irksome.

Overall
Pros: - Fun intro
- Decent although forgettable melee combat
- Glitchy co-op

Cons:
- Everything above
- Awkward gameplay leading to annoying outcomes
- AI is so terrible it gets another mention here

[b]Dead Island[/b] feels like they came up with one great mechanic (The melee combat with analog sticks) and surrounded it with half-baked content all around. Driving is floaty and shooting sucks. Movement in general is clunky. It's really easy to get stuck on random props.

[h1] My Honest Reaction: Dead Island Definitive Edition [/h1]

So I'm a tad late to the Dead Island party and my overall experience is a solid 6/10. I finished this entire game solo in 20 hours, on & off in the span of two weeks, and that included doing most of the side missions before completing the main storyline.

[h2] Gameplay: [/h2]
I can forgive the janky gameplay considering this was a 2011 game , and having played Dying Light (my fav btw) prior to touching Dead Island, I had to get used to the slow transitions between combat and traversal but generally a decent movement set for a moderate-paced zombie hack n' slash. This was an enjoyable game to pass the time although later stages could get frustrating if you're not great at organising inventory, and not upgrading your weapons more than you should be. 

The skill-tree is a lifesaver, and the 'Fury' section can mostly be ignored as I barely used this gimmicky skill once I obtained more powerful weapons mid-game, and only focused on increasing stamina, damage and weapon durability.

[h2] Bugs: [/h2]
There were some missions where I had to mow through an entire town of gunmen, only to not have the final boss appear or invisible walls not deactivate then I would run back to the start, mow through the town again (they re-spawned) and THEN have the final stage of the mission appear. Other than that, a few minor bugs can be overlooked as they're not that detrimental to your progression.

[h2] Story: [/h2]
Oh boy, where do I begin. I had no idea what the story of this game was when it first release, despite watching early game-plays on YouTube, but finally playing through the entirety of it has made me feeling confused and unsatisfied.

[b][i]*Spoilers Ahead*[/i][/b]

Dead Island begins with the main characters stranded in a hotel resort surrounded by a zombie infection. 
[i] Good start, I'm pumped. Let me at 'em [/i]
Various objectives require you to retrieve and return objects, while killing baddies on the way
[i] okayy, as expected of an action-adventure. Give me something moree [/i]
We later find out that the virus originated from a group of natives inhabiting the jungles of the island.
[i] Interesting! (?) I can sort of believe it. Not the craziest thing I've heard so far [/i]
[spoiler]The military man from a super-maximum prison wants you to obtain a cure, send it to said prison, take it from you as he knocks you unconscious, turn super evil and send a mob of zombies AND humans to stop you, gets infected by his dead wife, shoots the one side-character as everyone watches, turns into the most mid zombie; highly vulnerable to elemental and explosive damage, dies.
[i] Uh...uhm, okay. That escalated... like a LOT. A bit nonsense but surely the next part should resolve it, tie up all loose ends quickly...right? [/i]
Hearing news that Banoi is quarantined, the team fly away from the prison in a helicopter.
[/spoiler]
[i] aaaaaaand!? [/i]
Game ends. Credits roll.
[i] Motherf*cker... [/i]

Despite having game-changing game-play mechanics, Dead Island's generic amalgamation of action-adventure tropes could not save the absurdity of its final act. The four main characters Sam B, Xian Mei, Purna and Logan all seemed like interesting characters that had me wanting to know more about who they are and what makes them special as survivors immune to infection. 
Instead throughout the game, I almost felt no attachment to their characters and there was times during cinematics where I felt like I missed something in the story. There were clearly times of conflict between the four members but it was never revealed how it originates or how it becomes resolved and the game clearly skips these moments of developemtn and decompression, purely for the sake of progressing and getting right back into the action, making their actions feel robotic and empty, like they're templates for a great action-protagonist group instead of being one.

As for Jin, her side-story of losing her father and taking the responsibility of the crew's equipment felt somewhat fulfilling and close-ended, like she could've stopped being involved before the second act. But the rest of the game needed a 'storage' mechanic and we're too late in the game to introduce a new character with the same character development, so Jin stuck along for the rest of the ride, all up until her confusingly and hilarious demise. 
Why did Jin get the final monologue before punishing the big bad? Why was she the one to release the zombie wife and be the only one to die because of it. Why did everyone just stand there and watch her get shot and fall off the platform, AND watch Mister Military-I-Can't-Remember-The-Name-Of inject the only apparent hope for the people of Banoi into his body? 

The ending of Dead Island felt rushed, and packed with too much information to be resolved in the limited cutscene before the final "battle". Jin's character was wasted on a plot-device purely meant to evoke feeling and quickly progress to the boss fight, but her actions and the direction that led up to her end was comically stupid and erased any instance of minute attachment anyone ever had of her. If anything, it felt only right for the team to apprehend Mister Military White and give a monologue on hope and humanity since it meshes well metaphorically as a co-op game or even Yerema should've died since she's a crucial part of the cure and that valiantly takes away any hope for humanity AND hope for White to bring his wife back. But alas, the team does nothing but watch because the game still needed a reason to proceed to the boss battle.

The game ends without any explanation of what happens to the people in the Resort, Lighthouse, Church, River Village etc. and the Island is closed-off to the rest of the world with room for more opportunities for sequels. 

I have not played Riptide at the time of writing, and frankly I have been hesitant to, but I'll give it a shot since I need something to kill the time. 

[h3] TL;DR [/h3]
Gameplay is good, story is a bit eh and over the place so I recommend playing with friends and have fun with it. Bought this and Riptide together for 12 bucks, pretty good deal for people looking for a quick hack n' slash kick out of it.

Dead Island: Definitive Edition is the remaster (2016) to the original game, which was released in 2011 after a wide marketing campaign involving a really sad CGI trailer with a dead child and some tie-in short films and novelizations. I can’t seem to find much about development as it keeps redirecting me back to the development hell of Dead Island 2 so I assume the game went swimmingly for the first part. I had initially missed the whole sad trailer hype so I never really knew what everyone was on about with the game per say, only that I had some buddies who played it and wanted me to join them. I remember first dropping into a 360 lobby with some peeps and a random person gave me a modded (not in game but an actual modded) baseball bat that sent people flying along with an infinite ammo shotgun. Playing the game with these items actually made the game fun but other than playing it with buddies from time to time, I didn’t really remember much of the game other than certain locations popping in my head every once in a while along with Sam B, so I bought the game for other people twice so I could play a coop game with them. The first two times failed because the game was incredibly boring and it didn’t mesh well with the others but third times the charm so shoutout to Brandon, Casey and Asian for the play session, and I'll also say that the Remaster comes with all the OG game's DLC in case you were wondering.

Overall, the plot in Dead Island is kind of middling a bit in my opinion. I like certain ideas about it, like the mystery behind The Voice, the potential to bond with and help survivors, the whole virus being a certain strain of Kuru in relation to the native tribes in the jungle, like it has some things I could see being interesting from a realistic perspective. However, I honestly hate to say this but I don't really care. The backstories you get for your main heroes don’t factor in at all to their character development in-game in anyway shape or form, and either you’re decent like Purna or Xian Mei or kind of an a s s like Logan or Sam B (not even an interesting one to be honest). The other characters are forgettable except Ryder White himself and Jin, with the latter just because she's kind of relatively annoying and kind of frustrating with certain story beats. For example, after being told multiple times not to go to the police station because they’re raiders and not nice people, she goes to deliver food anyways because it’s “the right thing to do” and then gets kidnapped for it, like no s h i t it’s not a good idea but she’s a good Samaritan so I can respect the intentions. Getting shot because she released Ryder’s dead wife in the end however? That was just stupid to do, though the rest of it with her being sad I can sort of understand with her experiences. In fact, she’s the only one I do understand because Ryder’s stuff you only really learn in a two hour DLC and even though there’s a twist in there (with him not being the voice), it didn’t feel like much of anything changed anyways from what was presented in the main campaign. Honestly, I barely remember ANYTHING with the main plot because as one review I read put it, it’s basically doing “errands inside of errands inside of other errands” and it just feels boring. If I could compare the main plot of this game to something it would be a DoorDash delivery, because literally that’s kind of all it is. Same with the side quests, there are some interesting ones I sort of remember but not enough that I’d want to spotlight them to be honest, and you kinda need to do these in order to level up while speaking of the gameplay.

The gameplay is not my cup of tea really and here’s why. The game’s mechanics surround itself with a system that we still see even to this day: level based combat. Level based combat can be fine if it’s not monotonous, but here it kind of is. Luckily zombies level up as you level up so it’s not unfair that you’re restricted from certain areas due to you being a level 9 and them being 26 but it’s still frustrating a bit due to the tools you're given. You earn weapons doing quests and pick weapons up off of the ground to use against zombies, and you're encouraged to use resources to mod these weapons (which hilariously enough also requires money, which why? You stuffing dollar bills into your electro sickle?) but if you constantly invest money into these weapons only for an hour or two later to have a better weapon with better stats that makes your old weapon kind of pointless, then why spend the resources to upgrade it in the first place. This is a pattern that kept going on for me throughout the entire game, and at this point it only felt worth it to wait til I was at maximum level to do it. That’s not to say each hero can’t do damage on their own, as each one has their own skill trees depending on the type of person you are. I played as Sam B, who was mainly a bruiser guy and whose skills mainly used heavier blunt weapons. I barely used the heavy weapons cause they always felt like ass but besides the point, you kind of create your own build depending on your skill trees and what you want, and you can’t upgrade everything to the top from what I understand. Purna’s special involves pulling out a gun and guns are her main thing (which you don’t even get an actual gun til’ later in the city so it’s helpful in the resort), Xian Mei has knives and Logan is just projectiles (which feels kind of useless because Xian Mei has knives so if Logan has throwing knives then what’s the point?).

The zombies I’ll start out by saying that I appreciate how much of an actual threat they come off compared to zombies in say Dead Rising. It’s a very strategic game and combat is based off of “how much stamina do you have in your bar” and “this guy is kind of a powerhouse, could I perhaps cripple his legs and make him fall down for some free hits?” and I can appreciate that aspect in relation to the horror the game is based around. Even seeing a giant horde come around and attempt to murder me is scary, but also kind of annoying because it gets into this loop of getting bounced around like a pinball machine before eventually dying and losing a percentage of my money. The more money you have, the more money you lose and it always feels punishing no matter if it’s my fault or if it’s someone else's. As an example, two of my buddies got tired later in the game and started messing with grenades and I got killed multiple times by accident and lost 100 grand out of 160 and that was frustrating as hell to lose all of that. As for actual combat, my experience playing co-op mostly consists of knocking out a few zombies then having to team up with the homies to kill one. I also want to point out here, playing this game in co-op brings the difficulty up a lot, while it’s a lot easier if it’s just you to go solo. I guess my main point is that while I appreciate the threat of the zombies, I feel like with how the game is balanced and mixed in with the level based combat system it goes from scary to annoying really quick, as I feel like I got cheap deaths (like pushed off a cliff for example) more than anything else, especially with suiciders.

Dead Island is one of the best zombie games ever made and one of my first Steam games. I absolutely love playing this game with my God Slayer Xian Mei.

The graphics in the game are spectacular and the action is intense. The cutscenes are also some of the best I've seen. I especially enjoy playing co-op with other people. It's a great opportunity to team up and take down hordes of zombies together. 

The weapons and upgrades are diverse and you can make your character the way you want to. I love collecting and modifying new weapons. Having all these options is a great element in the game and makes it that much more enjoyable.

Overall, Dead Island is one of the best zombie games I have ever played and it's certainly worth playing with friends. The co-op is an awesome experience and if you're a fan of zombie games, then you definitely need to check this out.

[b]TL;DR:[/b] It is a console game, that basically just got ported and not a single thing has been adjusted for the PC except for "registering the keyboard and mouse". The Gameplay get's stale pretty fast.


[b]Pros:[/b]
[list]
[*] A lot of sidequests wherever you go. Most of them are basically the same, but still believable. Everybody would require mostly the same help in such situation.
[*] Navigation via the minimap is ok in most cases
[*] Hack n Slash works decent
[*] Various weapons and mods that you can apply to "fake" diversity
[*] Potential Co-Op
[*] Your rewards from quests and loot scales with your level
[*] Enemies scale with your level - so you can remain in the same area while the loot and xp gains grow
[/list]



[b]Cons:[/b]
[list]
[*] Story is bad
[*] [b]Graphics and character design[/b]
[list]
[*] Every single of your possible characters seems to be a prick. You don't have an influence on that - at all.
[*] Voice acting is terrible
[*] Graphics are meh
[*] Character models are disgustingly ugly and the most scary thing in the entire game - no wonder you get attacked non stop
[/list]

[*] [b]Gunplay is one of the worst I have ever seen[/b]
[list]
[*] Upon ADS-ing there is a crazy aimbot on enemies bodies (never their head!) - even through walls
[*] There is an even bigger aimsupport whenever you aim next to enemies, that slows down your mouse movement so that you have to wipe across your entire mousepad to switch from somebody, you are aiming to, to another one that is literally right next to them. Same when you want to correct your ADS-aimbot from chest to head. It is just tedious and unreliable
[*] Not ADS-ing works in close range but later in the game it is required since the weapons are not accurate enough when you don't ADS ...... So you can't compensate it with your own skill. FUN
[*] No way to disable the aimbot and aimsupport
[*] No way to adjust the ADS sensitivity separately
[*] Shotgun feels terrible. Doesn't deal any damage to the head, even close range, when all pallets hit. It is only effective against charging enemies while in close range. Since there are usually multiple that charge you at once and the shotguns shoot rather slow you are most likely better of with a sword anyway.
[/list]

[*] [b]Gameplay[/b]
[list]
[*] Every now and then you need to use these guns though. Especially against living humans, that usually die to a headshot. Due to the low amount of bullets you can hold, you kinda have to run around with a pistol and a rifle all the time, taking up two valuable slots of your tiny inventory.
[*] There is a lot of slow motion going on when you kill an enemies or cut off limbs - why? Don't slow the game down and break the immersion
[*] The sidequest rewards can range from garbage to actually good weapons or blueprints. The major downside however is: You can not see what your reward is going to be - because that depends on your level at completion - not when you started it. But please at least show me which type of reward and of which rarity it is going to be. Potentially it is rare, but most likely it is going to be garbage. Especially in the later levels (35+) there are no good weapon drops anymore, so you are reliant on them to update your arsenal.
I assume it is smarter to ignore many of the midgame sidequests to avoid leveling up that fast. Especially when you are a firearm expert (which you should not pick btw)
[*] Your inventory is way too small, since your weapons break very fast depending on what you use and you need to loot enemies weapons to make profit. (Most importantly at levels 35+)
[*] Distribution of traders and workbenches is stupid. In a few areas there is one at every corner, in others you run around for half an hour without a single one. Combine this with scaling enemies and a tiny inventory and you get a lot of broken weapons so you can't touch enemies anymore. NICE. In this case you are going to die A LOT until you reach a trader or workbench.
[*] The skill tree is terrible. After level ~30 there are not necessarily any useful perks left. I never used the rage mode (still don't know how to activate it, due to the non existing keybind visualisation - see below) and never wanted to use firearms, which unfortunately was my characters expertise. For non firearm experts it may be different.
[*] The movement is weird. I don't know whether it is a performance issue or a bug, but whenever you run longer distances you slow down drastically every few meters, even though the FPS are stable. It feels so weird and actually made me sick a few times in certain areas
[*] Variety of non boss-enemies is 8. Which is ridiculously low and makes the game very repetitive.
[/list]

[*] [b]Usability, User interface, QoL[/b]
[list]
[*] FPS are locked at 60
[*] No way to adjust difficulty - game is way too easy in the beginning and gets tedious after level 30/35
[*] The keybind options are terrible - a lot of the actions are not listed and it took me a while to figure out how to open the weapon wheel for quick selection. Other listed options simply don't work
[*] Unfortunately there is no quick selection of a specific weapon. You have to use the weapon wheel or mouse wheel to scroll through them ....
[*] The amount of stuff you can do to your weapons is very limited and doesn't really make them feel different.
[*] Mod-upgrades don't tell you in which way they affect your weapons on the first selection, only in the combination menu with one of your weapons. Missing QoL in the user interface
[*] Can't zoom out from the map far enough to see the entire map, so you are constantly shifting the map around to search for locations ....
[*] Can't filter for specific things on the map
[*] Options to tweak the game are basically nonexistent
[/list]
[/list]

At the time of writing this review, I've spent completed the main plot line and some side quests in roughly ~22 hours playing the 2011's Dead Island, from the makers of the Dying Light's franchise and a prequel to one of the longest awaited and development-hell ridden, Dead Island 2.  Dead Island is a more of a light-themed experience with multiple protagonists to pick from, set in a remote island archipelago in the Oceania.

It offers some RPG-like mechanics to level up your character's three main skill trees (Fury, Combat and Survival), where with each level increase of your protagonist, the world around you also levels up - so the game actually balances the risk and reward to keep you from feeling overpowered and ensures you can feel strong as well as vulnerable at times.  This prevents you from toying around, which is essentially to keep you in your character's foot.

The game is basically broken down into "hubs" with huge playable open-world areas, with some areas being vastly larger than others, sort of similar to Deus Ex HR/MK, with areas to explore and learn about the island, its natives and lifestyle.

The game isn't jank-free, released in 2011 when the concept of high quality PC ports wasn't really a thing - the motion blur and chromatic aberration implementation is quite awful which can not be completely removed without modding. Zombies re-spawn just few feet away from you and quite frequently - this is problematic as it can catch you by surprise, there's also no concept of zombie count decreasing, which is somewhat unexpected as our progress through the story should have some level of impact on it.

Each chapter has main quest, side quests (and recurring quests).  Main quests help you progress through the campaign, whereas side quests help you learn about the world (and some are essential and contribute towards the main plotline).  The third form, is to gain cash or items by fulfilling demands of certain characters at specific places around the map (usually safe-houses).

Although the game is far from perfect, it is in some ways better than the original "non-Definitive Edition" and has been fun for the massive discounted price I got the entire Dead Island bundle for.

Badly dated, overly repetitive and just plain boring, the most remarkable thing about Dead Island is the original game announcement trailer. Released in 2006, the controversial decision to include a dead child got a lot of attention. The trailer is still held up by some as one of the most effective game trailers ever released. If you have an interest in the history of games, I’d recommend giving it a watch.

What I wouldn’t recommend is actually [i]playing[/i] Dead Island. It got lukewarm reviews when it was released and it hasn’t aged great since then. An emphasis on melee combat coupled with awful movement controls is a bad combination. Throw in fetch quests, bad economy balance, constant glitches and an incredibly dull story - and you’ve got quite a stinker.

Sure, killing zombies with a friend is fun, and a lot of people have nostalgia for the times they did that with this game. This remaster is for those people with rose-coloured glasses on, not for those of us with taste.

[h1]Dead Island - Sun, Sand, and Zombie Apocalypse[/h1]

[h2]Rating: ★★★☆☆[/h2]

Playing Dead Island is like planning a dream vacation only to realize the resort is infested with zombies. It's a tropical paradise turned into a survival nightmare, where your beachside cocktail comes with a side of undead chaos.

[h3]Pros:[/h3]

1. [b]Open-World Setting:[/b] The game's open-world design on a zombie-infested tropical island adds a unique flavor to the survival horror genre. Exploring the scenic yet perilous environment is both thrilling and terrifying.

2. [b]Weapon Crafting:[/b] Crafting your weapons from seemingly random items brings out the MacGyver in you. Who knew a baseball bat with nails could be so effective against the undead?

3. [b]Co-op Gameplay:[/b] The option for cooperative multiplayer adds a layer of camaraderie to the zombie apocalypse. Teaming up with friends to bash zombie heads is strangely satisfying.

4. [b]Varied Environments:[/b] The game offers a variety of environments, from beach resorts to dense jungles, keeping the backdrop fresh as you battle your way through the undead hordes.

5. [b]Emphasis on Melee Combat:[/b] While guns are available, the emphasis on melee combat is a refreshing change. There's a visceral satisfaction in smashing zombies with a sledgehammer.

[h3]Cons:[/h3]

1. [b]Buggy Gameplay:[/b] Dead Island has its fair share of bugs and glitches, from zombies walking through walls to weapons mysteriously disappearing. It's like the undead have mastered the art of teleportation.

2. [b]Clunky Controls:[/b] The controls can feel a bit clunky, especially during combat. Precision movements become a luxury when you're surrounded by a swarm of zombies.

3. [b]Inconsistent Voice Acting:[/b] The voice acting ranges from decent to cringe-worthy. It's as if the survivors are more concerned about the delivery of their lines than the impending zombie apocalypse.

4. [b]Repetitive Missions:[/b] The side quests tend to be repetitive, often boiling down to fetch quests or clearing out zombie-infested areas. It's a formula that wears thin after a while.

5. [b]Outdated Graphics:[/b] The graphics, while once impressive, now feel outdated. The character models and environments lack the polish seen in more recent titles.

[h3]Conclusion:[/h3]

Dead Island is a mix of sun-soaked mayhem and undead chaos. While the tropical setting and weapon customization bring freshness to the genre, the game is marred by technical issues and a lack of polish.

[quote=][i]In the words of a survivor desperately fending off a zombie horde, "I need a freakin' vacation." Dead Island offers a vacation from the ordinary, but be prepared for a getaway filled with both the breathtaking and the brain-eating.[/i][/quote]

Dead Island is a weird game. It's clunky, but it's playable. It's good, but it's also kind of bad. It has cheesy bad dialogue and yet it's hilarious at the same time with memorable lines and characters. The combat is pretty good, but also lacks umph to it. The atmosphere is great at parts and other parts not so much. The driving is frustrating but it's also satisfying when speeding quickly and doing crazy stunts and glitches. 

It's a unique game that I've played through multiple times over the years and to be honest I feel kind of nostalgic for since it carries a lot of good memories. It's one of those it's not a bad game, but it's not amazing either. It seems to be just an overall ok fun game to play that you can't take too seriously.

It's weird to think it came out 12 years ago. I think it's aged well despite it's flaws.

While the campaign is extremely mediocre and honestly forgettable, this game is a gem. This was my first ever open world zombie game. My neighbor used to talk about how cool Sam B was, and we used to go over to his house and play it with him. At one point, he gave me a copy and I played the hell out of it on my Xbox 360. Countless hours of fun, but as an adult, It certainly has it's flaws. For the definitive edition, there are some tweaks that you can do for the game to feel a little more modernized and actually playable, but it's still bearable without them (mostly just movement speed increase and a higher FOV.) Regardless, this game is still a little blast to the past, and allows me to relive a part of my childhood. A good game, even with it's issues.

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead, murdered by my brother-in-law Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, Hank came to me with a rather, shocking proposition. He asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using his connections in the drug world. Connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded, I... I always thought that Hank was a very moral man and I was... thrown, confused, but I was also particularly vulnerable at the time, something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me on a ride along, and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin so I agreed. Every day, I think back at that moment with regret. I quickly realized that I was in way over my head, and Hank had a partner, a man named Gustavo Fring, a businessman. Hank essentially sold me into servitude to this man, and when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn. Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling out. From what I can gather, Hank was always pushing for a greater share of the business, to which Fring flatly refused to give him, and things escalated. Fring was able to arrange, uh I guess I guess you call it a "hit" on my brother-in-law, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured, and I wound up paying his medical bills which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge, working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring, and did so. In fact, the bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen in the ranks to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA, and about that time, to keep me in line, he took my children from me. For 3 months he kept them. My wife, who up until that point, had no idea of my criminal activities, was horrified to learn what I had done, why Hank had taken our children. We were scared. I was in Hell, I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, to end this nightmare, and in response, he gave me this. I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. I... All I could think to do was to make this video in hope that the world will finally see this man, for what he really is.

Summary:
"Dead Island" is an action role-playing survival horror video game developed by Techland and published by Deep Silver. The game was released in 2011 for various platforms including PlayStation, Xbox, and PC. Set on the fictional island of Banoi, located in Papua New Guinea, the game follows the story of a group of survivors who find themselves stranded in the midst of a zombie outbreak.

Players can choose one of four playable characters, each with unique skills and abilities, as they attempt to survive and escape the island. The gameplay focuses on exploring the open world, completing quests, crafting weapons and items, and engaging in intense combat with hordes of zombies.

The game is known for its emphasis on melee combat, where players can use a variety of improvised weapons such as baseball bats, knives, and firearms to fight off the undead. The island setting offers diverse environments, from lush jungles to beach resorts, adding to the atmosphere of the game.

"Dead Island" also features a cooperative multiplayer mode, allowing players to team up and tackle the challenges of the zombie-infested island together. The game received mixed reviews from critics, with praise for its engaging combat and open-world exploration, but criticism for technical issues and narrative execution.

Overall, "Dead Island" is notable for its unique blend of survival horror and RPG elements, creating an intense and immersive experience as players strive to survive the zombie apocalypse and uncover the mysteries of the island.

[h1] 𝕀 𝕘𝕠𝕥𝕥𝕒 𝕤𝕒𝕪... 𝕀 𝕟𝕖𝕧𝕖𝕣 𝕥𝕙𝕠𝕦𝕘𝕙𝕥 𝕀'𝕕 𝕝𝕠𝕧𝕖 𝕤𝕖𝕖𝕚𝕟𝕘 𝕫𝕠𝕞𝕓𝕚𝕖𝕤 𝕥𝕨𝕚𝕥𝕔𝕙𝕚𝕟𝕘 𝕠𝕟 𝕥𝕙𝕖 𝕘𝕣𝕠𝕦𝕟𝕕 𝕨𝕙𝕚𝕝𝕖 𝕘𝕖𝕥𝕥𝕚𝕟𝕘 𝕖𝕝𝕖𝕔𝕥𝕣𝕚𝕗𝕚𝕖𝕕... 𝕀𝕥 𝕨𝕒𝕤 𝕢𝕦𝕚𝕥𝕖 𝕤𝕙𝕠𝕔𝕜𝕚𝕟𝕘 𝕝𝕠𝕝 [/h1]

Welcome, survivor, to the Island of Banoi... Had enough fun partying? Guess what, you just woke up to the apocalypse... Now you really gotta put your nimble fingers to the test.

In Dead Island, the whole world has gone to the poopies and you are one of four (or five with DLC) survivors, each with a different set of skills... Your task? Find a way out of this god forsaken place. It's actually easier after you've found out you're immune to the virus... Which actually doesn't serve your cause much if you've got a health bar. 

Dead Island is an action FPS RPG hybrid that's basically about a zombie virus, you get the idea; chaos and a lot of fighting and smashing things are involved. This game holds itself together through time, I swear... It's still graphically very beautiful to look at! Mechanics vary depending on who you're playing; as Logan (my favourite badass gangsta) you get these "dart-knives" you can throw that deal huge amount of damage after your RAGE meter is full... You fuel your Rage meter by kicking some arse. Your character can also take quests, RPG-style... Another very RPG-like thing your character does is level up and pick up new skills from a skilltree, but most of them are passives. 

Story-wise, this game is all over the place; sometimes your hero wants to find the nearest plane, and hijack it out of the island, other times your hero just wants to sit around and do voodoo magic to release the spirits lol... However, as you well know, in a game like this, a story is only secondary to the mayhem... I probably forgot to mention, that you find blueprints around these zombie-infested areas that you can use to craft new custom-made badass weapons. I like to use Katanas with a Light Saber Mod blueprint, which causes the zombies to become electrified and on fire; I gotta say I enjoy it a lot.

Dead Island is a [b]9/10[/b] Zombie RPG game and with badass Logan on the front, and Purna's ghetto sword swinging on the back, these zombies should be the survivors, not the other way around.

I want to try and make this review as mixed as possible, meaning I will state some positives and negatives about this "Definitive Edition" after talking about the game's main plot.

[h1] TL;DR[/h1]
The game has exceptional melee combat, which is one of the main things good about it. It is very satisfying to kill a zombie in many ways possible. However, the "Definitive Edition" is pretty much like the original game with its flaws: repetitive quests that gets bland quickly and dreadful gunplay. Also, you can't play with others that have the original game.


The game's main plot has 4 acts in total, which should take on average somewhere around 20 hours in total to reach the end and beat the game.

Act I takes place in the resort area of Banoi. The map is pretty wide open and you can discover a lot of reachable locations, especially some minor quests where you help out survivors eliminate some zombies while they are stranded. They introduce driveable vehicles, trucks in particular, which are useful in going from Point A to B fast. Two special enemies are introduced: Thug and Suicider infected types. Thug infected are like Walker zombies that move at a slow pace. However, they have a lot of health and can easily knock you down with one swipe. Suiciders on the other hand are creatures that explode when you get too close to them or when they are killed.

Act II takes place in the city of Moresby. This is probably the longest and annoying setting. The area is so cramped and there are a lot of zombies and infected types (the ones that will scream and run at lightning speed). Some of them can even glitch and clip through walls. Not to mention, some annoying quests. The lack of fast travels around the city requires a lot of running. Ram and Floater special infected types are introduced. Rams are tough and strong undead zombies that will charge at you, potentially knocking you down if you are in their line of sight. Their weakpoint is an opening on their back. Floaters are decomposed zombies that spit out projectiles that blind or disorient you and will spray putrid liquid if you get too close. They are hard to kill because they can absorb a lot of damage. Lastly, human enemies are introduced, which are punks armed with either melee weapons or firearms like a pistol or an assault rifle in very rare cases.

Act III takes place in the jungle area of Banoi. This is where things get very interesting in the main plot. Human enemies are now more common to encounter unlike the ones in the Moresby city area. They are known as troops of Afran, an enemy warlord that commands his troops and is also the arch-rival of Matutero of the River Village. They are armed with pistols very commonly and instead of being armed with an assault rifle in very rare cases, they are sometimes armed with one. The last special infected introduced are Butchers, which are essentially faster, stronger versions of the Infected.

Act IV is the last and final act in the game, taking place on a small prison island that is east of the resort. Once you travel to the prison, there is no going back so it is best to prepare and make sure you have everything you need before traveling. The prison is home to many wanted terrorists and criminals from around the world. Firearms and ammo are fairly more common to see and you can buy ammo from prisoner vendors. You learn that "the Voice" first heard in Act I is Ryder White, a colonel in the B.I.D.F (Banoi Island Defense Force). However, you also learn that White is about to leave in a helicopter and will bomb the entire island of Hanoi and you must stop him from escaping after he has drugged you and taken the vaccine. Once you reach and confront him, you witness a hard scene by watching Jin get shot and killed by Ryder after she releases Emily (Ryder's wife that is infected) that causes her to bite Ryder. As Ryder injects the vaccine on him, it actually doesn't turn out to be a cure at all as he mutates into a big zombie. As the last enemy and protagonist, you end this for good by eliminating him and escape in Ryder's helicopter to beat the game.


So that's that for the main plot. Now for the pros and cons based on my experience.

Pros:
+Decent graphics which is nice for those who has owned and played the original game.
+The game is open world. You're free to explore pretty much anywhere and you don't have to finish a quest on a time limit.
+Nice and addicting melee gameplay. You can find a good melee weapon almost anywhere and if you have good luck then you can find a much better one.
+Amazing gore when you kill zombies and human enemies.

Cons:
-You can't play with people that own the original game. If you want to play with each other, then you and your friends must buy and own the "Definitive Edition". Some people bought the original game and still have it to this day and asking people to buy the same game again is very demotivating.
-Wonky movement. By that, the movement is not so smooth at all, even when capping at 60 fps.
-Horrendous gunplay. The gun combat is just... what is even that? There is like some sort of assisted aim that even when aim assist is completely disabled, it's still there.
-Melee weapons will break and don't last for a long time. If you want to keep it running, then you have to find a workbench and repair it.
-Quests are very bland and are all the same. Help survivor get something and return it back to them, escort them to safety, etc. It's a rinse and repeat process to which it gets boring very fast. This doesn't add any originality and creativity.

am a 54 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2022 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game.

This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you were supposed to do. I asked my son for help and he hosted a game for me to join.

I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.

Dead Island is an action-packed and thrilling survival horror game that offers a refreshing twist to the zombie genre. Set on a stunning tropical island overrun by the undead, players embark on a harrowing journey, battling hordes of zombies with an array of makeshift weapons and engaging in gripping combat. The game's open-world environment and immersive storyline create an intense and immersive experience, complemented by a cooperative multiplayer mode that adds to the fun. While some technical issues can be mildly frustrating, Dead Island's gripping gameplay and atmospheric setting make it an enthralling choice for zombie enthusiasts and gamers alike.

I originally had this game on the xbox and completed most/all of the achievements there. Now I'm replaying the game on PC as I get bored of other games and still find myself enjoying the game play. Dead Island is a pretty awesome zombie survival fps. It has some sandbox elements. It sort of reminds me of how Skyrim plays out - you're the hero and you travel from place to place saving people and tying up their loose ends. The arena mode is super fun and somewhat addicting for a while.

All in all, this game is a complete package. Multiplayer is easy to use and you don't need to download hamachi or other third party programs or know how to set up a server and use some arbitrary symbols in a line of code to get it to work.

There are 4 characters to start with and I believe only 1 secret character you eventually get - I hope I am remembering that correctly. I've been playing this game on and off for the last 10 years now. Great game and still very playable today - especially on lower end systems.

The movement will feel awkward and clunky at first, but it something you get used to.

Dead Island - экшон-гриндилка от первого лица про зомбей.Зомби никогда не выйдут из моды, особенно в играх, потому что мочить и без того мертвых оппонентов всегда было и будет весело. 
Сюжет у игры максимально детский и не представляет из себя ничего кроме силы дружбы и сказочного желания жить мирно в ситуации зомби-апокалипсиса. Персонажи не проработаны и их мысли такие же как я описал в предыдущем предложении. Но при этом главная цель все-таки дает какой-то стимул верить что люди в игре правда стараются бежать от беды.
Кат-сцены в игре убогие от чего и смешные, безэмоциональные лица персонажей во время диалогов с повышенной экспрессией, а перевод на русский еще смешнее - во время диалога гг с персонажем можно услышать то, как актеры озвучки просили перезапись сначала или ошибались и смеялись в процессе. Единственная проработанная кат-сцена, проигрывается при заходе в игру, там и анимации и мимика лица на высоте, в самой игре - БУЭ!
Геймплей - моя любимая часть этой игры! Нам предоставляют на выбор 4 персонажей, у которых есть умения в одной из областей использования оружия - метание, огнестрельное, заточенное, тупое, ну и так же у персонажей свои статы на старте, здоровье и выносливость разные. Я играл за заточенное оружие, так как кромсать противника гораздо веселее и проще на мой взгляд. В процессе нарезки противников направо и налево я заметил один огромный минус, залагивание персонажа во время удара, то есть перс может остановиться от слова совсем и принимать на себя волну ударов ходячих. Еще один минус системы боевки, так это то, что зомби имеют особый баг или особенность бить от 3 до 4 ударов в секунду, да еще и опрокинуть на совсем (насмерть в общем). Раз уж мы задели тему опрокидывания, то уместно будет сказать что если вас откинет в текстурку где нельзя встать то вы умрете, если вы попадете в текстурку где все таки можно встать вы будете обречены на смерть, если вы были опрокинуты в толпе зомби, у вас есть 99% шанс выжить потому что зомби очень воспитанные бойцы и не бьют лежачих. 
Теперь я хочу задеть очень зубоскрежащую и глазовырывательную тему как ПЕРЕДВИЖЕНИЕ, не удивляйтесь, лучше сыграйте и поймете уже на первой минуте игры. Передвижение в игре выглядит так будто я передвигаюсь по льду, легче будет сказать что я играю в Thief 3 Deadly Shadows где ходьба примерно такая же, ну или давайте пример посвежее - Only Up. Машины - очень удобный вид передвижения, но очень криво реализованный, в этом приспособлении шайтана нельзя нормально повернуть или развернуться, а сдавать назад без видения того, что там находится не очень... Также сенса в игре не позволяет нормально осмотреться находясь в транспорте ну и не только в нем. И КТО ПРИДУМАЛ ЧТО В ИГРЕ ВСЕ МАШИНЫ ПРАВОРУЛЬКИ?!?!?! Это очень неудобно, особенно когда ты хочешь зайти в транспорт с другой стороны ПРОСТО ЗАЙДИ И ПЕРЕСЯДЬ НА ВОДИТЕЛЬСКОЕ, тупая условность...
Опасности игры. В игре очень много опасных моментов, от которых игрок будет чувствовать себя напряженно. Перечисляю: Бешеные зомби, которые кричат и быстро бегут за вами - их удары могут оглушить или нанести большой урон. Громилы - любым своим ударом наносят колоссальный урон и опрокидывают. Таран в смирительной рубашке - 50 на 50 что вы его задоджите, потому что ходьба в игре, опять же, ужасная, ну а если удалось уклониться, то не забывайте что у него есть ноги и голова - колоссальный урон+опрокидывание или моментальная смерть. Камикадзе - говорит матом и взрывается, в чем опасность?? не открывайте дверь за которой слышите маты, иначе взрыв и смерть. И наконец зомби с заостренным оружием - самые опасные ребятки, эти особи умеют кидать оружие в вас и это смертельно опасно (ваншот ван килл ноу лак джаст скилл)
Реализм??? Я не знаю зачем разрабы сделали так - персонаж очень аккуратно открывает двери и собирает предметы, но это не похоже на то, что он старается каким либо образом выжить, а как будто находится в детской песочнице.
Стрельба - с ней все замечательно, но ей мешает, передвижение и сенса игры (она слишком плавная и целиться от этого не удобно)
Регулярные задания - это что-то с чем-то) лишнее...
В этой игре минусы преобладают над плюсами, но их на самом деле не так много. В основном игра затягивает, но бесит всем что я перечислил выше. Рекомендую к прохождению, но ожидать чего то грандиозного не стоит. 
Когда покупал, меня никто не предупредил что в игре много недочетов. Так что прежде чем покупать подумайте о жизни.
