Compared to its spiritual successor, Dying Light, the first Dead Island game is relatively tedious but nevertheless an essential foundation for what will become excellent zombie game. The definitive edition is a remaster or a “facelift”, if you will, that make Dead Island and its sequel Dead Island: Riptide more in line with Dying Light. In terms of graphic, it got a decent upgrade thanks to new Chrome Engine which was used in previously in Dying Light. And the comparison ends there.

Dead Island is not the same as the later franchise. It focused more on melee combats and exotic but isolated locales than with parkour or a true open world experience. The story is serviceable and player can choose who to play as, each with their own specialty and weakness. Melee combat is the main draw of this game. You can use variety of blunt or sharp objects, with better weapons and guns appeared later in the game. You can upgrade or modify weapons to be more effective. You mostly fight zombies and sometimes human enemies throughout the game. But, the enemy AIs wasn’t very good to begin with.

The game starts slow. It gradually opened up as you progress. The world is mostly divided up into sections rather than a seamless open world. The highlight for me is the city section with its long winding roads, shortcuts, and bunch of materials and weapons to collect. There’s a simple leveling system and skill tree for players who wants to prioritize towards a certain build or gameplay style.

There are plenty of missions and side objectives to complete or places to discover. Each mission’s structure is relatively simple and can be completed quickly. For some it can become tedious and doesn’t offer a lot of variations.
At the end of day, Dead Island shows that there’s a potential for this kind of games.

[h1] Review[/h1] 
I played this game back then at release and enjoyed myself a lot and recently got it as part of the franchise pack with Riptide as I never got to play that one. The “definitive” edition is not what it advertises, as the main base game never really had huge content expansions. The only thing of interest is the arena and Ryder class/campaign DLC, which are in itself not that interesting which means its more of a marketing trick.

[u]Gameplay[/u]
Dead Island basically takes the Borderlands gameplay and completely alters it on a zombie focus. You have 4 main classes, each focusing on a specific combat aspect, blunt, sharp, throwing weapons and guns. The latter being rater a niche thing in this game, most weapons you find are useless and those that are useful tend to be used rarely due to the rarity of ammo aside from lategame content.

Weapons have durability and have to be repaired to be used again after a certain amount of time. There are various weapon modifications available, where weapons look completely different and have the chance to add new status effects like electricity. The combat itself is really simple and fun but a bit lackluster as you cannot really block or dodge. Aside from kicking or throwing there isn't much you can do to avoid damage. But the combat that is there is unique enough, atleast for the time it released, to be fine with some shortcomings. There is also a variety of zombie types that slowly get introduced to spice things up.

The classes all have their own rage mode that fills up via kills. This is mostly the biggest difference between those classes, the only other one will be if you either focus on blunt or sharp weapons, the latter being a more common skill shared across the characters. Enemies level with you, so it doesn’t matter if your friend is the first level and you're max level, the main difference is some minor side skills like being able to stomp enemies when downed. I don’t really like it that much as this makes levelling absolutely superficial. Starting area zombies will require more or less hits even with max level. The biggest difference is the gear, having a really good weapon for your current level will make the biggest difference.

Additionally the correct build for a specific time is also detrimental. This can make certain player levels harder if they focused on non damage upgrades first, or have no damage upgrade available later. This is not as bad as it sounds, as the game is not really that hard, you respawn immediately anyway and just lose money.

Quests itself are also not as interesting, some have unique tasks, but mostly its just grabbing an item and bringing it to someone. Serviceable.
On a side not the game also can be a bit buggy, nothing gamebreaking but noticed glitches here and there.

[u]Story[/u]
The main story of the game is not really interesting side quests even more so,  although the zombie infested island setting is pretty creative. Most of it is there just to give you a goal so you don’t get bored, a reason to continue to the next area and do activities there.

[u]Sound[/u]
Although the main theme is very good, there isnt that much in this game in therms of music. Most of the sound design is very atmospheric, especially the distant zombie screams, wind howling and so on. Combat sounds are also really neat and add a lot to this game.

[u]Graphics[/u]
Especially for its year of release the graphics are amazing. Not only can you cut off enemies limbs, but also break them or make them bleed. Generally the main focus was on the zombies and their movement and reaction to combat. The island itself has also a variety of cool locations and nice effects to them, although it is personally too hard for me on the motion blur and bloom. Animations and models of other side characters can be really awkward and unrealistic though.

[u]Conclusion/TL;DR[/u]
 Now if you look for a coop game with some unique melee combat this one is pretty good. But it has its shortcomings, with some combat design issues and I personally don’t like autolevelling enemies in general which cause non-damage skills to make the game much harder. The island design is really great and a lot of the games systems are really well made for such a unique game. Classes arent that much different aside their rage mode and some passives. In general its a fun game, with a few bugs here and there that dont break the game.

I am a 40 year old father, probably one of the oldest people who plays this game. I am alone with my son, who is now 13 years old. And recently he downloaded TikTok where he played more than 20 hours. It was terrible for me because it's hard enough to spend time with him, since he's always with his friends or watching videos on TikTok. So I decided to create a Steam account and buy this game thinking that I might be able to play it with it. I launched the game, I finished the tutorial but I was stuck on what I should do. I asked my son if he could help me and he created a game for me to join. It was amazing, it was the best time I've had with my son since my wife died. This game helped me get closer to my son and now we spend time together outside the house. This game reminded me that after all I can have fun, and especially my son and I are creating great memories!

This game is terrible. If you're not like me and you don't have a strong sense of nostalgia tied to this game (it was the first game I ever bought with my own money), you have no reason to put yourself through it. It's not worth explaining, but for shits and giggles I might as well.

1.) The story and the characters are just awful. Since I've already played it a long time ago this might just be a "me" issue, but very rarely do I find myself skipping everything just for the sake of getting to the end of the game. Midway through chapter 2 I couldn't handle any more of the same song and dance of fetch quests with minimal backstory, so I skipped every bit of dialogue I could.

2.) The progression is a joke. If you want to have a modicum of fun playing this, just play Logan. I played Sam B and I never once felt powerful (although I hear Sam B is the only one that doesn't get one shot by zombies wielding knives. Sound fun to you?). I finished the game at level 35 out of 50, and most of the skills are completely worthless. It's not like Dying Light where you get to level 2 and you unlock a lethal drop kick. You'll get a level and you can now unlock the first tier of a perk granting you +5% blunt weapon damage. It's boring and levels feel meaningless. You'll unlock the headstomp and that'll be your bread and butter for a while and will be the most powerful you feel throughout the entire game.

3.) The guns. I mean, what in the actual fuck? First off, the game has autoaim for M&K. Or atleast some kind of autoaim. It tries to faintly guide my aim, which is a big no no for any PC game. If you try to hip fire, your character will resemble the wacky inflatable arm tube man. I'm talking gyro-copter levels of camera spin. Akin to spin-bots in CS. I suspect this has something to do with my FOV mod I made sure to install to go from 60 to 90 FOV. So yeah it's probably my fault, but I ask you this Mr./Mrs. PC gamer: do you want to play on console FOV? On top of this, they have this weird hit registration to where your first shot will ALWAYS be a blank. It won't hit anything, not zombies, humans, or propane tanks. If you go like 3 seconds without landing a follow up shot after any successful hit, your next shot will always miss. Expect a 5th of your total ammo used in the entire run to be blanks and another 5th of your shots to be straight up misses due to weird auto-aim and other things.

4.) The sound. This one is the most confusing. I turned my volume down to 5% so I could watch Netflix or Youtube while I grind the achievements because, as I said before, this game ain't worth paying attention to. Anyways, there's a loud bang that plays for no good reason and it isn't affected by your audio settings. And by loud I mean LOUD! At first I thought it was to denote a critical hit, but it plays randomly for no reason. It even played when I opened a door for god's sake. It sounds minor but it will grate your ears after a short while. I recommend just muting the volume altogether, but c'mon, what game worth your time gets better when you mute the volume completely? Absolutely none. 

It wouldn't be a proper review if I didn't try to shine some light on the positives. The first chapter set piece is awesome. They really should have based the game around the resort rather than limiting it to the first chapter because once you complete Act I the game plateaus. Also, the basic concept of killing zombies however you please is tried and true, although Dying Light does this concept much better. That's about it for the positives.

TL;DR Dead Island is just not fun. You'll enjoy the first Act, but everything after is such a slog and wouldn't be fun even on a first playthrough. I would strongly recommend you don't waste your time on Dying Light's bum of an older brother.

Dead Island visually still holds up over a decade later; however, the gameplay and story is lacking.

Nearly all of the missions are lifeless fetch quests. The story itself feels very tacked on and cliche. The melee combat against certain specials is infuriating and unfun. The best part of the game is combat against other humans inside buildings, but for whatever reason, these encounters are few and far between. Instead, most of the gameplay is weaving through the same open areas with obnoxious amounts of glitchy zombies to fetch item A and return it to place B.

Near the end of the game, after you finally get decent guns and melees, the speed and fun of the missions greatly increases. This would be good, if not for the fact that the first 75% of the game was a very stale slog. The last 25% is quite good, but after finally becoming fun, it ends.

Quantity over quality
The game "burns out" too quickly. After 16 hours I questioned myself why I'm still playing it.

Pros:
- Tropical island is nice to explore and pleases the eye
- Dynamic action, blood & gore look spectacular and have decent animation.
- Variety of weapons and mods
- Immersion into the atmosphere of the disaster of Zombie Apocalypse (one thing that was completely lost in Killing Floor 2) is present in the game.

Cons:
- There are better games about adventures on tropical island. Such as Xenus 2: White Gold (aka War in Paradise) and Far Cry 3.
- The gameplay becomes boring too soon. Running back and forth through the same locations many times to bring a quest supply item from one hut, then from the one next door etc., and fighting through the same crowds of zombies. After going for the 5th time on the same road, I wished the location was just cleared for good.
- Weapons. While there is a lot of them, they are all similar with randomly generated stats. You come across dozens of cleavers, diving knives, kitchen knives, sticks, sorting the ones that have slightly higher stats. It's annoying and consumes lots of time.
Special rotten tomato for absolutely ridiculous weapon durability. Where have you seen knives, hammers and axes that break so fast.
So, logical continuation of previous issue (and game mechanics) that the fighting balance is broken. There is absolutely no reason to use anything than throwing weapons. Throwing has auto-aim, mostly 1 hit kills a regular zombie and doesn't make the weapons degrade. In the end, you just keep a bunch of blades (they don't bounce) with highest damage to throw them at the enemies. Mods, durability and appearance of the weapon don't matter. Also throwables let you avoid getting hit by the enemies, melee combat might look showy, but enemies tear the hero apart too easily. After killing 334th enemy with auto-aim thrown cleaver it gets boring.
It's better when a game has just a dozen of weapons, each with it's own unique, handmade fixed stats. In this case, obtaining each of them actually makes difference and becomes an event in the game.
- Leveling system. In some games leveling is made to make the protagonist stronger then basic enemies and be able to take on stronger ones. Here you level up and the enemies and items keep leveling up with you. So, the entire leveling system makes no sense.
However skill bonuses are done well. Would rather had only them without the level number
Another game series published by Deep Silver had it done right: Risen. Enemies were always the same level (actually, they didn't have any), some of them were meant to encounter in the beginning of the game while others required a well developed and equipped character to fight them. Xenus 2 also had it right. Each level was giving you literally +1 hit point to basic 100 on Lvl1 (so you have 130 HP on Lvl 30) + some combat skill to choose from that gives a little advantage, similar to skills in Dead Island; and all this in the world that remains the same.
- Open world is good when it's handmade, every enemy and object is thought through and placed right where it fits the best. Here I see one big Random Number Generator.

Sometimes properly directed linear "rails" are better than a poor open world sandbox. I played enough of Left4Dead 2 and Killing Floor 1, and wanted something new. New, but not better. Unfortunately, there is no The Last of Us on PC. I'll try Dying Light, hope it would be more interesting.

Dead Island is a FPS where you get to kill lots of zombies. This in itself could have been great. Where it fails is the lack of focus, it does not know whether it is a comedy or serious, whether it is an action game or a RPG. The problems are manifold, I will begin with the main ones.
The leveling system is very similar to what is found in Borderlands. This means you gain experience by killing zombies and finishing quests. With each level your character (there are several playable characters with different strengths and weaknesses) gains a skill point. The enemies also gain levels making them stronger. The weapons have levels as well. I understand the point behind the system, this forces you to constantly get newer weapons. The problem I have with this is that it totally breaks the immersion. For instance: Let's say you have a Feeble Kitchen Knife level 2. Let's say 30 hours later you have gone up 34 levels and find a Feeble Kitchen Knife level 35. Now, for some reason this newer and shinier Feeble Kitchen Level 35 will kill zombies 20 times better and the old one is now totally useless. The only thing changing is the level of the kitchen knife. Alright, in the real world Japanese and German high carbon steel kitchen knives will be better than Chinese stainless ones with plastic handles. But will they be 20 times more effective at killing zombies? No, they wouldn't. This is an artificial way to force you to get better weapons. I have the same gripe with the enemies. Yes, the game should become gradually more difficult, but another way to do it would be to introduce more enemies, or different enemies or other means. Which the game does, but it still has the same old walkers gaining levels, which means a walker level 20 will be much stronger than a walker level 1 even if it's the same enemy. Why do the zombies become stronger? Since the enemies will scale with your level it gives very little motivation for your character to gain levels (other than to get the skill points). I just find the leveling system very stupid and immersion breaking. In Borderlands it kind of worked perhaps because of its comic book aesthetics or its sci-fi setting. Here, it makes zero sense. I mean RPG games in general have a progressive system for weapons. Knife, short sword, longsword, twohanded sword. Or something like that. It makes sense, it gives a sense of progress. Kitchen knife level 1 to Kitchen knife level 20 does not. To be fair, there are other weapons as well, I am just saying the level system feels like something that is tacked on.
The next problem I have with the game is the constant re-spawning of items and enemies. Even if it's within a constricted location your enemies will reappear quite soon. Again, it breaks the immersion. Places you have looted will be filled with loot again. How? Why? Don't ask, don't know. You are never awarded for cleaning out spaces of enemies unless it's a part of quest. In real life it would make sense to kill the enemies so you know you have an escape route if things turn south. Here it's pointless, the enemies will be there anyway. And it is not because they move from one location to another, they magically reappear. Which brings my to my next problem.
Quests will make certain enemy types appear at just the wrong moment even if you made sure everyone was dead and there were no enemies in sight. Again, breaks the immersion. Game mechanics.
Then we have the headstomp. If you fell a zombie (or a human) you can instantly kill him by stomping the head. This is way more effective than any melee weapon or gun. Even if the enemy has metal helmet on. Makes zero sense. This is actually the most effective way to kill zombies. Get them on the ground and step on their head.
Repairing the weapons. I don't mind melee weapons breaking down. I mean tools with wooden handles or weapons made of wood will break down. Knives will get dull or even blades could break. However, the repairing system in this game is really silly due to several things. You can repair and upgrade weapons at workbenches. Knives, machetes I get. You can sharpen the blades. However, how do you fix a tool with a wooden handle for instance? In real life you would have to replace the handle. In this game, you just pay some money. To whom? No idea, but it costs money and not parts to repair weapons. And why do tools like crowbars or hammers with metal handles break? I mean big mean wrenches are practically indestructible... They would not break after smashing in a couple of zombie heads. Again, the whole system is so far from reality it makes zero sense.
The crafted weapon is the next point. Could have been great. There are way to many silly weapons you can craft in this game. And many of them would make good weapons worse. Like the Ripper mod. Would not work at all. It would make sense to fasten the circular blade instead of having it rotating with the help of a small battery. Or make it like and angle grinder. Some of these weapons would more likely make the zombies die of laughter than damage. Or the Barbed Wire mod. I really wanted to make a Lucille for my character. The barbed wire in the game around the bat is totally loose. It has to be wrapped around the bat supertight so it does not move a quarter of inch. The spiked bat, such as in the game, not good. Those spiked would come loose in a few hits.
Guns. Gunplay feels totally wrong. The weapons sway way too much and are way to slow to aim with. Unless you play with Purna. Basically the gunplay is terrible for anyone else. I have very limited experience with guns in real life. I've shot with shotguns and rifles a few times, I am not an expert but in real life it is way simpler to use firearms. In this game, it's very very clumsy. And very ineffective. You can shoot a high level shotgun aiming for the head but it still requires like 5 shots to bring down a zombie. Like what the what? A headshot against a zombie head is always instakill provided you get a good hit. Should be so with pistols and rifles as well, but not in this game. Terrible gunplay with other words. Throwing knives or other weapons is way more effective. I don't think the developers have ever used guns in their lives.
Killing zombies does not require you to damage the head. Like, this is rule number 1, 2 and 3. Always go for the head. Hitting the head will kill faster though, but I wish it would be the only way to kill a zombie.
Driving totally sucks. I don't mind the steering wheel being on the "wrong" side (the game is set in Banoi) but I do mind total lack of physics. Feels nothing like driving a car. I don't think the developers have ever driven a car in their entire life either.
Talking about physics, minor items like inflated balls or small bags can stop not only you in your track but cars as well.
Bandit AI is as stupid as zombie AI (the zombies are excused, bandits not so much).
Some enemies are just annoying and do not fit in (like the ram).
Plot, very bad, I have seen B-movies with much better plots. This is more like a Z movie plot (pun intended).
I think I have covered most of the issues I have with the game.
The good things. Killing zombies with melee weapons is fun. And the damage system isn't half bad. The graphics are totally okay. The maps are okay. Overall, I think this game is very overrated.

Basically, I think it would have been much better without any character or enemy or weapon levels. A set amount of enemies instead of re-spawning. Only hits to the head should kill. A lack of crosshair would make the game better as well. A better system for crafting and repairing. More serious (like S.T.A.L.K.E.R. or Metro). Better physics. Gunplay should have been improved. More open world than now (it is quite linear in reality). So in short, if this would not have been a console port it could have been great. I just feel that there are way too many distracting issues that break the immersion.

The best way to describe Dead Island is that it is an honest grind. It is rewarding to play, but more than that, it has gameplay that you can respect. And because its gameplay, simple as it is as a first-person keep-away simulator that consist of the the same gameplay loop from start to end, is so pure and distilled, it comes off as gameplay without conceit, one that compels you to continue squash zombie brains for hours on end.

That doesn't mean this game is not without its problems. Dead Island is overstuffed with repeat content that has you visiting the same locations over and over; exploration is not encouraged, a strange characteristic for an open world game; the story is trite and the added DLC only serves to double down on this distinction; and it shows itself to be insensitive in its portrayal of minority and aboriginal characters. Worse of all, the chapters are arranged from best to worse, leaving the player's expectation with nowhere to go but down after leading off with the resort, easily the best part of the game.

And yet, it does have its charm. Having to deal with the enormous success of its memorable teaser trailer, Dead Island shows itself to be an enduring gem that can easily stand on its own merits. Perhaps the nicest thing to say about Dead Island is that its graphics are too good. (Yes, really. A game about bashing in skulls standing three feet away from you doesn't need draw distances that stretch a mile away.) All the same, the craft and care put into Dead Island makes for an immersive game that gives players exactly what they want: an fulfilling reward-to-time ratio that translates well into a cozy, comforting, chicken noodle-type of game to play.

Dead Island - Definitive Edition is done and dusted. I’d started this game a couple times over the years, finally decided to actually play it through once. I started with Ryder’s campaign, but didn’t particularly enjoy it and stopped at the point where he first enters the sewers.

I then started the main campaign as Purna. It’s actually a pretty vast and detailed game world with extensive maps, more side quests than you can shake a stick at, a beefy primary campaign, decent cinematics, solid gameplay, fairly good voice acting although also fairly cringe dialogue lol. There is also a very real sense of tension and urgency in this game despite there never really being timers attached to any actions or quests.

I didn’t particularly enjoy melee, but throwing melee weapons OTOH…I pretty much lived by this technique lol. I also made liberal use of firearms since I was playing as Purna. Aiming is a little wonky, but you get used to it. Also, running over zombies in a vehicle never gets old.

One weird detail is that no matter if you’re playing solo or co-op up to the full group, the cutscenes and all relevant dialogue presumes that you are playing with all four main characters active. That can be weird at times since any unused characters do not accompany you in game. Also, you will likely be OP by the time you fight R...I mean, by the time you get to the final boss fight. Protip: after the first wave of zombies, run to the back. It's easy to get bogged down in endless waves of zombies and not notice the next stage of the boss fight.

Anyway, as much as my memories of the original were mixed with this game, the Definitive Edition was actually a lot of fun and has the potential to be quite the time sink if you’re diligent in completing all side quests and especially if you are a cheevo completionist. As it stands, being fairly diligent and playing through once was good for a solid 32 hours (I've played this on both Steam and the PS5, for reference).

Anyway, holds up perfectly well and is worth at least one playthrough. Definitely one of the better zombie games out there.

[h1]Dead Island: A Classic Zombie Adventure[/h1]

Dead Island is an open-world zombie survival looter shooter that made its debut in 2011 on the PS3/Xbox 360. Set on the fictional island of Banoi, just off the shores of Australia, this once beautiful beach resort has turned into a blood-soaked battleground against hordes of hungry infected.

[b]Personal Connection and Nostalgia[/b]

When Dead Island was released, it felt like a dream come true for many of us. It was a game that shook the world and captured the imaginations of countless players—including mine. Prior to its release, we had other great zombie games like Resident Evil, Dead Rising, and COD Zombies. However, Dead Island brought something new to the table—the atmosphere, gameplay, characters, and story were a breath of fresh air. I've had the pleasure of experiencing this game on the PS3, Xbox 360, and PC, and it has never disappointed.

[b]Modern Era and Gameplay[/b]

In comparison to its successor, Dying Light (from the same developers), Dead Island feels a bit clunky and weighty. You're not a superhuman in this game—you're just an ordinary person who happened to be in the wrong place at the wrong time. But that's precisely what adds to the charm. While it may not match up to modern Resident Evil or Dying Light 2 in terms of mechanics, it excels in other areas. The game's beautiful landscape, humorous and sometimes silly characters, gripping story, and immersive sounds create an atmosphere of death and survival that captivates players.

[b]Final Thoughts[/b]

Please note that my review is based entirely on my opinion, and I respect that yours may differ. However, if someone claims this game is bad, they're simply mistaken. It's scientifically proven to be one of the best zombie games ever made in history—check the books.

The Dead Island Definitive Collection is definitely worth buying. It includes everything the original games offered but with improved graphics and other enhancements. While I'm a thrifty shopper who advocates waiting for sales (especially in Australia, where game prices are often high), I would willingly pay the full price for this gem. With hundreds of hours of gameplay and the ability to enjoy it with up to four players in co-op, Dead Island is a fantastic experience. Even if you don't have friends to play with, there are still public lobbies where you can join other players. While there may be a few bad eggs who kick you out, you might also stumble upon lasting friendships, just like I did.

So, take a break, relax on the beaches of Banoi, and enjoy your drink. But always keep an eye on what lurks in the jungles. Dead Island is waiting to provide you with an unforgettable zombie adventure.

Fetch quests. That's what the whole game is, it's repetitive nonsense. Aside from the lack of gameplay variety, you're forced to endure the same awful story with all 4 characters if you want to get all achievements. I can't comprehend what kind of sadistic prick came up with these piss-take achievements. It's not enough to level up one character, to be able to withstand a dozen of waves in arena mode, you have to do it with all of them! The only good gameplay element is the gunplay which can't be relished until you're deep into the story and selected the right character to actually make the firearms useful. The weapon system in this game is just designed to be as annoying as possible. Just when you get enough money together to upgrade your weapon, it becomes useless one quest later. While the player received plenty of level-ups in a short time span, the weapon does not. You have to throw away weapons that were previously overpowered because they turned to utter shit. How about giving the player an option to adjust the level of the weapon to the character by spending some money? No, that would take more than two brain cells to figure out. It's because of this very reason that even late-game weapons become less effective permanently when you start a new game+

The story and characters can go straight into the bin. There isn't much of a story to speak of, you just jump from one NPC to another, deceiving you into believing that there is some kind of narration unfolding. The devs clearly had no plan whatsoever which becomes obvious given the minimum amount of voice acting from the main characters. The only redeeming aspect of the story was the expansion in which you get to play as the supposed antagonist of the game, allowing you to view the blank canvas that is this game's story from a different perspective. But even all that aside, this game has some of the most annoying enemy types, worst environmental designs, awful AI, and frequent bugs I have seen in a while. You will constantly run out of stamina, meaning that you get shoved to the ground everytime you find yourself in a fight. You can't run or hide due to the open world's terrible design and invisible walls. You often find yourself blocked off by the most infuriating special infected I've ever had to witness in a zombie game. You sometimes even die randomly when the game decides that you've squeezed yourself into a place that you shouldn't be in. 

And the arena. My god, what were these devs thinking adding that? Scratch that, what were they thinking adding achievements for this shit? It obviously wasn't tested properly. Enemies get stuck in the level geometry or die to some random bullshit in the distance. The map that is supposed to be the 'easiest' is a major pisstake while the 'harder' ones are significantly easier. On one particular map I just randomly died because I got stuck apparently, in a late wave mind you. Nobody would even bother with this mode if it wasn't for these mindless achievements. I even had the displeasure of grinding this game mode for a completely unrelated achievement which is otherwise pure rng. Speaking of grind, it sums up the game perfectly. You're just grinding to become more resilient toward enemies but that is always short-lived. The melee combat quickly starts to grind my gears after a while. Especially the feature that allows you to throw your weapons is a total fucking mess. You have to manually pick up your weapon if you manage to find it that is. You can actually lose your costly weapon if you're not careful enough. I just can't stand these awful design choices. And you know what the worst part is? I bought the Dead Island bundle. Meaning that I have to play the sequel of this pile of shit too. My torment will never come to an end.

𝑫𝒆𝒂𝒅 𝑰𝒔𝒍𝒂𝒏𝒅 is a mostly mediocre game made fun by co-op.

I played this game back in the PS3 days and decided to give it another go for nostalgic reasons, and while I still had fun and enjoyed it a lot, this gaming has some glaring issues.

Firstly, the good stuff:

I enjoy the gameplay a lot. I love jump kicking zombies, I love crafting mods and I enjoy looting unique or exceptional items. I think the concept of having a zombie outbreak in a tropical island is fantastic and it definitely stands out. I am also a big fan of co-op, and this game encourages it immensely — 𝑫𝒆𝒂𝒅 𝑰𝒔𝒍𝒂𝒏𝒅 is a lot more fun when played with friends. This remaster looks beautiful and definitely does the game justice.

The combat can be frustrating at times but it also feels rewarding — using a machete to cut the zombies' heads off, cutting off a thug's limbs, or setting a horde of zombies on fire with a Molotov does something to me. My co-op partner called me a sadist!
The DLC arenas are also very fun and enjoyable and I am glad they are included in this version.

Finally, even 11 years later, that intro is still sick.

Now, for the bad stuff:

If you are looking for a good story, look elsewhere. This game's plot is atrocious and so is most of the voice acting. Even the cutscenes are badly put together and the facial animations leave a lot to desire.

The soundtrack is a bit of a let down as well. Besides the trailer theme, Sam B's 𝑾𝒉𝒐 𝑫𝒐 𝒀𝒐𝒖 𝑽𝒐𝒐𝒅𝒐𝒐 and a very small percentage of the in-game tracks, most of it is very generic.

In terms of world-building there is not much either. The collectibles do not enhance the lore at all nor are they fun or interesting to read. All side quests follow a recurring pattern of fetching items, saving people, and escorting survivors.
There are also quite a few side quests called "continuous events" which award you XP for delivering certain items to the quest giver over and over — I did not see the point of this at all and found 99% of them to be useless.
I completed all the side quests, but by the end of it I could not stomach it any longer, and I started skipping most of the dialogue, which was always the same.

𝑫𝒆𝒂𝒅 𝑰𝒔𝒍𝒂𝒏𝒅 is also infested with bugs, not just zombies. All this remaster did was enhance the graphics (textures, lighting) but they did not bother to fix actual gameplay issues, such as:

• Suddenly dying for no reason (sometimes because of being stuck between objects)
• Losing items in your inventory
• Bugged achievements
• Clunky car controls on keyboard (many times the car will not turn and you crash)
• Funky textures in some rocks
• Clipping into solid objects
• NPC's blocking the way
• Waypoint not showing the path on the mini-map (not sure if this one is a bug but I would have to reposition it)
• NPC's you have to escort suddenly going back the way they came from while you wait for them to return
• Zombies grabbing you while they are on the ground
• Aim assist cannot be turned off, which makes aiming with the mouse considerably annoying
• NPC's and zombies floating mid-air, sometimes getting stuck
• Sound bugs

A lot more stuff like this happened during my playthrough but I cannot recall it now.

Another negative point is that the characters do not interact with eachother as in, for example, 𝑩𝒐𝒓𝒅𝒆𝒓𝒍𝒂𝒏𝒅𝒔. There is no gameplay dialogue between them, and they barely speak to eachother during cutscenes. Their voice lines are also not synced when playing online, so you rarely hear them talk, and when you do, you and whoever is playing them do not even hear the same voice line.

In conclusion, I think 𝑫𝒆𝒂𝒅 𝑰𝒔𝒍𝒂𝒏𝒅 is a fun game with a few shortcomings. I have a nostalgic bond with this game and I will always cherish it for the fun times it gave me, and I do like the combat, so I can never not recommend it. However, I do strongly suggest that you play it with friends, as it makes it a lot more fun and less of a chore.

If you liked original Dead Island, then you should like this one for sure.

Graphics is improved.
Still, colors are bad (too gray) and it's better to disable chromatic aberration.

Speaking of game itself, rather than DE.

Characters.

4 character to choose.
1 DLC character for DLC short campaign.

Each character has his / her own class.

Purna is specializing in guns.
In mid-late game, when guns are everywhere, she will be very useful.

Sam B is blunt weapon guy.
Good anti-zombie horde character.
I think he's the best choice if you play alone.

Xian Mei is a sharp weapon chick.
No guns skills, which all other characters have.
Worst choice for single player.
Too bad I picked her...

Logan is throwing weapon expert.
Balanced well, according to skill tree stats.

Zombies.

Different types of them, from slow classic zombie to fast Butcher, who use his own bones as weapon.
You can cut hands, legs and head.

Locations.

Sunny resort, city, sewers, jungle, prison.

Co-op up to 4 characters.

Custom craftable weapons.


Now the bad side.

Game is mostly close-combat oriented.

Weapons break too often.
You can't main one weapon, unless you plan to repair it regularly, but it can cost a lot.

Combat is not very good.
Timing is important here for special attacks or at least it was, when I played as Xian.

MUY BUENO...

(NO SPOILERS) Where do I even begin with this game? I bought this game because I played it for a short period on the Xbox 360 and thought it was fun with how long I played at the time and with the fanfare it got afterwards (mind you, I only got through the first hour back then). With this being a remaster, the reviews on it being positive, and it was on sale at the time, I thought to finally try my hand at the game and play it all the way through this time. 

The beginning of the game was just as I remembered and still enjoyed it all the way through Act I, once Act II began though, my desire to play the game decreased as the issues with the game and the story for me became apparent and didn't cease until I finished the game, or because possibly, even worse. Firstly, the story is very boring and has absolutely nothing going for it in the way of learning about the characters, creating emotional bonds with any of them, or really anything that a story should endow upon the player. The side missions are completely and utterly useless as they do nothing with the story and are usually just fetch quests or following companions to certain points on the map. 

Speaking of those following missions, this is a game that will have the player walk slower than the NPC, but run faster than the NPC moves, which is frustrating with how often you are doomed to these mission types.Now with missions and the story over, lets talk about the actual gameplay. For a game where you hack and slash as well as shoot zombies and human enemies, they did a poor job of ensuring that it feels responsive, fun, or even unremarkable. Melee weapons have issues with not swinging at certain times, usually when you need it most. It also has terrible hit detection and you can easily miss your target when in tight spaces even if you are aiming directly at your target. When it comes to the gunplay, I would recommend sticking to using guns only when you have human enemies (which all also have guns) as the ammo is hard to come by and the zombies are complete bullet sponges. That's not even the bad part about the gunplay, the worst part is that the aim assist (which you cant turn off) is atrocious, it will regularly take you off target when you are perfectly lined up with a headshot, which is especially important as most of the human AI will gladly move back and forth between firing and their cover so aiming is a massive chore. 

The other problem with melee and the gameplay as a whole is that there is never enough stamina to deal with large groups or "hordes" of enemies even if you completely upgrade your stamina through the perk system. With the gameplay issues, the entire gameplay loop is boring and monotonous with no real feeling of progression through the game. In my eyes, this game is almost unplayable without playing co-op as the solo experience is awful. Towards the very, very end of the game, the balancing becomes way more difficult at the most unexpected of times and doesn't slow down at all. I coasted through most of the game without dying a single time, but towards the end, even with upwards of 18-19 medkits, I was dying about every 3-5 minutes. Sometimes, even using the death respawn system to skip some of the most difficult sections. 

Another issue I have is that the game is still incredibly buggy even with a remaster, most noticeable is that when you carry a large item, it will get very blurry and an issue where you can get pushed and stuck in place, leaving yourself vulnerable to the overwhelming horde that probably awaits you. The only good things that the game does is that it is a beautiful game, the intro song is always a great thing to hear (it's better than the game itself), and that it. is. short.

The combat is simple at first but as you level up the skill trees you get many more options and a good variety of ways to kill zombies. The weapon modding is possibly the best part about this game. Great game, still holds up in 2023.  This runs pretty well on my Steam Deck with occasional slowdowns but not enough to ruin the experience.  Just be mindful of the lackluster saving system.  The game uses checkpoints instead of manual saves which can be frustrating if you die because you tend to lose the weapons you had when you last saved.  My character throws their weapon to kill and for whatever reason, if I die without the weapon in my possession, I spawn from the last checkpoint without the weapon! So frustrating!

Nevertheless, I still highly recommend this game, especially if you like zombie games and have a Steam Deck.

What I like about this game is their weapon creation. So many blueprints to make such cool weapons. 

But some melee weapons did not affect much on zombies, for instance, frying pan which is quite useless. I enjoyed using frying pan in Left 4 Dead 2 which is so satisfying to slap zombies. Also, big weapons such as hammers and axes will lose stamina easily which make the character barely move hence, zombies take the opportunity to attack and do some damage. What I hate the most about this game is I lost weapons every time I throw them on special infected and suddenly poof, they're gone. Not to mention weapons are easily unequipped and I have to equip them again.
Female character in this game like Purna for example has poor defense. But her skill was great but it has limited time so just once in a while you can use that skill.
There are several continuous side quests, for example, give empty bottles to npc in order to get Molotov but it's limited only for certain bottles. Kinda waste with extra bottles that I can't exchange it unless if you want to sell them but in a cheap price. Those Molotov are quite pricey depends on merchants. Side quests in this game were messy. It's all over the place but you can't do it simultaneously if some occur at the same place. So many repetitions, you have to go back and forth just to do one side quest. What pisses me off more that I accidentally played main quest however I can't change it into side quests back. You have to finish the main quest which is so annoying. There was this part where the npc (who have side quests for me) died and became zombies. I finished those quests but to whom should I turn into? To zombies then? It didn't make any sense. They could have blocked the main quest so the players can finish all these certain side quests then you can go back to the main quest story. Furthermore, there are still bug at Quarantine area where hoards were non stop attacking us and I died over and over that I lost so many money then which makes us so stress out. The NPCs were unintelligent, expecting us to catch up that fast to protect them and at the same we have to protect ourselves and the npcs dies and we have to do the same side quest over and over, it's so exhausting. There was one time the nps, Jin, pushed me out from the boat and I died??? We lost money every time we died and that death was so unnecessary. Overall, the gameplay, the plot, everything were quite messy.

Dead Island Definitive Edition  holds up remarkably well for its age. As a hack and slash game, it offers a lot of fun, fast-paced combat that keeps you engaged.

The tropical island is both unique and immersive, something different from your typical zombie apocolypse setting. The story is engaging enough to keep players interested, but the real draw of the game is the satisfyingly brutal combat. That being said, the game can feel slightly repetitive at times. Though, the game's upgrade system and variety of weapons and skills help to keep things fresh and interesting.

Overall, Dead Island Definitive Edition is a solid choice for anyone looking for a fun, action-packed hack and slash game. Its age doesn't detract from the gameplay, and the updated graphics make it even more visually appealing. While it can be slightly repetitive at times, the game's addictive combat and upgrade system make it well worth playing.

I've been playing this for years now, along with Riptide. The first time i played both of these games were on the Xbox 360, and they remain in my all time favorites for that console. This version plays exactly the same, without the long load times and missing many of the bugs - while retaining the fun ones and janky physics that make this game so enjoyable. It's an absolute blast, the mods get absurd in late game and even basic weapons will keep you occupied for hours on end. If you're looking for a game that's unpretentious fun, you've found it, look no further. There's really not even any minor gripes i can think of right off the top of my head, everything I found annoying from the X360 version has been patched out or eliminated due to hardware advancements.

Playing this in 2023 I can only say it is the absolute worst. I do not understand why people hold this game in high regard. When it came out it was banned in my home country of germany. Since it was finally released last year or so I have been looking forward to playing it with friends. How wrong I was.
The thing that I immediately disliked is the controlls. It feels floaty, unresponsive, like your character is sliding on ice skates. I assume they tried to make it feel like the movement has weight to it but this certainly is no Apex Legends or any other game that does this properly. It just feels horrible. Potentially this is better on a controller but on keyboard and mouse I just hated how it felt. After a while you get somewhat used to it but it is very bad non the less.
The story and overall athmosphere of the game is also horrid. I remember the tonal shifts of this game being a point of critique when it came out, however I never would have imagined how bad it actually is. You do a sidequest for a person that has decided to leave his wife and bunker down with a bunch of prostitutes or porn-actors or whatever while walking past a NPC that cries because they had to kill their entire family. You bring alcohol to some party girl while a child is dying because of a lack of medical supplies. Some games can handle having serious moments along comedic ones. This game cannot. You can never take somber moments serious because the game as a whole is just a circus. The "funny" moments boil down to a "lol so random" kind of humor that seems to be aimed at preteens. I was constantly asking myself "who is this for?", "what even is it trying to be?".
One particular questchain leads you to a garage with a man that has been bitten and his daughter. They try to make this an emotional moment but you don't even know who these people are, nor care about them. The daughter later decides to join you. While trying to help out some obviously evil people she gets taken and it is strongly implied that she is r*aped by them. Like why on earth could anyone think that is an appropriate subject matter in such a goofy game.
It even goes beyond that. At some point a character explain that when the outbreak started "the rich people" (tm) destroyed the bridges so the poor could not steal from them. That is ridiculous in itself. How would "the rich people" (tm) do that exactly and why would they care when litteral man eating zombies are already in their neighborhood trying to kill them. One of the characters then remarks that this is like what happened in New Orleans, seemingly making a referrence to the aftermath of hurricane Cathrina. This is just so utterly tone deaf I still struggle to comprehend how no one on the dev team or the publisher objected to this. It seems to me that they created a goofy as* game and at some point in the development process decided that they want a more serious tone, hence glueing on these completely out of place scenes.
The playable characters themselves also feel a bit problematic by todays sensibilities. You have the black guy that wears a gold chain and talks like some sort of gangster rapper. The asian lady of course being a master swordsman. In short, walking stereotypes in a story that tackles themes of r*pe and social injustice. Great design choice.
When you are not engaged in melee combat there is also gunplay, if you can call it that. Lets just say that any open source, made by one guy shooters you can find plays better than the shooting in this game. The weapons feel like peashooters, the enemys just tank shots without much of a reaction like you play a ps one era game. There are multiple section where you fight humans with guns for a while. They are by far the worst sections in an already bad game.
Another "side activity" is driving vehicles. The driving is among the worst in any game. Give me Mario-Cart for the SNES, heck even furmula one for the Gameboy before I ever want the drive in this game again. It reminds me of the vehicle sections in Tony Hawk. Clearly some lazy, glued on "feature" lacking any physics, any weight, just anything. Luckily, unlike the shooting sections, the game does not force you to engage with it much. You can just walk everywhere for the most part which I would recommend.
Being this old the game also has some of the bad decisions that were common in that time. Missions where you have to protect a braindead NPC that charges into hordes of enemys. Migraine inducing depth of field effects and blurrines. Endless fetch quests and padding. Difficulty spikes out of nowhere. Unfair sections where "suicide bomber" type enemys wait around a corner where you could not possibly anticipate them without having died once already.
The performance of this game is also very bad considering it looks not so good by todays standard. I can play recent games likes Sons of the Forest on high without problems yet this game constantly laggs and performs terribly inconsistent depending on where you are and where you are looking at.
The weapon upgrade system feels grindy and pointless. The durability of the weapons is a joke. You are constantly forced to switch from the weapons you like to those you don't because they degrade afer like 3-5 Minutes of playing. The weapon- and character-upgrades are boring af. "Your blade-weapons degrade 5% slower". Yeah thanks. Really fun stuff, just don't bother with a progression system if that is what is on offer.
The nice looking locations that were in all the trailers unfortunately is only the first section of the game. After that it is of to a generic city and - oh joy - a sewer level. Other locations include a jungle, lets just say crysis this game is not and supposedly a prison which we did not see because we quit the game for good before that. I image it is more uninspired corridors.
The game is sure to milk the locations for all they are worth. It is particular noticable in the jungle which is basically a circular corridor that you walk back and forth on, over and over and over.

Are there any good sides? The melee combat, excluding the floaty controlls is decent. Having a runner charge at you and timing your blade attack to decapitate them is a fun time the first fifty times you do it. It quickly gets old though.
For an older game the multiplayer also works well. Joing in a session with your friends is easy and everyone can see the cut-scenes which is not to be taken for granted I suppose.

In conclusion, this is the worst game I have played so far this year. I am fairly certain I would have also hated it if I played it back then. Bad controlls, boring quests, grind, unfunny, gringe and in some cases outright offensive. The spectacle is engaging for a very limited amount of time. I just can't understand what people see in it. Maybe I am just an outlier given people already sing praise for the second part which seems to be just as bad...

Dead Island is a flawed yet largely enjoyable zombie slasher/survival game. It isn't as fast and flashy as its successor, Dying Light, but it does offer a degree of challenge that is both fair and fun, especially once gun play becomes more frequent/viable. My only large gripe is that the game is too long and becomes a slog in its second half. That won't be a problem if you're itching for 20+ hours of relatively slow-moving zombie survival action, but for me it felt a bit excessive; 12-15 hours would have been plenty, I think. Aside from that (and a silly final boss fight) I feel Dead Island holds up, especially with the upgrades from the Definitive Edition. It will seem clunky to gamers who have already played Dying Light or Dead Island 2, but I believe it's one worth experiencing for fans of the genre.

One annoying thing is that some times when you return to play your in a nest of zombies. Not good. Stock up on Medical Kits. 25 is not a bad number to have on hand. It's sort of a Love/Hate relationship I have with this game.

Now, the game is good, not great, its just a good game, theres fun to be had. 
And for the price on sale its a really solid purchase. 

But what i struggled with when deciding if i would recommend it or not. 
I landed on "NO" purely because i had to mod the game quite a bit before i could actually play it. 

The movement feels wrong otherwise, so sluggish and uncomfortable, has weird delayed acceleration and deceleration, i had to manually adjust settings files to make it feel smooth, and whats even worse is the limited FOV its locked to 62.5. 
And the head bob when moving, and fighting and especially sprinting is so horribly over the top, that it actually gave me motion sickness and a headache after only 10-15 minutes of play, and the restricted FOV makes the motion so much worse. 

This has been an issue since base dead island, and no small portion of the player base also had these motion sickness issues to some degree, and the devs never cared enough to address it, modders needed to make mod tools to disable the head bob, and movement issues, but those tools where never updated to this edition. 

And what makes that worse is, the devs instead of addressing the issue with sliders or toggles for it, they doubled down and actually made the motions more aggressive.

SO to fix the issues i had to do the modding myself, fortunately what to edit is available on the forums if you look hard enough, the end result is not perfect there's still motion glitches and jitters but at least is playable. 

And this is why i find i cannot recommend the game as one should not need to risk having these issues and needing to fix the game themselves in order to play it.

An interesting piece of zombie-game history, and not without its merit for the time, but honestly you should just play the Dying Light series. Techland learned a lot between this game and those games, and by comparison this game is a friggen slog. And that's discounting all the copious jank you are guaranteed to experience like things disappearing in the floor, random full-to-zero deaths because you clip into something, lighting issues, pop-in issues, horrible optimization even on modern-day machines, and more. It's not un-fun, it's just not fun. Only get it if you want to experience it for education's sake.

Welcome to the zombie apocalypse experience of a lifetime – and now more beautiful than ever. Caught in the midst of an epic zombie outbreak on the tropical island of Banoi, your only thought is: Survive!

In anticipation of the sequel coming out, I bought the original. Fun, violent, straightforward. The sub menus took me some time to figure out and realize they were there. Oh, you're tracking all the quests and subquests for me? Thank god. I can't keep them straight. Go tell who that some other guy is alive? Go to where and do what? A dotted line on your compass shows you where to go for many quests. Which is both insulting and extremely helpful because I have zero sense of direction.

As the weapons get better, so does the fun. Chop off a head? Good times.

I prefer to play games solo as opposed to embarrassing myself in front of a group of strangers. So far, solo is fine. But I can see how having three other people on your team would be useful.

The graphics feel a bit dated and sometimes it's hard to tell who is a "sexy lady" and who is a grotesque corpse. But I don't mind that too much.

its always very fun to beat, decapitate, kick around some zombies, especially when you have variety of weapons and styles. gameplay is satisfying.
definitive edition graphical improvement is very noticeable, jungle area looks fantastic.

some cons: has minor bugs, sometimes you might bump into your buddy in co-op and instakill them, you can't look behind you while driving, money is duped when both players take it from the same source, weapons deteriorate way too fast, can't disable autoaim.

Dead Island Definitive Edition is a game that fails to live up to the expectations of its players. Despite its remastered graphics and updated features, the game falls short in terms of gameplay, storyline, and overall entertainment value.

One of the major drawbacks is its clunky and unresponsive controls. The combat mechanics are frustrating and lack precision, making it difficult to engage in battles with any sort of fluidity. This makes the game feel more like a chore than an enjoyable experience.

Additionally, the story is lackluster and uninspired. The characters are forgettable and the plot is predictable, leaving players feeling disinterested and disconnected from the game's world.

Another issue is its repetitive gameplay. The missions are often mundane and follow a similar structure, leaving players feeling bored and unengaged. The lack of variety in the game's objectives makes it feel like a grind rather than an exciting adventure.

Furthermore, the game's technical issues make it frustrating to play. The game suffers from constant glitches and bugs, making it difficult to progress through the story without encountering frustrating obstacles and setback.

Dead Island Definitive Edition is a disappointing game that fails to deliver on its promises. The clunky controls, lackluster story, repetitive gameplay, and technical issues make it a game that is not worth the time or money.

Coming back to this game years later was a strange feeling. On one hand, the setting is a breath of fresh air from more recent games. On the flip side though, the gameplay is stale and needlessly grindy for a perk system that is basic at best. No one character feels truly unique. Just arbitrary stat buffs for weapons against enemies that scale to your level anyways. Making the RPG system added to the game absolutely pointless. Honestly I'd say if you're curious about playing this game, don't, get Dying Light 1 instead. It's made by the same developers, and branches out on every aspect of this game and Riptide, by making the mechanics feel meaningful while adding parkour to the mix.

Overall Dead Island is a good first person zombie survival game. The graphics aren't bad for its age, but the mechanics are a little basic and the story isn't the most immersive. It ticks the box for exploration and slaughtering hordes of undead though. I also highly recommend playing with a controller. Basically everything I would improve in Dead Island was implemented in Techland's successor Dying Light, which makes me really appreciate Dead Island even with its flaws. It will be exciting to see what Dead Island 2 brings later this month.

Are you ready to dive headfirst into a zombie apocalypse and fight for survival? Then Dead Island is the game for you! Just don't expect it to be all sunshine and rainbows - this game is about as cheery as a funeral parlor.

The game's graphics are impressive, with a beautifully rendered tropical island paradise that's been overrun by hordes of undead. It's like Gilligan's Island meets The Walking Dead, but with way more blood and guts.

The gameplay itself is a bit clunky at times, but hey, when you're fighting off a horde of flesh-eating zombies with a paddle, you can't really expect it to be easy. And speaking of weapons, there are plenty of them to choose from. You can use anything from a machete to a propane tank to take down your undead foes. It's like a twisted version of "Chopped," but with zombies instead of food.

The characters in the game are also pretty memorable, if not a bit cliche. You've got your tough guy, your damsel in distress, your scientist, and your wise old man. It's like a zombie-themed Scooby Doo episode, but with less mystery and more brain-munching.

All in all, Dead Island is a fun and intense game that will have you on the edge of your seat (or hiding under it) as you fight your way through a zombie-infested paradise. Just make sure you've got plenty of sunscreen, because it's going to be a long, hot, and bloody ride.

And the best news of all? Dead Island 2 is on the horizon, and it promises to be even more epic and gruesome than the original. I can't wait to see what kind of new weapons and characters they come up with. Will we get to fight off zombie hordes with a flaming pineapple? Only time will tell.

You wake up to the sound of screams. The island is overrun with the undead and you're the only one left alive. You have to find a way to escape before it's too late.

You frantically search for a way to escape the island. The undead are everywhere and you're running out of time. You see a boat in the distance and you start to run towards it. But before you can reach it, you're tackled by a zombie. You fight it off and make a run for the boat. You're about to board when you're tackled again, this time by a group of zombies. You're outnumbered and there's no way you can fight them all off. You're doomed.

It's bad. 

There's lots of systems like levelling, skills, weapon types upgrades and mods, BUT they work agains the player:

Getting a level up is basically getting a downgrade for all owned weapons since zombies scale directly, but weapons need to be gathered, upgraded and modded for their power.
Modifications can grant status effects like burn, poison or shock, YET touching the affected damages you as well so it's also a downgrade at times. Especially since damage has a nock-back and visual effect, sou you can end up much worse than before.
The game simplifies most zombies to either boring or unfair-they are either slow, predictable damage sponges, or an unstoppable force you need explosives for.
Most explosives are lethal, especially to you, the grenades, bombs gas canisters and 'bloaters' easily one-shot both the enemy hordes and the player.
Useless death- due to many dangers, you can die at plenty of opportunities, and yet you respawn almost at the exact same spot, sometimes even with enemies removed.
'Parkour' is a mostly gimmick crouch through small places or jump up to vantage points, if it worked.  Crouch is only used to enter forcefully shrunken places that could have easily been a normal size. There's few obstacles to properly climb, and thenm without ranged weapons like guns or explosives, you can't really do much there either. Not to mention hit-boxes are messed up and and you can get stuck on things you can't see due to hitbox or manage to die by tripping over a pool-chair (well i sure did).
The first region gives guns few guns without purpose, since zombies don't really seem to mind headshots or need more than weapon throwing.
Weapon throwing is upsettingly close to being decent- more damage for temporary loss of weapon, but the auto lock-on is trash and still misses, works only at a set distance and picking up your weapon has lower priority than looting other things, lock you into an animation and very often displaces your hot-bar.
Interaction points are horribly small and the same for every tupe- use placed consumable, interact with special objects, pick up weapon, use gathering spot, stomp execution (skill unlock). It's a mess

Horribly unfinished and unbalanced.

Reloading a checkpoint does not give you your used weapons back - took me eight hours before I realised that one... goodbye, epic hammer!

Dead Island is a FPS zombie game with some RPG elements. You level up your character using a skill tree. You can choose from playing with 4 different characters who have their pros and cons. What make this game stand out from the rest is it's stamina mechanic. Running, attacking and jumping drains your stamina. When your stamina runs out your attacks don't do any damage and you can be pushed to the ground by a single hit. This game has some weird controls that take some time to get used to. The walking just feels odd.


You wake up in a luxury island that has been hit by a zombie outbreak. For some reason you have immunity to the virus. This makes you a key player in helping other survivors how to escape from the island.

This games plot sucks ass. I don't mind the idea of a luxury island as a setting for a zombie game but the execution in this one is quite bland. This game also has a major part of the plot missing if you don't play the DLC where you control the antagonist of the game. No DLC should contain plot information that changes the plot of the main game almost 100%.

"Dead Island: Definitive Edition" is a remastered version of the original "Dead Island" game, developed by Techland and published by Deep Silver. The game was first released in 2016 and features updated graphics, gameplay improvements, and all of the DLC content from the original game.

Story:

The game takes place on the fictional island of Banoi, where a mysterious outbreak has turned the majority of the population into zombies. Players take on the role of one of four survivors, each with their own unique skills and abilities, as they try to find a way to escape the island and uncover the cause of the outbreak.

Gameplay:

The gameplay in "Dead Island: Definitive Edition" is focused on melee combat, with a variety of weapons and upgrades available to players. The game's combat system is satisfying and visceral, with a variety of different zombies to fight and strategies to employ. The game also features a crafting system that allows players to create their own weapons and upgrades using materials found throughout the game world.

Graphics and Sound:

The graphics in "Dead Island: Definitive Edition" are a significant improvement over the original game, with updated textures and lighting effects that make the game world look more detailed and immersive. The game's sound design is also excellent, with a haunting soundtrack and sound effects that add to the game's sense of danger and tension.

Multiplayer:

"Dead Island: Definitive Edition" also features a cooperative multiplayer mode that allows players to team up with friends and tackle the game's challenges together. This mode is well-designed and adds a new layer of depth to the game, as players must work together to survive and complete objectives.

Reception:

"Dead Island: Definitive Edition" has received mixed reviews from both fans and critics. While many praise the game's satisfying combat and engaging multiplayer mode, others criticize the game's repetitive gameplay and lack of depth in its story and characters. Some players have also noted technical issues with the game, such as bugs and crashes, although these appear to be relatively rare.

Conclusion:

Overall, "Dead Island: Definitive Edition" is a solid remastered version of the original game that offers improved graphics, gameplay, and all of the DLC content. Its focus on melee combat and crafting, combined with its engaging multiplayer mode, make for a fun and satisfying experience. While it may not offer the deepest story or characters, it's still a great choice for fans of zombie survival games. If you're looking for a fun and challenging game to play with friends, "Dead Island: Definitive Edition" is definitely worth checking out.

Melee is terrible, no dodge or block mechanics in a melee/FPS hybrid? Awful decisions. Melee weapons also don't really take into account weapon length so for instance a wrench and a bat have the same hit-range despite the bat clearly being several feet longer. Gun-play is equally horrendous, either the Iron-sights on rifles are broken or they aren't allowed to score head-shots. Not to mention most characters aren't even allowed to store anything more then about 5 magazines worth of ammo. Watching the zombie's get "stuck" on simple things like barrels while funny when they are frozen mid-sprint and screaming like lunatics, from a player perspective that is just dumb. Music is non-existent, the fact that it's almost a requirement for me the player to provide my own music is dumb. Like even simple gameboy games had that down but someone didn't tell these dev's that. Dialogue is infrequent at BEST, I jumped one time because my character said something and since he hadn't spoken in the last 20 minutes I honestly forgot I wasn't playing as a mute. A lot of the skills for the characters fill like filler, Like exp gain increase's. On paper that might sound good but in reality once you hit level cap these gain increase's become irreverent meaning you wasted skill points on them. If I had to rate this game out of 10 I'd give it a 3/10. The art is the only thing keeping this game from a 2 honestly.

I played this again since it first came out in anticipation for Dead Island 2.

A great many of the bugs and problems in the original version have been fixed and the definitive edition acts as a complete experience sans some jank here and there.

It can be enjoyed either solo or with up to 3 other players. The game is really fun and provides a surprising amount of environments throughout a 4 act campaign, including a resort, city, jungle and prison.

The story is simplistic and lacklustre and the characters are often obnoxious but the exploration and variety of weapons makes up for it. The game is one of the first to boast a physics system where the dismemberment of zombies react according to the type of weapon you are using. 

Each character has a set of skills you can unlock as you progress through the character levels.

DLC included is the wave based arena mode which proves to be a fun way to farm money and xp as well as Ryder Whites campaign which is fun although at times frustrating.

Overall would recommend giving it a try when its on sale.

If you ever get bored and want to play a game that doesn't require lots of skill or investment. Get this zombie game. With 4 playable characters with different set of skills, 4  acts, and a unique pallet of open - world environment, comes a casual zombie game that is just dumb fun. For the most part this game has everything you would want in a average zombie game. Survivor skill tree, Weapon Combinations, Special Infected and a Decent story. However with that in mind, it comes with a set of issues which I shall mention in the negatives. But in order to have the " best " fun in this game, you must pick the best starter character out of the 4: Sam B (Blunt Expert), Xian Mei (Sharp Expert), Logan Carter (Throwing Expert), and Purna Jackson (Firearms Expert). Which in this case comes down to Sam B because he is " the tank " or Xian Mei because she deals the most " damage ". While on the other hand Logan throws his weapons which isn't great and, you always have to pick up thrown weapons, and the game mostly revolves around combat and as for Purna. You don't really get good firearm blueprints or guns until act III. Which is already 65% into the game. So unless you are playing with friends play as Sam B or Xian Mei.

Here are some reasons to play Dead Island with a bit of humor:

Zombie killing never gets old! And in Dead Island, you get to do it with a wide variety of weapons, from machetes to electric hammers.

Want to combine your love for zombies and beach vacations? Dead Island lets you do just that.

Ever wanted to drive over zombies in a car and then jump out and finish them off with a sledgehammer? Well, now you can!

Dead Island's beautiful open world setting is perfect for exploring and discovering new things. Just watch out for those sneaky zombies lurking around every corner.

The game's RPG elements allow you to level up your skills and create the perfect zombie-killing machine. Who doesn't love a good character progression system?

Dead Island's story may not be its strongest suit, but it still manages to keep you engaged and interested as you try to unravel the mystery behind the zombie outbreak.

In short, if you're looking for a fun, zombie-killing, co-op experience with some RPG elements and a beautiful open world setting, Dead Island is the game for you!

Dead Island: Definitive Edition is an upgraded version of the original Dead Island, featuring improved visuals and all of the available DLC for that game.

Other than the improved graphical fidelity, the Definitive Edition plays identically to the original title, so expect the same blend of visceral zombie massacre, fetch quests, skill tree upgrades, bad voice-acting, and weapon-building that you experienced the first time around, either by yourself or with up to three other people in co-op play.

If you didn't like the original Dead Island or were only mildly impressed with it, the Definitive Edition won't win you over since it's essentially more of the same. The Definitive Edition *can* be safely recommended to hardcore Dead Island fans, and to those who like loot-heavy action RPGs like the Borderlands games.
