The greatest game ever sold. Made.

[b]Graphics and story[/b] 8/10

[i]Dead Island[/i] is a zombie themed action game. The story takes place in Banoi, Papua New Guinea. The four main characters are living a night party near the hotel, the next day they will realize that something strange is happening there. As soon as we leave the hotel, we will notice people have turned into zombies. A mysterious voice will intercede sometimes, it tells us about immunity to the Kuru, a prion that causes the transformation of islanders. That voice promises a vaccine with the blood of the immune survivors. Colonel Ryder White will negotiate with us in an effort to obtain the vaccine and extract us from the island, since he's urgently looking for it for his wife who has been bitten by one of the enemies. One last helicopter is awaiting evacuation orders. All our travel and the fight against the colonel after his betrayal will allow us to escape from the island. 

The game is set on an island based on the culture, flora and fauna of Papua New Guinea. Although the game is divided into four scenarios, each of them is presented as an open world. It is made up of the tourist zone, the city, the jungle and the prison. We can even find interesting facts about the Papuan culture. The settings look impressive, exotic, like a summer day. It offers that feeling of being a tourist in a paradisiacal whereabouts. 

The game's story adds a new element to the zombie theme: the [i]Kuru prion[/i] and cannibalism practiced on the Papuan islands. Although the characters' dialogues don't express or give an opinion of anything relevant, but the missions allow us to understand what the story is about and the historical context of the island. We start from uncertainty and as we progress we learn something from the narrative. We can notice many influences from movies (like those of director George A. Romero or Danny Boyle) and games related to zombies such as special infected and zombie types ([i]Left 4 dead[/i] or [i]Dead rising[/i]) that we will come across on our tour. As the story is simple and linear, it is easy to assimilate and digest all the narrative content.

[b]Playability[/b] 9/10

This is an action game, although it has many other elements that its gameplay provides. Gameplay mechanics take precedence over melee combat. There are some firearms with limited ammo, but the variety is concentrated in those melee weapons. We will find boxes, sellers to buy or get rid of them, as well as those can be enhanced and upgraded, add damage bonuses. We will have a work table where we can repair them and other stuffs such as first-aid kits, some homemade bombs and bait, an item that was added to this version of the game. Our health recovers with chocolates and sodas. It is possible to drive cars to move faster, since running consumes energy. With all this it makes the game quite dynamic, fluid and contiguous, whose actions are not interrupted. 

On the other hand, we can choose one of the four playable characters. Except for the character Ryder White: this is a campaign of the antagonist's own. Each of them has unique abilities. To upgrade the skills, the game relies on the levelling system. We will obtain this by completing missions as well as by eliminating enemies. In addition, each character has a special action enabled, such as a type of [i]fury[/i] that allows us to easily knock down any enemy. In this manner, this game is recommended to play with friends in order to take advantage of the skill tree in a role-playing game. The game is something like RPG, action, melee combat, looting and levelling up.

[b]Music and FX[/b] 8/10

The game's soundtrack was composed by Paweł Błaszczak. To refresh our memory he also performed the music for [i]Dying Light[/i], [i]Call of Juarez: The Cartel[/i] and [i]The Ascent[/i]. The soundtrack shows the important scenarios and circumstances in the game. Although many times we will listen to these musical pieces at certain moments, such as when being chased by zombies, that is, in the drama of the action. Or the music is presented in a timely manner in the essential acts of the plot. Each piece of music is related to some place. This occasions us a remembrance how creepy and scary it is there. That feeling appears of not wanting to return, of wanting to escape from the nightmare. 

The music achieves its intention from the dark ambient and electronic ambient music. Most of the musical pieces are suites with atmospheric content. Sometimes it adds ambient noise and harsh industrial-style tones. At other times it adds electronic music beats just like an OST from an action movie. Certain changes of rhythm allow us to experience action with fast and short cadences as well as terror through ambient music loops with long-lasting sounds. This harmonic opposition adds environmental sounds, thus offering enveloping events.

[b]Duration[/b] 9/10

The game contains 4 acts and in turn they are divided into 18 chapters in total. An act corresponds to a particular scenario. As it is an open world game on each map, we can perform various activities as well to completing the story missions. The game offers a solemn freedom of exploration, as if we were sightseeing on the island. However, the search for resources, items to improve weapons, looting weapons-meeles and currency, all of this will take us more time to accomplish the main tasks. That will make the game enduring. It has a plus: the game has a mini campaign of the antagonist, a game in which he narrates his adventure that complements a before in story. A tale whose character crosses half a city in chaos to reach a radio and contact the survivors. Another extra includes a type of arena or hordes mode with different scenarios and difficulties. Be that as it may, it is quite re-playable if played with friends and by choosing rounds with unalike characters. Although we can rarely find connected games. Online co-op mode is still supported. But we can hinge on discussions on Steam for player search. But my recommendation: exploration in every corner of the island solo or team.

i guess people will be interested in playing this game once again because part 2 is coming out. i enjoyed it a bit. Just expect things from old games like graphics and wonky controls. A lot of looting. The story feels meh. Weak character writing. its just a game to smash zombies and if you are in to that i guess you could enjoy this game. Gameplay is mid, its just that the story is a bit "undercooked" in my opinion. Its like they want characters to feel more important or impacting but they just fail to build up.

A game that was released back in 2011 that still is in many people's minds after so many years, a game that has lead to countless spin offs and a standalone DLC simply because of the amount of people that were captivated by this release. With hopefully follow up games to come to the market one day.

There's even a bit of story here, it's not great and it's not bad. Most of what's in between will probably be forgotten, like it was by me the first time I've played the game. However the ending is quite memorable so there's that. But that's not the strength of this game.

The main reason for this game to stand out even after so many years is the combat system, the co-op system and possibly even the glitches that the game contains. The game doesn't take itself too seriously which leads to a better experience than it would if there was no humour, it's about mindless fun of slaughtering an insane amount of zombies with anything you can find or even your fists and kicks in the face. Join up with up to 3 other players for even more fun on the island of Banoi. 

After so many years and coming back to this game quite recently I could still remember the whole first map really well as well as big chunks of the follow up areas that are unlocked, which definitely shows how and why this game was able to stand the test of time so well. There's just something there that you can't find anywhere else, well, maybe in Dying Light 1 but that's also made by these developers which truly saying something about this approach.

Entertainingly campy, environments are gorgeous and stellar, and the combat is fun. I don't know what people were saying about this being a horrible game, but I think it holds up quite well. I had my fair share of doubts about getting this, but after allotting quite a few hours on this game, I am completely hooked. If you're on the lookout for a fun zombie slasher game, Dead Island provides more than enough satisfaction. A lot of content is jam-packed on here not even including the DLCs, which are all also included, so you're getting your money's worth definitely. Yes, I've seen my fair share of bugs here and there but nothing all that immersion/game-breaking, and yes, the plot is kind of dumb and nonexistent, but all in all, at the end of the day it's just something you plug in to slash and dice zombies in your way.

[h1]Sum-Up[/h1]
[h3]In-depth analysis further down.[/h3]

[table]
[tr]
[th]🟩 [b]Pros[/b][/th]
[th]🟥 [b]Cons[/b][/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]
- Solid variety of available skills, weapons, consumables and modding options that don't get stale.

- Great amount of worthwhile quests that often award unique blueprints, weapons or other advantages.

- Compelling and rewarding exploration: the world is filled with secret chests, hidden quests, Easter eggs and optional locations.

- Despite its relative simplicity combat is engaging, fun and has enough momentum to keep you hooked into the action.
[/td]
[td]
- Glitchy, unreliable collision models can cause sudden deaths, thrown weapons to disappear and other shenanigans.

- The last chapter is a bland, rushed mess that isn’t up to par with previously-seen ones in any aspect. 

- The consequences of side-quests, like how characters end up, are never outlined in the ending; all your efforts will seem vain.

- Firearms are generally underpowered and gimmicky until very late game, and even then some categories are just garbage (e.g. shotguns).
[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

[table]
[tr]
[th]🟨 [b]Bugs & Issues[/b][/th]
[th]🔧 [b]Specs[/b][/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]
- Players cannot trade money with each other. A puzzling decision, since everything else can be exchanged.

- A few achievements are tied to online-only activities (playerbase is pretty much dead), or may even glitch out completely.

- Some dialogues may not play out correctly for one or both players in a session.
[/td]
[td]
- 3900X
- 2080Ti
- 32GB RAM
- SSD
- 1440p
[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

[table]
[tr]
[td][b]Content & Replay Value:[/b][/td]
[td]It took me, alongside another player, around 36 hours to complete a single playthrough, taking time to fully explore all locations and finish every side quest. Despite the presence of NG+ mode and some different abilities between characters, I don’t see a reason to replay once finished.[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td][b]Is it worth buying?[/b][/td]
[td]Yes, especially for co-op. The current price of 20€ is fair for this content amount and quality, so I can recommend to buy even without a discount at this time.[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td][h3]Verdict: Good[/h3]
[url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2548409603]Rating Chart Here[/url][/td]
[td]A more than passable melee-focused zombie FPS, that gives its best when played in co-op. Not a masterpiece by any means, but its B-movie shenanigans, fun combat and plentiful activities carry it through.[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

[quote]Follow our Curator page, [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/41449676/]Summit Reviews[/url], to see more high-quality reviews regularly.[/quote]

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2911965125

[h1]In-Depth[/h1]
[h3]Setting & Writing[/h3]
The tropical paradise of Banoi Island, a world-class tourism destination, suddenly turns into a hellscape due to a zombie outbreak. This rather clichè premise introduces us to one of the four available characters, each with their own background, personality, voice-lines, weapon specialization and abilities. Dead Island takes place not only on sandy beaches, but also in the neighboring cityscapes, sewers, tropical jungles and more locations; there's a good variety of environments. 

The main focus is clearly not a deep story nor intricate lore: typical B-movie humor and tropes are put side-by-side with genuine desperation and saddening moments, especially in side-quests; however none of the writing is high-quality at any point - that’s fine for this type of game, though. Usually side missions have their self-contained story, while lore files are plentiful in the form of collectibles by the dozens, alas rarely exciting.

[h3]Exploration & Secrets[/h3]
On paper an open-world, in reality only half so. While you’re free to explore and loot to your heart’s content without forced guidance most of the time, most areas will be locked out behind main or side quests regardless. It's best to follow the main path to open them, and then start clearing side-content or explore, otherwise frustration sets in from the many quest-related invisible walls and locked gates. A handy global map displays important info and facilitates navigation. 

Fast travel is available from fixed hanging maps, and will be a boon to avoid fighting the ever-respawning zombies and bandits all the time… unless you want to, that is. Exploring the island is rewarding, as there are many collectibles, side-areas, hidden NPCs with quests and rare loot to find. Those with a keen eye for secrets and paths will definitely feel rewarded by the extra time spent. 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2911411281

[h3]Progression & Quests[/h3]
Slashing and shooting your way through zombies and bandits, completing quests, discovering locations and performing specific actions will award XP, leveling your character up from time to time and award one Skill Point to assign in one of the three available paths. You may choose to focus on combat, support, utility, or mix passives as you see fit; there isn’t a huge difference to how a character plays out regardless of the “build” you choose, however, and that’s one of the main reasons replay value is limited - different builds don’t really feel like another gameplay style.

NPCs found at safe locations or randomly throughout the map, will often give chained quests that award XP, money, unique blueprints, weapons or unlock new areas. These tasks include elimination, escort, fetching X items, killing a boss and so forth - your run-of-the-mill RPG quests for short, not terrible but not great either. The rewards are generally good though, so it’s recommended to give them a go.

[h3]Combat System & Weapon Modding[/h3]
Dead Island strongly focuses on melee combat throughout, and guns won’t even be a thing until the second act. Improvised weapons at first, and then proper ones later on, will be your go-to murder instruments against the undead. A stamina system ensures button mashing is heavily punished, while hitting specific spots of an enemy like the head, arms or legs delivers different effects like stumbling, reduced attack effectiveness, or increased damage. Kicks and dodges give some utility in melee to push back the enemy and avoid attacks, however the dodge is unreliable and clunky, you won’t use it much.

All weapons can be modded with blueprints found while looting or obtained for quests. Each of these projects requires materials, also acquired from loot or bought from traders at a high price. Modded weapons not only are more durable, but also inflict passive effects like burning, electrical shock, venom and more on enemies - the better the mod, the higher the status chance. Ranged weapons are overall expensive, have limited ammo and aren’t as effective as their melee counterparts, except when facing other gun-toting enemies like bandits, in that case they’re the best choice.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2911965350

[h3]Additional Modes & Arena[/h3]
An optional difficulty option will have any damage one-shot you, hardcore to say the least and only recommended for masochists. The Arena is a side-area detached from the main map, and allows you to fight endless zombie hordes in four separate locations; it’s great to grind money and high-rarity equipment at all times, but brings nothing new to the already-seen formula, except much greater quantities of zombies than you’ll face in most areas of the normal campaign.

I'm not giving heavy budget games, that are abandoned with a million different bugs a pass anymore, this ones full of them.

- Jumping over something and getting perma stuck.

- Curb stomp uses the same voice even for different characters.

- Cars respawning across the map making you run alllll the way to get another one.

- Explosive zombies killing you, sometimes they don't. 

- Curb stomp stops working in multiplayer if the zombie is moved an inch.

- Driving a car into a new rendered area will prevent you from turning, feels very terrible, always crashing into something unless you stop.

A HUGE lack of QOL

- Weapons cost a shit ton to repair.

- Stuck in a loop getting weapons your character doesn't specialize in.

- Brute and big zombies knocking you down for a long ass time. Also effectively wasting your entire rage build up.

- Guns used on zombies being weaker than on humans, pretty much forcing you to use the expensive melee, bullets are only in those human sections also.

- Leveling slows down to a crawl. 

- There's player collision and the game forces you in tunnels and very tight areas about 70% of the time.

- Story is strange and all over the place.

A ton more issues, these are ones I can list off the top of my head, imagine all the ones I forgot.

I genuinely wanted to give this a good rating because its an old game and I remember enjoying it when I was younger and even more so it's pretty easy to find it on a sale for like 4 bucks but immediately entering act 2 it starts to become way more frustrating than fun with how clunky the game is. There are so many things that should have been patched into the game at some point like additional settings and just very simply quality of life changes that arent there. Being released in 2011 it's clear that this game was specifically made for controllers and consoles because using mouse and keyboard with these menus are generally a pain in the ass. 

The first act of this game is totally fine and easy to vibe with. Run around a resort, look for better weapons, overall just killing things and leveling up and slowly getting your character's specific build off the ground. Going into act 2 a lot of the game's designs that are frustrating to deal with become more and more apparent. Things like zombies literally spawning 5 feet from you the moment your back turns because spawn locations only care whether or not you're looking directly at them and the game no problem just infinitely spawning zombies a few seconds after you kill them in the exact same spot over and over. Zombies that just do not get staggered at all show up more often and I've had times where they rush into me and do that sort of shambling flailing attack and our hitboxes get mashed up and I literally cannot move until they're dead or I get lucky and they eventually get staggered and I can knock them onto the ground. Playing as Logan becomes a huge detriment because his whole gimmick is throwing weapons, which is generally pretty powerful ngl, but then it becomes a huge major pain to put up with because retrieving weapons becomes incredibly difficult in many situations. From an animation of your arm swinging in a cartoonish way to forcefully grab a weapon that cant be skipped to the way this game layers loot as more important than your main weapons forcing you to pick up weaker garbage that is automatically thrown on your equipment bar over the top of your actually useful damaging weapons. 

While solo play can be done this game is definitely better with friends and a variety of characters with their abilities working together. Otherwise it can be an incredibly frustrating game at times when you just get absolutely bodied nonstop by some dumb mechanic like infinitely spawning zombies while doing some of the worst escort missions I've seen in a video game.

In my opinion Definitive Edition is better than the original Dead Island, some bugs were fixed, some werent. Maybe I'm wrong but I wanted to see some QOL improvements: 

- Slightly better physics for npc movement (Enemies are fine)
- Driving a car still a nightmare, TPS view would be good when you enter a vehicle.
- Still can't do any side quest if you are on a main quest...why? Whats the reason behind this?
- If you track a quest while playing coop, the quest marks/directions wont appear on your friends minimap unless they track 
   the same quest, not even if you are the host.

Anyway this is a very good game zombie survival game, I finish the game in coop with my friends once a year.

What it boils down to is "fetch work" and not many people enjoy it hell I don't but it's part of the game in order to progress so as a result of people not liking that sort of thing they label the game as "boring".  If you take the time to fully read the game's description and story line you'll see that it's not boring at all but it is WORK and lots of it but it is worth it if you want to find out what happened to the island you end up on.  

Is the combat perfect? No but I haven't seen a perfect game yet so there's that.  I like this game a lot although I go through my moments of love/hate with it I guess the main thing is you have to take frequent breaks so you don't experience "burn out" and that's people's main issue anymore is finding balance.  

"Boring" lol nah this game is not boring.

Man, I really wanted to like this game. Zombies are a huge weak spot of mine, and that $4 sale was cheap enough for me to just buy it without thinking about it. 

The pros:

1. Open world is a huge W. Especially with vehicles that can just plow through zombies

2. The skill tree, crafting, repairs, and upgrades were all very nice. Optimizing and min/maxing was fun.

3. There were a lot of quests you could do. There was never a time where I ran out of quests to do. Granted, some of them were boring, but I could just not do those and go do a fun one instead. Half the time I'd accidentally complete a boring one anyway.

The cons:

1. There wasn't a feeling of progressing difficulty. The zombies levels kept pace with yours almost completely evenly. I only felt threatened once, and it was because I put myself in bad position (which I ended up easily getting out of anyway). The result is the combat gets stale fairly quickly.

2. The quest descriptions are often vague and unhelpful. The main quest at one point said, "help _ and _." Just the two character's names. It didn't say what to help them with. When I tracked it, I wasn't given a location or a way point. A lot of the quests have similar issues where they just don't tell you where to go, or what exactly to do.

3. The game felt sleazy. It's a beach vacation so, obviously, people will be in swimwear. Not shocking. What caught me off guard is 1/3rd or so of the guys were fully clothed. Meanwhile. every. single. woman. was in a skimpy bikini. Didn't matter if you were at the gas station, the hotel, or the beach. Again, women wear bikinis. I got 0 problems with that. This game just made it feel sleazy and uncomfortable. It would have felt better if the normal clothes to swimwear ratio was the same for both sexes. But this last one could just be me.

Overall, I'd say the $4 price tag is fitting. Even then, I wouldn't buy it again.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

So I finally played this. It was alright. The gameplay loop of finding increasingly powerful weapons to slay increasingly more dangerous zombies was fun and simple. Combat was repetitive but satisfying thanks to the gore and physics systems. The first two areas (resort and city) were gorgeous and immersive, the resort especially, and did a great job setting up a really desolate mood. 
There were some glitches and a general lack of polish that in my opinion added to the charm. Nothing gamebreaking and since death didn't matter at all I didn't mind. 
What did bother me was the nonexistent plot and the portion from the jungle onwards, which felt rushed and restrictive. Very disappointed in the lab section, it's always the part I anticipate and enjoy most in zombie games and this one was just awful, way too short with nothing interesting going on. Also the side quests were mostly boring errands that I started to ignore after a point. 
Definitely worth to pick up at a discount for a few hours of relaxing entertainment.

I've already started to play this years ago however I was too scared then (in general) so I chickened out during the Act 1 already when they introduced Thug zombies :D But now I discovered that it's quite easy to navigate yourself through the game as the difficulty is very friendly actually, requiring only a minimum strategic thinking. As far as I know there is no difficulty settings such as Easy, Hard, Brutal etc, the enemies just scale with your game development.

I was pretty content with the linearity of the main quest as I played this just to chill out and smash some zombies. I usually get very distracted when playing open world games so I was happy I finally managed to finish the main quest (because the game doesn't let you roam around so much and the map isn't so large that its exploration would distract you from your quests) which didn't happen for many years :D I liked the setting in arcs to introduce each location. 

The rooms/locations designs are pretty repetitive (though there are many unique locations which I enjoyed to visit) however I admire the details and texture of objects in there. It's a pity though that the interaction with many objects is prohibited (e.g. only specific bottles are scripted to be interactive so there are a lot of alcohol or water bottles that can't be collected though their design is the same as the interactive ones). The collectibles here are fun to discover.

I really enjoyed the weapon modifications. I also like how authors provided most "battlegrounds" with many different weapons and items (propane tanks etc) to offer various combat strategies.

I'll definitely start a new game with another character (I want this one achievement :D). I didn't used the Fury feature at all because I forgot it exist :D so I'm expecting to get different gameplay experience next time.

[h1]Overview[/h1]
This is the 1st Dead Island game that I should be finished first lol. Instead I played the "supposed to be extended sequel" of it called "DI Riptide". Well this time I played it alone than with friends. And actually this game sucks to do alone.
[h1]Pros[/h1]
+ At the time, this game has pretty graphics, aside some zombies model repetitive AF.
+ The 4 player multiplayer, sad this time no one play with me lol
+ The huge maps, even if its not fully open world
+ The weapons variety actually many. But some locked behind levels, and blueprints
+ The level design pretty, although most of it filled by hidden walls and un-walkable paths
+ The main story is a bit unique, most zombie games mostly virus that came from nowhere that already too late to discover, here we really find the patient zero, also some small mission playing the main villain.
[h1]Cons[/h1]
- Well the gameplay can be felt dated. Its 2013 game anyway. The movement a bit wonky. the running and jumping felt bouncy with no reason. Combat felt bland, I tought some combat mechanics actually same in Dying Light but actually it worser here lol. Riptide actually improved some of this, but still its not justified as sequels of full game. It felt like DLC.
- Driving cars really no different, all trucks no different, and it felt worse than any Far Cry 1st person driving. Car often get stuck, car steering felt like dodge cars arcade you find on piers, but glad it doesnt get damaged somehow. Also you mostly can drive anywhere since idk why the game even give us vehicles if most road is not passable by any cars. We mostly walk & run for everythings.
- The weapon mods really limiting our creativity to make weapons, and without skills durability and losing your thrown weapon really sucks especially when you fully upgraded it.
- Guns sadly sucks if you not play as Purna. They often miss, slow, expensive and now way we can upgrade how many ammo or accessory we can get. Using word "Sluggish, Medum Fire, UInreliable, etc." and their stats actually randomized, you can find same gun with same status/rarity/name but their stats can be better or worse. And when yoiu reach lvl 60 its the same!! WTF??
- The materials is everywhere but its taxing to find expecialyl with walking around since vehicles sucks so hard in this game, and most of it sold by shopkeeper for expensive values. And finally limiting us to make certain crafted weapons. And it's mostly sucks too, toxic/flame backfires if zombie fall to us. Shocks don't do shit to zombies, guns never get accurate except you are Purna. Farming guns need to kill humans that have AI worse than zombies.
- Switch between level have too many loading, good if your pc fast enough tho since its fast. But imagine if you PC sucks.
- The minimap on the bottom right serve nothing than make you confused, its just blanks. It really not showing what to pick or where to go. You need to find promts from game UI. Then why not design it as top compass like skyrim then if the game hesitates to tell us what layout we are walking is? So we repeatedly open and close maps.
- There still game breaking bugs everywhere. Can be solved by reloading save/restart last checkpoint/suicide but we spawn aaaaallll the way back. Escort missions is the worst in this game.
- While VA is good, the interactions is really bad, but I commend the game since our main characters speak and behave like NPC too lol. Stiff, clunky, souless and uninspiring. All of them behave the same. 100% immersions. And I think the deeper you progress the story, the more you think all of the DI team isn't a team at all and most of them either oblivious or arsehole completely.
[h1]Consclusion[/h1]
So I decided not to finish the game lol, It's really tiring grinding alone and I already have many games that need to be played that actually a singleplayer game. I will replay the game if there's any friend that want to play this game one day. Is it a bad game? Well no, but for a game that really designed as multiplayer coop game, the grinding, missions, exploring, etc. feel tedious. So if you can find 3 more friends to play, go for it.

It´s my favorite zombie game just for the gameplay and vistas in it.
Though while the visuals still hold up with the definitive edition, the gameplay doesn't.

The second act is what feels like an extremely early prototype for Dying Light 1.
And for that, for a modern audience I'd recommend picking up Dying Light 1 instead.

Also the Definitive edition barely fixes the main problems of the PC port, no FoV slider, mouse sensitivity is a bit better but "unplayable" for gun aiming and the game hasn't had any mechanical improvements like balancing.

But if you have a very subpar gaming PC, this is Dying Lite, I hope you enjoy some brainless zombie action.

I played the original Dead Island many years ago. Before Dying Light existed at all. Back in the days the zombie survival games weren't that many. For a long time I was in a dilemma if to buy the definitive or not because of the negative reviews telling me that it';s buggy, unmpleyable, worst etc...
I'll tell you what, kids, the game was buggy, gummy and clunky back in the days as well. Doesn't matter how well you remember it. Doesn't matter if you played it before or not. Right now, the game has improved textures and (maybe) some gameplay improvements, although I doubt it. It feels just the same as before. The game is improved to the point that you won't feel it worst then before. That's it. And being 4 euro on discount means it is cheap. You are not robbed, or anything like that. Pls stop exaggerate. 
The atmosphere is very nice. That's what made the game soo good and nostalgic. The story is dull, but Dying Light's story isn't good as well. It's a game and the gameplay is fun. That's what matters first. You can craft nice melee weapons, you can cut zombies in pieces and you can airkick them in the face. Yes, the gameplay is clunkier then dying light but overall, this game feels and looks more beautiful. A beautiful tropical island and a zombie apocalypse. Love it.
Well, I'm looking forward to DI2 in 2023

A few years back, I got this game on Steam. I never played it because back then my PC couldn't run it.

Now, with my friends wanting to play with me, there was one issue: My copy was delisted, and my friends had this so called ~DEFINITIVE EDITION~. I wouldn't be able to play with them with my copy because the devs/publisher did not provide me with a copy, I'd have to pay them again for it. 

Got this thing, and expecting a decent, remastered game... Boy, I was in for a treat.

The first thing that popped was the comically stereotyped characters and NPCs that were clearly supposed to be someone else. Examples: A child, voice-acted and with the model of a 30-year old woman. Two Asian brothers with the stereotypical accent, but had their models being of white males.

Then came the playable characters whose Skills are wildly unbalanced. 

- The Firearm-focused character can't use Firearms because they're either without ammo or because they are useless against zombies (multiple headshots with an Assault Rifle are like throwing cotton balls at them), specially when often bullets would PHASE THROUGH enemies without damaging them;

- The Blade-focused character has barely any XP bonus Skills, and will stay at least 20 levels behind everyone else in the party;

- Sam B is the most OP in XP Skills, will be ahead of everyone else, and will easily have the best weapons as most of the weapons you find are of the Blunt type: his specialty;

The character animations are laughable most of the time, with their dead, bug-eyed faces staring at the screen as if they're zombies themselves. The writing is also atrocious, and with characters dying when the player can't feel a thing for them. Their face textures are like from an indie cash-grab Android game;

The enemies themselves are really bugged. They can respawn in front of you while you are looking at them, about 30 seconds after you killed everyone. This will be so surprising it'll easily kill you as you're speechless. In fact, zombies in the Prison Level (Act IV) will sometimes LOSE THEIR TEXTURE, displaying a debug message on its corpse like "please select missing skin" (I don't recall the right message) as a bright yellow helmet floats on top of their corpses. Enemies can also run through you as you're fighting them.

Also on the Texture side, most in-game objects are mirrored, likely out of laziness. Problem is, they were so lazy they incorrectly did so, and any player can easily notice this since it's everywhere: from the dashboards of cars, to posters on walls or to the jacket of one of the MAIN CHARACTERS.

Spawning after you login back in a friend's game puts you in a different place than the one you logged off. You may have quit the game inside of a safe building, only to spawn in the middle of a horde on the street once you log back in.

Some doors ingame will be stuck in a position, you won't be able to open or close it after using them a couple of times.

The weapons are inconsistent, with most of them being locked away at higher levels, and even so, a Shotgun, Assault Rifle or Magnum are often weaker than the Wooden Paddle you're currently carrying.  A Heavy Pistol is apparently capable of holding only 9 rounds when its model is of an HK USP pistol.

The Jungle level has an unique zombie but it's extremely underwhelming and easily defeated. What is also worse about the Jungle level is the amount of invisible walls and glitchy map features that can make driving a nightmare. One moment the entire party was killed because the vehicle got stuck in an invisible object in the middle of a road clearly marked by the game's map.

Some walls in the game maps are completely missing, specially in ACT IV, revealing the broken insides of the map since it was either rushed or lazily put together.

Finally, there was the final boss fight. It literally took 35 seconds for us to finish it, and by the end of it? The game's hyped up, scary monster, was bouncing on top of the helicopter as its ragdoll glitched and threw it around like a rocket.

This game was paid for twice, for this sort of experience, and then some YouTuber will come and say it was over-hated? Sometimes players deserve broken games, lmao

Dead Island Definitive Edition is a fantastic survival horror game that offers a lot of replay value. The game takes place on a tropical island that has been overrun by zombies, and your goal is to fight your way through hordes of the undead in order to stay alive. The gameplay is fast-paced and intense, with a variety of different weapons and abilities to choose from.

One of the things I love most about Dead Island is the sense of progression you get as you progress through the game. As you level up, you'll unlock new abilities and weapons that make you more powerful, which is always satisfying. The game also has a lot of different side quests and activities to keep you busy, which adds a lot of replay value.

The graphics of the game are also a standout feature. The island is beautifully realized, with a lot of attention to detail in the environments. The character designs are also very cool, and the zombie designs are particularly impressive.

Overall, I highly recommend Dead to anyone who enjoys survival horror games. It's a fantastic game that offers a lot of depth and replay value.

Lots of nostalgia, played this a lot on xbox 360 and I still love it to this day.

With sequels, prequels and spin offs there's an army of reviews, videos etc etc etc out there so I'm not gonna repeat them. Instead I'll concentrate on why I bought it (again).

[h1]Two Braaains[/h1]

I had this game originally on the PS and started playing it shortly after meeting my partner. I'd play and she'd sit there watching, too afraid of the zombies to join in. So naturally I have a soft spot for this game, lets fast forward to today >>> we now have two kids.

[h1]Mini Zombie Slayer[/h1]

My son is now 8 years old (just about to turn 9) and likes age appropriate horror themes in all media however, it's hard as a parent to authentically get excited over a Minecraft mod that makes Minecraft "scary" when you personally have no interest in Minecraft. No matter how hard I try, it's just not for me.

Naturally, I always kept an eye on the look out for a game that we can both play that has:

* Horror themes
* Plenty of fun
* Many laugh out loud moments from an immature perspective
* Works as a good stepping stone into more mature horror media.

Dead Island without a doubt ticks these boxes, then some.

I seen Dead Island on sale and thought "perfect", I'll get that, let him watch it for a bit and gauge his reaction. If all goes well, I'll offer him a go. He loves it.

[h1]My 8 Year Old Sons Review[/h1]

"It's fun to jump on zombies heads and kick them and then just kill them when they're on the floor. It's fun to explore, like, everywhere. 

The story was good but they could make it better. I liked the crafting but they could've made more like wooden planks to put on the door so zombies can't break in. It wasn't really scary unless a zombie jumps up on you".

Dead Island is a fantastic zombie game - great fun solo but even better with a friend. Taking the heads off the shoulders of the undead is satisfying and impactful and the sunny island of Banoi provides a stunning backdrop for all the bloodshed. I've played through Dead Island several times on the Xbox 360 and later the Playstation 4 so I'm looking forward to spending more time with it on PC. 
Yes, there is a layer of jank and more than a few bugs to be found but I've never come across anything that has ruined my fun or broken the game. To be honest, the jank is part of its personality along with the plastic npc's and laughable voice acting. I would recommend Dead Island to fans of classic Romero Zombie films and when you have played this, go play the even better Dying Light.

The mouse sensitivity in the menu's is abysmally slow. and the sensitivity ingame is extremely sensitive so you have to set a custom mouse dpi profile that is super low in order to make it playable. I hate using controllers so this is a huge negative downfall of this port. i really wish they could have fixed such a BASIC issue in the g-d d-mned "remastered" version of the game but they didnt. shows how much they care right?

Sigh, another day, another game I can't finish due to technical problems. Granted, I did manage to play until Act 3 and got just under 8 hours of playtime. However, the game has crashed on me 6 times during. I was willing to just patience it out and deal with it, but it seems the closer I get to the end the more frequently it happens. Its gone from happening every hour or two, to happening within 5 minutes of entering the damn game. I tried a bunch of listed troubleshooting methods, but to no avail, so I'm just gonna have to give up.

That all being said, when the game isn't crashing constantly, is the game any good? Well in total honesty, the game is fine? If anything its incredibly average.

The island locale is very interesting and there are lots of different locations that you will visit as the game goes on. The remaster leads to some really great lighting and in some places the game has aged pretty well. Although I will note that the animations in particular have not aged very well.

The combat still feels really satisfying to this day, the levelling system is pretty satisfying and there is just a solid foundation here for a great game. The problem is in the execution. The plot is basically every zombie game you have ever played in your life, and the characters are boring/forgettable. The voice acting is also pretty bad across the board, I know I straight up died laughing as soon as I heard Steve Bloom attempting an Aussie accent. The game has an odd tone as well as I couldn't tell if I was supposed to be taking it seriously or not? You can't really take it seriously regardless because what's here is just far too shallow for you to actually care.

Really the main issue I have with Dead Island is the enemy and mission design. The default zombies are fine but the special types lack imagination and aren't even fun to fight. The armoured zombies in Act 2 are incredibly spongey. The tall buff zombies are also like this except they knock you down every single time they hit you, forcing you to watch a slow as hell animation of you getting up over and over again.

You might ask, "Well why don't you just dodge those hits?"

Well the issue with this is that the movement is also incredibly limited and clunky. You move really slow, you can't mantle or climb at all, meaning anything taller than waist height is your arch nemesis and all in all, moving around the zombies is a right pain in the ass. This also extends to the driving, which feels really floaty, not to mention the weird delays when steering and accelerating.

The mission design is also really basic, I'm talking first time developer basic. Nearly the entire game is spent doing fetch quests for other survivors who are either too pussy or too lazy to do it themselves. You are literally just an errand boy for everyone else on the island. You'll be collecting cans, flicking switches, escorting survivors and everything else you hate doing in better games, except this is for the entire game. You know you've messed it up when the side missions and the main quests are virtually the same, both being extremely basic and boring.

There's plenty of other minor things I could pick at, like how all the characters appear in the scripted cutscene's regardless of if you're playing co-op or not. Zombies with melee weapons can absolutely drop you compared to regular enemies. Jin, who you meet at the end of Act I, is incredibly annoying and is essentially a walking burden to you. I also experienced a bunch of glitches, including npc's vanishing into the ground, the game had rain sound effects without rain being present and a bunch more.

This remaster was the gold opportunity for the devs to fix these technical issues and perhaps clean up some of the funkier mechanics. Instead, they did a lazy port of an already incredibly flawed game. All of this combined with the constant infuriating crashing that prevented me from even finishing it? I'd say leave it to rot just like the zombies, its not worth it

Dead Island is a Melee focused FPS/Looter Shooter.  Being an 11 year old game, there are some flaws, especially with the gun play portion of the game.  
     You can tell the melee is what they focused on, and it plays very well, with you having to aim at the body parts you want to cut off, and having to find the correct distance to stand from an enemy to hit them.  I struggled with some of the boss type enemies, one in particular, but mainly because I have a hard time moving and shooting in this game.  And because I suck.
     The graphics look about as good as you expect them to for something that is 11 years old, and the age is also apparent in the cut scenes.  The story is average.  You can see where things are going and what you are going to have to do to progress past certain areas.  
     I only did a portion of side quests in this play through, and they where all average for the most part.  Get this for that person, kill this guy for that person, find this person for that person, let them know they are OK.  About what you'd expect for this game.  The environment scales with your level, so if you choose not to do them you won't be under leveled later in the game.  
     So if you are a fan of FPS, Looter Shooters, or Zombies, or need something COOP to play with your friends, definitely check this one out.  It's worth a look, especially if you can find it on sale.

[h1]Zombie flesh eaters the game[/h1]
 
[u]What I liked about the game[/u]
[list] 
[*]	You have a choice of four different characters, each with their own specialities and back stories. I played as Xian Mei who specializes in sharp weapons.  

[*]	You get to fight different types of awesomely designed zombies, like the Walkers, Infected, Floaters, and etc.  

[*]	I like where the game takes place. I liked exploring the resort, Jungle, and town. 

[*]	Loads of collectables, like ID cards, files, and tape recorders.  

[*]	A nice selection of weapons. I like that the low level weapons look like they are falling to pieces compared to the higher level ones which look pristine and badass. You can also upgrade your weapons and repair them. 

[*]	I like that you can drive vehicles and use them as battering rams. 

[*]	The game has a ton of side quests to keep you busy. 

[*]	You can upgrade three different areas which are fury, Combat, and survival. You can upgrade inventory space, your fury mode, weapon effectiveness, and etc. 

[*]	The gameplay is a lot of fun. I like that you can dismember different parts of a zombie’s body. The kick makes the game much easier, so make sure you use it.   

[u]What I disliked or was disappointed with[/u]
 
[*]	The voice-acting and the cut-scenes are dreadful, although they do have a certain charm to them. 

[*]	The game is has a few bugs and glitches, like items clipping through objects, doors being able to kill you, dodgy lighting and shadow effects, and etc. I had to keep switching full screen on and off to fix the lighting and shadows. 

[*]	The game is a bit too long. 

[*]	The characters stamina is pathetic. 

[*]	The flashlight takes too long to recharge. It would have  been nice to be able to upgrade your flashlight. 

[*]	Soundtrack wasn’t anything special. 

[*]	I didn’t like the idea of items respawning in loot boxes you already searched. 

[*]	More vehicles to drive instead of the same pick-up truck. It would have been nice to be 
able to upgrade your vehicle.

[*]	You can’t disable the auto-aim for the guns.    
[/list]
[u]Conclusion[/u] 

The game reminds me of the film Zombie flesh eaters, because the game takes place on an island with zombies and it also has bad voice acting. The game just need’s a cut-scene where zombies have a fight with a shark underwater. The game isn’t on the same level as Dead Rising or Resident Evil, but it is still a good game. I liked exploring the island Banio and I really enjoyed the combat.  If you like zombie games then I recommend you give this game a go. 

[h1]7/10[/h1]

The game is extremely buggy, in all the same ways the original was. In particular, it doesn't play nice with alt+tabbing on Windows.
For a 2011 game, it doesn't run well on older hardware.
NPCs have an extreme case of sameface, the remaster did not help on this front at all.
The plot struggles to be coherent, let alone interesting, and the main characters have no agency in it. Quest writing is similarly bad.
Dead Island's damage over time mechanics are some of the most annoying I've ever seen in a video game, to the point that otherwise cool weapons (like a fire axe that sets people on fire) aren't worth using because you'd have to deal with your own DOT effect.
Balance is all over the place in general, you probably don't even need a weapon for 95% of the first act because the E key is just better in a lot of ways. 
Level design is also all over the place: most of the game is kind of trivially easy, but you get spots where a zombie will one-shot you with a throwing knife or where you're forced to break down a door directly into the line of fire of several men with guns.
The final act is extremely short and linear compared to the previous acts, and makes the game seem unfinished.
There are several escort missions (everyone's favorite) and the NPC quality varies greatly, with some of them practically running through zombie hordes.

In spite of all this, I had fun playing Dead Island again. This game feels like an experiment in how janky you have to make a zombie game for it to stop being fun. I still can't recommend it though. $20 is too much for what it is. If you still want to buy because you're nostalgic for the 360/PS3 days, at least wait for a sale like I did.

Long story short: the game is decent, but it has a fair share of its problems.

[h1]Pros:[/h1] 
- very good for coop, if you can manage to get someone to play this game with you,
- numerous choices of weaponry,
- various upgrades that further increase the variety of weapons,
- number of enemies and enemy types keep the game interesting for a longer time, you don't really expect tougher enemies in seemingly normal areas, therefore it keeps you on your toes most of the time (once you get out of the beach),
- different enemy type will require you to assume a different tactic for them, also it is amazing how seeing one of the tougher enemies (Ram, Butcher) will make you instantly go "oh sh*t" when you least expect it,
- skill tree is actually useful and allows you to pretty much have most if not all of the perks you would like your character to have,
- nice touch for a zombie design as going from beach through city to the jungle you can clearly see the difference in former residents (now zombies) in form of their outfit, this helps to maintain the immersion somewhat,
- the same goes for the music, it changes with locations, 

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
- firearms are pretty much a no-no until you reach the city, prior to that good luck finding any ammo (unless you found a recipe to craft bullets),
- game feels clunky, especially in combat when multiple zombies swarm you, if you are unlucky you will be dead there and then,
- floaters are a joke, particularly when the game decides to place 3 of them close together then make you walk back through the same section and fight them again, 
- respawn rate of enemies is ridiculous, you can literally wipe many areas to go for a mission, fulfil requirements of it just to go back and clean the same area once again - and then again if you were tasked to do something within that same area,
- NPC escorts... seriously, i was thankful for checkpoints as AI of escorted characters decides to fight 4-5 or more zombies on their own, just to be killed and make you restart your mission,
- placing suiciders right behind the door that you have to break through is a d*ck move,

[h1]Side notes:[/h1]
Story falls apart once you reach the jungle, until that point the "disease" making zombies was a mystery and had a curiosity factor to it, when you realise why the outbreak happened it's more of a "is that it?". Also the very ending of the game, instead of having a great "reveal" of whatever was going on, or whoever was behind it all - all you get is a generic boss fight.

In general, the game kept me going because there was a clear progression through the campaign, however most of the main quests were really insignificant in terms of impact on the narrative (i like to think that if i would be trapped on the island like that, my main goal wouldn't be to go to the petrol station risking my life for two boxes of orange juice). Characters were also exaggerated, especially Sam B and Logan, but hey i get it. 

Still, regardless of all the cons - THIS GAME IS AMAZING WITH FRIENDS!

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead, murdered by my brother-in-law Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, Hank came to me with a rather, shocking proposition. He asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using his connections in the drug world. Connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded, I... I always thought that Hank was a very moral man and I was... thrown, confused, but I was also particularly vulnerable at the time, something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me on a ride along, and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin so I agreed. Every day, I think back at that moment with regret. I quickly realized that I was in way over my head, and Hank had a partner, a man named Gustavo Fring, a businessman. Hank essentially sold me into servitude to this man, and when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn.
Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling out. From what I can gather, Hank was always pushing for a greater share of the business, to which Fring flatly refused to give him, and things escalated. Fring was able to arrange, uh I guess I guess you call it a "hit" on my brother-in-law, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured, and I wound up paying his medical bills which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge, working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring, and did so. In fact, the bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen in the ranks to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA, and about that time, to keep me in line, he took my children from me. For 3 months he kept them. My wife, who up until that point, had no idea of my criminal activities, was horrified to learn what I had done, why Hank had taken our children. We were scared. I was in Hell, I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, to end this nightmare, and in response, he gave me this. I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. I... All I could think to do was to make this video in hope that the world will finally see this man, for what he really is.

If there's anything positive I can say about this game, its that I had alot of fun playing through the story in co-op mode with a buddy. Besides that, there isnt much to brag about.

-Zombies kept clipping through walls and got stuck in the most ridiculous way. 

-Weapons constantly degrade to the point where i ended up using my fists until i could scrounge up enough cash to upgrade. 

-By the 3rd Act you'll constantly be running into Zombies that will pretty much require you to have guns in order to deal with them properly. 

-The driving mechanics are shit on a shingle. 

Basically it felt like left 4 dead but turned into an open world with a quest system instead of plowing through linear levels. I would only get this if you love Zombie Survival games and dont mind a lack of polish.

This game hasn't aged very gracefully. I'll open with that. Its systems are outdated at best and there are tons of bugs prevalent throughout the game. Facial animations are offputting at best. With that in mind, even given it's flaws the game still manages to be fun. Weapons feel like they have real weight to them, and every hit feels good. The mods are pretty cool, though I wish there was some crazier stuff you could craft. Fighting zombies is the best part of the game, which is why it's a shame that the game feels like it constantly keeps you from doing that with too much talking and too many fetch quests. 
       Aside from that, if you want a good story, you'll be disappointed. The game fails to make you care about any of the characters and all of it's attempts at emotional appeal tend to fall flat. 
       Even with all this, it's still a lot of fun. Fighting zombies is a lot of fun. I recommend playing with a friend and if you really have an interest in the precursor to Dying Light. If you just want a really good well rounded open world zombie game though, you should play Dying Light instead.

Dying Light is a grand game. Somewhat comprehensive parkour, weapon customization, truly satisfying combat, fluid controls and a story that... exists. A lively community and a very enjoyable experience, especially when playing during the night cycles. Especially especially, if you use a mod that lengthens the night cycles.

Dead Island, however, has no parkour (unless you count creative jumping), has clunky controls, does not have a day and night cycle (although it does rain in Moresby now and then), combat that is pretty straight forward and the story is.... in beta?

This may start to sound like a full knock against Dead Island, and to some extent, I can't really suggest this title to those without a certain level of patience or younger than a certain age (some of us are old enough to remember when EVERY game had terrible controls and acting), actually try this game. However, I can honestly say that while it is a thrill to run from Volatiles and stunt drive through the country side, eventually you become accustomed to the Volatiles AI, fully level Crane and become an unstoppable force of parkouring, fashion sinning, cliche'ing, repeatable event doing, super dropkicking, and bored Hero.

Dead Island, however, has never ceased to frighten me. Much like in the original Resident Evil, Dead Island will keep you guessing even after hitting it's level cap or NG+ simply because the controls and how the character moves can put you over a barrel if you are not careful. You can never become over confident because the game will constantly throw tons of the undead at you and no matter how powerful you are, Butchers will leave you rekt.

In these years of playing DI across several platforms, there is still a sense of dread and giddiness I get when booting up this gloriously fun fireball of a train wreck. Just don't play this for the story. It's not enough to put me off the game, I can see what the goal was, but as I mentioned above, it clearly wasn't finished. Rather, what shines here is the collection of massive sandboxes, the eeriness of the ambience, and laundry list of quests/missions.

As I said, Dying Light is a grand game. It's the safe choice. You get what you pay for, that is, a zombie game with melee and parkour focus, plenty of content and a finished (if predictable) story. However, if you enjoy the gaming scene from "ye olde" times and all their frustrations, if you have a certain level of patience, if you enjoy never feeling so powerful that you can go make a sandwich while the game plays and come back to room full of dead zeds, and you can find the mute option for the depressing music, you may find this to be a worthwhile experience.

As you might be able to tell, I am conflicted about this game. I want to recommend it because I love this title and it's flaws. However, looking at it metrically, it is a shoddy product. Especially for it's time. I think if you are still a zombie freak, you will get some good times from this. If not, well, play it safe unless you absolutely do not mind wasting a bit of time and money.

Recommending this game is a close call. There are many things that are pretty bad / outdated. It's by far not as polished but has similar vibes.

The game play follows a nice story with plenty of side missions and a nice rise for equipment (gun more widely available after the second act.) The downfall (main reason I don't recommend) is an odd system where weapons vanish at random (sometimes inopportune times). All the hard work of scavaging, earning and upgrading an item can vanish in a flash for no apparent reason. Sometime it can be when you are modding it with electric damage, toss it at a enemy who get out of you line of site for a split second and despawns, or when you build an item in the workbench. 
As I've researched after experiencing this bug/glitch/problem more than a few time, previously thinking I forgotten the item somewhere, I found it has been in the game since it's release, with no apparent work on fixing it. I will chalk it up to a unfavorable outcome and my nostalgia of playing this game on console (forgetting or not noticing it was there before). However I will not recommend this to anyone from this point on.

Dead Island has many great ideas that have turned the developers’ next zombie title ‘Dying Light’ into a great hit and made Techland a household name. 

Progression is exciting and the developers clearly put a lot of effort into making the world as interesting as they possibly can. I love the idea of tropical paradise turning into hell and there is a variety of different environments to explore. 

However, the game is reluctant to let you enjoy the fun part, killing zombies. It has all the tedium of the survival games that were popular back then, an era which I’m glad we have moved on from. The story and cutscenes are really bad, but not the funny kind, just sad. Although I love the environments, the game is visually really ugly, and it hurts my eyes. I’m not a huge graphics guy but I think Deep Silver really dropped the ball with these definitive editions.  

It's okay if you want to experience the game with the boys but the achievements show most people didn’t even make it into Act II, so be cautious.

So...Dead island. This game is plagued with bugs and glitches that depending on who you are will either improve or ruin the experience for you and the jank is never ending. The soundtrack is just alright with the exception of "who do you voodoo" which is honestly such a jam. Its just kind of okay there's really not a whole lot to be enjoyed as all the missions are repetitive and the gameplay doesn't change much throughout the entire run time of the game. The gore is fine but games like left 4 dead do it so much better. Honestly if you are looking for a zombie game of high quality this is NOT the game for you. However, Dead island does have a certain... something about it that charms me. Everything i have said may lead you to believe that this game is deserving of a negative review, however i for whatever reason enjoy this game a lot more than I should. Should you get in instead of dying light? no. Is it worth the money? on a sale maybe. but if breaking things is what you find fun then there is plenty to be had here. If i could do a mixed review i would definitely do that, however i lean more towards the positive with dead island. The same can not really be said for riptide though...

[b]Q: [/b]Should I buy this game and is it any good after all this years?
[b]A: [/b]Yes, definitely!

First of all, I want to say that I used to play this game when it came out, back in 2011. the original one, not the definitive version. It was a great game back than, unique for that time. I used to play it whole day, every day. It was great looking game, great combat and exploration, nice leveling system. I met so many good friends online playing this game and Riptide later.
I came back to the definitive edition game (this one) after so many years and after playing Dying Light (DL from now on). I was surprised that there are still players online. I was expecting bad graphics but it still looks great. Even better than the original, the graphics still hold up. It is still a gorgeous looking game and fun to play, must say maybe even better combat system than DL.
Great scenery on a remote island, beaches, palms, sea, mountains... You can drive cars, you can travel on foot, explore abandoned buildings and help survivors that you discover travelling on the map. Tons of a side quests to do, you will need to help a lot of scared people and make them feel secured. Main goal is to escape the Island.
Best part of a combat system is that you need to find weapons, upgrade them, make them even better, repair after and try to find better ones. Sure, you can find guns later in the game and became terminator, but still, hand weapons plays the big role in this game and make it so much fun. [spoiler]You can literally chop body parts of a zombie![/spoiler]
For the end, you can play this game online or over Lan, up to 4 players. Chat and voice system are supported and it can be really fun.
Give it a try, game is cheap nowadays so what holds u up for trying it :)

What can I say about Dead Island Definitive Edition... well, its a great game but its flawed in more than one way. I love Dead Island and it was one of my first Zombie games that I ever played on my playstation 3. In 2022 Dead Island cannot stand on its own two feet as it is dated so that means whatever is flawed here... other games like it do it better nowadays. 

Pros:
● A decent story but it lacks finesse 
● 4 player coop
● Several explorable maps, if that's your thing
● Crafting/modifications to your weapons
● Collectables 
● Graphics are much better compared to the original version of Dead Island

Cons:
● You get body blocked by teammates. Collision is on so if your friends are standing in a door or a random is... most likely they are trolling you and they will ruin your experience.
● There is no manual save in an open world game of all things.
● Cars can get stuck, zombies get stuck and you get stuck in pretty stupid locations.
● Mainly a melee based game but yet there is no "BLOCK" option with weapons.
● When you run you get this "Blur" that made me feel sick... there is no option to turn it off.

TL;DR/All in all:
Dead Island Definitive Edition is a great play if you have some friends to play it with. If you play with randoms... it will be a troll fest of them blocking doors and killing you. I would however recommend this game as I love the game and it is a MUCH better improved version compared to the original. 7.5/10.

Older game, obviously, but still plays very well. Throwing things at zombies is super satisfying.

One of my favorite games of all time remastered with better graphics and visuals, It's definitely one of the best zombie survival/story games ever made the story is fine and compliments the gameplay well, even more when you play the Ryder 
White DLC, there's also a LOT of collectibles and many of them are missable which makes the game more replayable and interesting, sadly in this definitive edition version of this game there's also some glitches and bugs that weren't there before, one of them is the collectible document Banoi Herald Excerpt 33 which is inside a building that's basically impossible to get in. The different characters with all their different skill trees make this game very replayable and there's even an achievement for playing on all 4 characters. The weapon modding in this game is pretty much top notch when it comes to modding melee weapons, there's a ton of different blueprints to find and test out. The open world is also fun and pretty unique I can't name any open-world where there's a tropical resort area with a luxury hotel, a city full of slums, jungle with a hidden laboratory in it and a whole prison island in one single open-world. The soundtrack/music score is also pretty good and fits well in the game overall.

When I bought this, I was expecting a dead island, as it is the name of the game. Instead, I got an island full of living… my disappointment is immeasurable, and my game is ruined. Please fix it.

The 'Dead Island: Definitive Edition'(s) are console-to-PC ports of a PC-to-console port, with "updated" graphics and dubious performance bottlenecks.
The best thing about them is that co-op play (a highlight -- and, for me, a must-have) is integral; whereas you could easily lose a dozen hours trying to get a multiplayer game going in the original.

'Dead Island' gives players the sweaty, gritty, greasy experience of being stuck in the videogame equivalent of an Italian zombie splatter-house film, alla Fulci or Argento.  The world is open, but segmented for story purposes, and you can foot it, or drive, and even attempt limited parkour -- which the follow-up series ('Dying Light') took as its new direction.
Sadly, combat is stuck in a 'Digital' option, which lacks the enjoyability of the original game's 'Analog' mechanics -- and simply turns combat into a button mash, as you go lick-for-lick instead of deftly combating flesh-eating nasties.

Also, it's worth noting that players must finish the single player prologue before multiplayer options are unlocked.

Worth a buy on sale, if you have a friend or 3 who're into some zombie co-op fun.

What can I say? 

Beautiful vistas, stunning graphics, great combat, entertaining ragdolls, huge open maps to explore, astounding environment control, great paced music, fun weapons + modifications. 

If you haven't played this classic gem yet, I highly recommend some good old Zombie slaughter with some friends. 

Even if you don't have friends, its a truly great time.

If I have any complaints, its this; The city section of the game is trash. Its design is repetitive and boring, its a real let down after how well done the first section/act is and feels. Zombies can instant kill you with zero effort by throwing weapons ... as if a zombie ... with rotten or eaten limbs, ligaments, muscles etc as well as rotting eyes (they are the first thing to rot after death) can accurately throw a knife/plank/cleaver/whatever they have picked up as accurately as an expert knife thrower and they will ALWAYS go for throwing their weapon as the AI knows it's an instant kill. 

This problem doesn't show itself in multiplayer within the city as the zombies attention is divided and groups are quickly dispatched but on your own, which is how the game is played by the majority especially now after a decade or more, it just becomes a very boring running simulator for the entire second act if you don't want to die continuously to expertly thrown weapons by walking corpses. It honestly sucks all the fun out of the game. Seriously, I die to thrown zombie weapons far more than thugs, rams, suiciders, bloaters or anything else combined and there isn't anything you can do about their aimbot throws. 

It doesn't even feel like the same team of dev's worked on these two areas and they certainly didn't talk what so ever as NOT ONE zombie will EVER throw a weapon at you in the first act but can hold and swing them, which makes at least some logical sense and I have zero problem with, but aimbot walking corpses are obnoxious and just honestly terrible work by the dev team. 

I still recommend but the city is boring, repetitive, obnoxious and down right flawed in many ways unless you play multiplayer.

I am a 54 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game.

This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you were supposed to do. I asked my son for help and he hosted a game for me to join.

I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.

I loved the original on xbox and it's still kind of the same game but the definitive edition feels like a straight up down grade, once again thanks to that garbage Dying Light game,

Probably the biggest crime of this downgrade is the fact that the devs spent actual time fixing stuff people would use for xp farming and helping to get achievements easier yet didn't seem to fix a single bug and in fact introduced many more. Most importantly for me, THEY ABSOLUTELY DESTROYED SHOTGUNS, like they aren't even worth using at all anymore, they just straight up suck, it's hard to comprehend just how bad they are now compared to the original and why they felt the need to even touch them never mind release them in the state they are in, i have no words for how stupid it feels to pump 6+ shells into a zombie and it's still alive.

It's been rebuilt using dying lights engine and it just sucks, the lighting is awful, graphics are better at times yet worse, faces look hillariously bad at times, like Jin is more horrifying than the zombies when you have to look at her when accepting quests. The god awful aim assist is still present which makes it near impossible to line up head shots as it keeps focusing on center mass with absolutely no method to turn it off.

It's honestly a worse dead island than the original for me but you can't get the original on steam anymore.

Mods will fix most of your problems but you currently cannot mod out the aim assist nor can you go back to the better physics engine the original had instead of the crappy dying light one.

I hate Dying Light, loved Dead Island, when you mix the two together you get a very subpar Dead Island. The only reason i still recommend it is because it's still ultimately Dead Island and the only one you can get on steam. I'd honestly recommend buying the original over this downgrade edition,

It should have been the foundation for a whole franchise to evolve on, instead we got Dying Light...

If you love staving in zombie heads with various weapons with a lovely tropical backdrop then this game is for you! 
Tons of fun, aged well for what it is and a satisfying gameplay mechanic as you explore this island either solo or with friends. I would recommend getting a buddy or two to join you as its a lot of fun watching a friend try and tackle a large zombie whilst you cackle and look on....only to be rushed by a fast zombie as punishment! Or you can recreate that classic "Shaun of the dead" moment whereby you and your friends all stand around a zombie smacking the crud out of it with your weapons. They missed a trick in not following this game up with a sequel, but alas we got what we got...and we got a good game!

I remember thinking this was a lesser Dying Light... And, sure, you can't parkour, but.... Boy is it fun with a buddy to smash a zombie head with an oar and see those beautiful dmg points show up. It is a simple concept, really. 1st person rpg with weapons that keep breaking down. You can craft, upgrade and repair your weapons and there are lots of quests to do on a pretty decent sized map. It's basic, and that's where it's fun. 
Each character barely barely differentiate in their talent tree, except for the special ability, which you may trigger when you've dealt enough dmg. And boy oh boy is it powerful.
It feels a bit sluggish at times, especially once you've played a game like Dying Light and you're used to jumping around and breaking your face on the pavement, but it is still an enjoyable experience.
