Dead Island is a computer game, a first—person shooter with role-playing elements in the Survival horror genre, which was developed by the Polish company Techland for PlayStation 3, Xbox 360 and PC. The publisher of the game is the company Deep Silver. The game is based on the Chrome Engine 5 engine and presents the player with an open non-linear gameplay, as well as hand-to-hand combat in the first person and the possibility of cooperative passage of the story campaign.

The player controls one of the four surviving characters. The main task of the player is to move around the island in search of other survivors, as well as perform various tasks. The main goal of the game is survival, so the player will come across all kinds of useful items: money, water, food and others. All this is necessary for survival, as well as for completing tasks and creating weapons.

The game implements a realistic manner of the character's behavior. The character has an endurance scale, which is spent while running, jumping or hitting. When the scale is empty, the player becomes vulnerable for a few seconds until the scale is replenished again. The weapon has various parameters: the force of the blow, the effect on the character (how quickly he will get tired) and others. As the weapon is used, it breaks down, losing its properties. Therefore, weapons need to be repaired on special workbenches. There you can also improve it, as well as upgrade it.

During the passage of the game, new parts of the island and types of enemies will be opened. As the player progresses through the game, he will gain experience, and for each new level one point of skills, which are distributed in one of three branches: the first branch of rage allows the character to fly into a rage and subsequently improve this skill, the second branch is responsible for the combat skills of the character and the possession of his type of weapon, and the third branch helps to survive in the game with its help, the player can slowly regenerate health, get more money, open locks and be more resistant to attacks. Each hero has his own skills, abilities, weapons, rage and style of play. The player can distribute skills as he pleases.

The game also has a cooperative mode. Any player can freely find a suitable game in the lobby, having an Internet connection (always except for the prologue, the player must pass it on his own). You can invite friends to the game. Progress is saved only if you play according to your progress, looking ahead, you will have to start from where you left off.

I think a lot of the positive reviews for this game are because of nostalgia and/or previous experiences. This game is just not very good. Hacking, slashing, and slamming energy drinks for HP is fun for a while, but the story is just so laughably incoherent and poorly written that any immersion or attachment to the characters and setting evaporates immediately. The combat is actually pretty fun, but the skill progression is boring and somewhat poorly designed, and the side characters and quests are incredibly bland. That isn't even mentioning the myriad of bugs that I ran into - and I don't know if it's because it's ported to the Dying Light engine, or if they were just in the original game.

The Definitive Edition DOES fix the catastrophic game-stopping bugs that the original PC version(s) had that literally prevented some players from even getting past Act 2, but the game just hasn't aged very well and when held up next to it's successor Dying Light it just becomes so painfully apparent that this game is effectively a tech demo.

Put simply: it's rare for me to not finish a video game that I've spent money on; I like to give games a fair shot and have the 'full experience' playing them. I was very, very tempted to simply turn this game off and stop playing it about halfway through, and the only reason I didn't was to finish the playthrough with my friends.

Just play Dying Light, you'll have more fun.

I bought this game for nostalgia so my opinion or review might not be helpful. But this game is great atleast for its time. The controls are kinda heavy feeling for today's standard and it has lots of glitchy animations. The cutscenes and characters are not dated obviously their expressions are lack luster compared to modern games. But considering that this is a remaster of a 2011 game it is quite good. The crafting and looting are simple and easy to navigate, the UI is kinda edgy in my opinion tho it is still on theme, the weapon deterioration adds to the immersion and the leveling system is kinda ahead of it's time. All in all the game is good and you can have fun with friends but if you are expecting some days gone level polish? this is not the game for you.. Now excuse me as I venture off on my nostalgia ship as I end this game once again.

With a fresh coat of paint concealing bugs, both new and old, and an overall lack of polish seen in its original form, this lacklustre release exacerbates rather than enhances; however, I can say that the game's still fun. It's a testament to its design and formula that most of its issues can be overlooked; newcomers will have an easier time seeing past its flaws, but it can be enjoyed solo or invariably with friends, as the tone jarringly oscillates between poignant and pantomime - of course the latter being multiplied in multiplayer.

Enjoyable game overall, but not without its flaws.

Positives:
- Beautiful graphics, I really liked all environments except the city
- Great sound design, adds to the scariness and tells you what zombies are nearby
- Overall scary but fun high intensity gameplay
- Perfect to bring friends along
- Reasonable price

Negatives:
- Sometimes unfair, especially referencing zombies that will one-shot you by hiding within a group and throwing a cleaver at your head
- Ridiculous bug where sometimes bumping into other players or objects can randomly cause you to die (I assume fall damage calculations going funny). This is really bad because you lose thousands of dollars for every death, but it only happened to me 2-3 times in 20 hours.
- Shotgun sucks in definitive edition

The game sort of plays like the same, The combat is really satisfying  to be honest and its definetly one of the few things that drives me into this game, Especially with the throwing ability, Like its really fun to just throw it at zombies, The story is okay but nothing special really, The quests are fine like its mostly  collecting items or doing certain tasks just like your other rpg games, Really its more of a decent game than anything else, All I really want from this game is the variety of weapons I do hear there are guns but not that much of them and I know its supposed to be a tropical game relying on melee weapons but some few guns won't hurt right?

Other than that the game is more of a hit and miss. You may like it, You may not like it, So its the best you buy this game when its on sale.

It's a solid game with collision boxes as big as a truck. But I play it in Co-op with 2 other people and the developers clearly did not.

I have finished it a couple of times, both before and after Dying Light :)
And we can definitely see a progress Techland has achived.
Setting in Dead Island is great and can be close for everyone: summer, island, vacation, sea/ocean, hotels, bungalows, sun and relaxation :)
Co-op experience is very good, haven't noticed any problems. Game is not hard, more like enjoyable. Playing it with somebody does not ruin the experience.
Visuals are OK, setting does it's job :D
Story is a bit on a weak side, so you can look at Dead Island as at linear co-op based game, where you can have some fun, with basic story supporting your journey.
You can choose from several characters, each has it's own speciality and bonuses. You have skills and levels here, so some sort of variation is present. You can drive cars, shoot from guns, not only meelee is present.
The thing I don't like so much in such games (including Dead Rising) are weapon crafting and it's constant breaking. I could not care less about this this aspect of crafting. You have perks that increase your damage with specific weapons, like 2-handed. But in order to use it properly you have to either look for them (good luck) or craft them, which means look for resources to gather. And your weapons are breaking pretty fast, which makes this process a bit not worth it. Some weapons can be fun to use and look at, but I'd like less loot, less weapons, but more meaningful with more durability.
To sum it up, Dead Island is like a prototype of Dying Light without parkour and with everything a bit more basic :)
Story-based co-op games are not very common, so I can definitely recommend to add Dead Island to you collection to enjoy with friends!

I re-purchased this game. I re-funded it initially due to reasons. 

Re-spawns happen a bit too fast in some instances. The game auto-launched me into online, co-op mode, and got me splattered. Aside from these issues, and the extremely unnerving beginning of the game where you will likely die for travelling too far down a certain hallway because you don't have a direction indicator, pretty fun game. If you have friends to play with, this is a perfect game. The world is gorgeous, the exploration is fun, and the npc's are enjoyable. The characters to be chosen from are immersive, each with their own style and diatribe.

Possibly the dullest gaming experience I've ever had. Quite literally _every_ mission is either a fetch quest or an escort mission.

The story is uninteresting to say the least, and full of cliches and nonsensical bits.

The gameplay is repetitive and clunky, with no actual progression or significant development.

The engine itself is glitchy as hell, I've had several (5+) points in the game where I either had to force reload from checkpoint or I straight up died 'cause some NPC squished me into a wall.

What little fun I had was thanks to my coop partner, and that couldn't last for very long in such a terrible playthrough. Looks like this is the game Techland went back to to get inspired while making Dying Light 2.

I wanted to try Dead Raising but got confused, ended up playing Dead Island.

Turns out it is not miserable.

Frankly speaking it is not bad for a 2016 game. I focus on the main missions (some side missions are on the way so I did them incidentally) and the story goes pretty fast and straightforward. It is a typical zombie outbreak story but happens on a vocational island. The protagonist gets up from a beachside hotel, quickly finds other survivors and they work together to get out, with some interesting set like the invisible blood from the tribe and the vaccine from the lab. Game has 4 chapters, within the progress player gets to visit the town, sewer, jungle, lab and prison. Other missions include temporarily area, the map is rich however not very into details, and big.

Good for players to go fast travel, certain main missions ask players to drive cars or follow companions. Those are tedious, driving feels boring, the cars don't take damage nor break down objects. Running over zombies can be fun, but not exciting because they cannot hurt you even if the car gets stuck. The distance to drive is too far, the good thing is the waypoint is clear. Following a companion is regular, make sure to protect this NPC otherwise it is a game over.

Most of the missions are simply going to point A and get items. For me I am familiar with The Walking Dead and have played The Dying Light just several weeks ago, I can almost guess what is going to happen in the game. The fun part is to see the island scenery, and the mechanics to beat up zombies - they don't come in swamps like The Dying Light or L4D, but they are everywhere and I need to stay alert, but not all the battles are necessary and zombies stop chasing after a while. In later game guns are available, missions will include battling people with guns, which are very challenging compared with zombies, the higher level they are the longer health bar they have. However, more than 2/3 of the game I go with melee weapons. Players level up by gaining exp, to unlock more weapons and skills, those are regular.

Maybe back 5 years ago Dead Island was one of the best zombie killing games, in my 7 hours gameplay I do not feel major advantages or disadvantages. It is not a horrifying game, the most horrifying thing happened when I talked to a scientist but stood too close and I got to see his eyeballs.

Nostalgia overload

Story is a more depressing take on the zombie genre. While a little over-saturated now, in its time that story clique was in its early peak. The story presentation comes off as a little awkward, but the main themes and story beats are still clear enough for your brain to fill in the blanks and become passionate and care for it. The combat is a little clunky and hard to adjust to, but much like Silent Hill it works in favor of the game with it's themes of mortality. Helps make you really feel like just a person (Despite being immune to the virus)

Overall I would still consider this game a little outdated and not favorable to modern gaming standards, BUT still a memorable and fun experience to play through

Great Graphics And Visuals Paired With Smooth Controls Makes This A Great Open World Zombie FPS... 

The Game Can Bd Quite Stuttery At Times When Loading In New Areas But Kept Above 60FPS In Max Settings...

A Couple Of Small Issues Now... The Achievements Are A Bit Tedious... Some Take A Few Hours To Complete,.. Other Take Minutes... At The Time Of This Review (2.4 Hours Played) All I've Done Is Ran Around Collected Weapons And Done The First Misson...

Overall Would Recommend... Very Addictive And Fun To Play 9/10... The Moaning Does Get Annoying... ( Unless Your Into That ;) )

This game is unplayable without modding, even with all the options in the settings disabled, there is an absurd and ludicrous amount of blur. Thankfully, the following mod can remove all of the blur, and make it so the game can be reasonably enjoyed: https://www.nexusmods.com/deadisland/mods/29

As to the definitive edition, what is the logic of patching the thug xp glitch? I just do not get it! To level from 50 to 60 requires tons of xp. The process is so grinding and uninteresting. The game itself does not grant more xp when you play a new playthrough, and when online you get less xp because you only get a portion of xp earned by other player. One of the BEST ZOMBIE GAMES HANDS DOWN!!! I have replayed this game a few times (not just on steam) and have always found new ways to stay engaged and have fun. This game is one you can easily play solo or with a group of friends. I love mission based games and if that is what you're looking for, you came to the right place. There are tons of side quest options along with the main story line so you can pick and choose which ones you want to do and which ones you don't want to do. I know for some people doing side quests where you feel like you're running back and forth to complete missions can feel tedious but it does not feel this way in this game. All around an enjoyable game and I would highly recommend it to anyone looking for a fun and fast paced zombie game :)

So, with all my experience gained from playing Dying Light, I´ve decided to give Dead Island Definitive Edition a second chance, and now it´s been so much more enjoyable, because I can use the tactics and tricks I learned from playing Dying Light. [spoiler](why waste ammo/weapon on a zombie when you can simply kick them?)[/spoiler]

Another thing that I don´t like is that, about middle-game, they make you run though the sewers, like, four or five times. Not only the sewers are such recurrent, boring paths in horror, surviving games, I was liking this game exactly because it took place in a parade-like resort.

Where to begin? For starters, the PC port performance is abysmal with mass amounts of screen tearing or framerate drops, either it isn't optimised for PC at all or is biased against AMD hardware. While on the topic of the PC port, I would like to mention the fighting mechanics are absolutely ruined with most button strikes not being registered, making combat difficult. Adding to that difficulty is the severe lag induced by however the multiplayer is handled, with desync so bad that it's easier to walk everywhere and avoid vehicles at all costs (unless Vertigo Simulator is something you're after). I enjoy the premise of the game, a classic zombie slasher with a really fun visual aspect. I'll admit, bashing heads in with a crowbar is done better in this game than any other. This, however, is quickly ruined by your stamina (or lack there of) as you're constantly forced to pickup every energy drink in a 10 mile radius just to keep combat moving, if you run out of stamina mid battle then you're SOL if multiple zombies are attacking. You're essentially helpless when knocked to the ground, left to die and forced to restart. I had high hopes for this game though, the graphics are good and the idea is sound. I figured, being an older game it's probably just the PC port that is bad - boy was I wrong. In hopes of more fluid combat and smooth framerates, I installed a copy onto my PS3. At first it seemed better, the controls are more intuitive and the cutscenes/light areas were rendered very smoothly. This quickly changed during the first mission, any more than two zombies will bring the PS3 to a sluggish halt as it chugs through loading assets. The combat is a bit better, button presses are actually registered and it becomes easier to push zombies away. However it still retains the awful stamina, leaving you fightless in a seige of undead. It seems every character in this game is an obese whale with the fighting ability of Mike Tyson that's only limited by their diet of processed sugar and xtreme energy drinks. Surely, I thought, it gets better at you level up and improve your skills. I was wrong, skill points are seemingly only dished out every nine thousand kills which quickly leaves your character severely underdeveloped for the majority of enemies you'll battle. What could've been an excellent hack and slash beatemup is really a grindfest runaround with most missions quickly becoming repetitive. The only accomplishment this game holds is giving false hope then smashing it right in front of your face as it forces you to suffer. Would not recommend, even for free on a PS3.

Great game. I remember when this first came out and everyone was disappointed that it didn't have a great story like what was implied in the trailer. It was also (and still is) a bit buggy. But it's a really great co-op game. Easily among the best in its genre, right up there with Left 4 Dead 2.

I wouldn't recommend it to anyone other than specific people.

I like the game but it was too tedious for me to do the side quests and feel that they were not used for anything other than to level up and get money. The weapons they gave you for doing those side quests usually didn't work for me because of the low damage they did.

The skills don't feel so satisfying to unlock either since it was usually things that went unnoticed like doing more damage, depleting less stamina, increasing the time of rage, things that were hardly perceived as in other video games where they give you new forms of attack or mobility.

The maps are very pretty but they don't feel dynamic. The zombies help keep the locations relatively entertaining, and the beauty of the maps makes you want to explore them but you quickly realize that your curiosity is not rewarded by finding almost nothing. In addition to the fact that the spawning of the zombies could be annoying by having to kill them going from point A to B, but having to kill them again going back. Also searching the bags ends up getting repetitive and throwing your weapons dangerous because they could "disappear" (fall somewhere incoherently far away and maybe impossible to reach).

Something that I really didn't like is that the game is made to be played in cooperative and if you play it alone, the other characters continue to appear in the animations behaving as if they were always accompanying you when they weren't.

But even with all its details, the game entertained me long enough to finish it. But probably because of the melancholy of having wanted to play it since I was a teenager.

To whom it may concern,

My recent stay in your establishment was certainly what one could call an "experience".
What was suppose to be an all inclusive weekend ended up as another energy drink and pills fuelled bender.
With no other form of transport available, I was forced to drive intoxicated all over the island until a man took things into his own hands and banned me from driving. 

Staff were incredibly rude and constantly jumping down our throats.
I was very disappointed to find that the swimming pool was NOT deep enough to jump from the second story and the sunset ocean cruise was a real downer.

Some of the sites were remarkable but the locals were seemingly very hungry.
Petrol prices were ridiculous, had to pay an arm and a leg!

But despite all of the above, I found an amazing man who DIDN'T have a terrible Australian accent.
We are madly in love and bringing our first zombie baby home.

10/10 would recommend.

Have you ever seen the Dead’s Island trailer? It was pretty damn good and for a short while made me live with a delusional hope that a zombie game could have a deeper meaning and innovative plot. Then I've started playing this title and found myself on a big map inhabited by dozens of bland NPC task dispensers. I know it was crazy to expect a good story with freakin’ undead in it, but getting a plot molded from a bunch of quest briefings was a LETDOWN OF EPIC PROPORTIONS. To this day Dead Island’s narrative approach gives me the feeling of disappointment like no other game.
 
For what it’s worth the titular island is BEAUTIFUL. The level design is great, with sprawling areas, multiple settings, and many GORGEOUS LANDSCAPES to admire. It looks incredibly interesting and overwhelms us with the urge to explore every nook and cranny to find pickable items. In most cases, we gather giant amounts of various junk for the game’s CRAFTING SYSTEM, but sometimes we stumble upon a hidden quest, a blueprint, or a weapon crate, which makes it all worthwhile. Overall exploration of those gargantuan levels can be quite fun.
 
Guns and ammo are quite scarce, so combat is mostly MELEE-FOCUSED, but honestly, it’s better this way, since that’s probably the best part of the game. The impacts of blunt weapons throwing undead away or slices of our sharp blade decapitating enemies in a brief slow-motion are INCREDIBLY SATISFYING MOMENTS. We can also customize the experience with various weapon mods and character upgrades, ensuring further that it won’t get stale too fast. So, for the most part, the battle is thrilling… but unfortunately, the magic only happens while we’re fighting low numbers of foes. When facing more than 2-3 zombies each confrontation quickly becomes chaotic, with no time for the subtle approach. We are usually forced to go into the fray and click frantically on our adversaries until they change their alignment from vertical to horizontal - at which point we perform a little Riverdance on their faces to finish them. To make things even messier someone decided it’s a good idea to display damage and XP values right in the middle of a screen, so the enemies during battle are constantly vomiting out colorful numbers with a happy out-of-place font, making big encounters look like a zombie episode of Sesame Street. 
 
Exploring and combat are fine core mechanics and the gameplay could be just oscillating between these two with great results. Alas, we have a third, hidden one, which I’m going to call Miscellaneous Management Crap. It’s basically WASTING OUR TIME ON VARIOUS SCREENS to optimize our combat proficiency. Weapons have the durability of a potato chip, so we have to find a workbench to repair them every few minutes. While we’re here, we might as well upgrade them… Probably craft some enhancements as well… The amount of space for weapons is limited, so perhaps we should drop/sell some of them… The constant inventory tweaks we need to do are infuriating and the UNINTUITIVE INTERFACE doesn’t make things any easier. 
 
Dead Island is first and foremost a multiplayer game, but whether you’re better playing alone or with some people is debatable. COOPERATION IS ALMOST NONEXISTENT, with the only difference other players make for us is providing extra firepower. Unlike other titles there’s no enemy here that can permanently immobilize us, so we can always fight alone - in the worst case we die and lose 10% of our cash, which is never a painful thing. Heck, you can't even use your flashlight to light things up for others (that one detail caused a lot of anger and confusion during the playthrough with my group). It's as if developers were completely determined to cut down interactions between players to a bare minimum, perhaps to help us immerse in this pandemic feeling of isolation.
 
I’ve played Dead Island twice: the original in a “solo mode” and Definitive Edition with a bunch of friends. To be honest I’m not sure which way of playing is better. It’s definitely a unique multiplayer experience since co-op games usually tend to provide shorter segmented missions rather than a giant campaign (this one takes 20-30 hours to complete!), but it’s usually hard to finish it with the same squad in a reasonable amount of time. Both modes are providing a similar amount of fun, so you should just pick the one you’re most comfortable with. But if you’re looking for something besides killing brainless zombies in swimming suits, you should probably keep on searching.

I think I played Dying Light before this, and I've known about it since I were a kid but only seriously got into playing it recently. 

First off, the lack of parkour is sorely felt. Your character feels like a crippled snail and is too lazy or fat to climb on anything that any normal person would be able to. Fall in the wrong crevice and you might have to reload. To say Dying Light is a massive improvement is an understatement.

The setting is amazing. I'm a huge fan of tropical settings and zombies so it's only natural that I'd love that aspect. People say the city is boring compared to the resort but I also love urban areas and I really liked the desolate, ransacked, gloomy feel to it, especially when it's raining. It also helps that it reminds me of Harran from Dying Light (for better or worse; once again, the lack of parkour bogs it down). I also really like the voodoo elements. I feel that's a lost influence behind the zombie genre and it's nice to see some homage being paid here.

I like the protagonists and wish they felt more involved. They don't feel as alive as, say, the L4D survivors. They kinda just feel "there" and it's a shame because they have colorful designs and backstories. The side characters are okay I guess. Nothing special but interesting enough. Voice acting is hit or miss. It's amusing to hear the more recognizable actors like Steve Blum and Yuri Lowenthal put on cheesy accents.

Combat is also pretty janky. Some hits feel like they should land but don't. Your character is also stiffer than the corpses so it leads to many unnecessary hits being taken. Animations are also hilariously bad, like what the hell?

This game aged poorly and Dying Light is better as a game period but I prefer the setting and aesthetic of this one. I wish it were polished more. This "Definitive Edition" would've been amazing if there were lengths taken to tidy up all the jank and maybe add in a parkour system similar to Dying Light; at least one that lets you climb on shit. I know it's unrealistic for Average Joes to be doing all these insane leaps and whatnot but this whole game is inherently unrealistic, so it wouldn't hurt to make a more fluid movement system. I'm bad at ratings so I'd say this is like, a 7/10. A dated game for sure that's a little behind on the times anyway but quite enjoyable for what it offers.

Dead Island is a fantastic open-world zombie-survival horror game set on a tropical island with simple RPG elements like crafting and skill-based character growth. The story is god-awful and poorly told through cut-scenes and cringe-worthy dialogue, but the combat itself is what sets this game above and beyond the competition. Slicing, stomping, kicking, and blasting walkers never gets old, and you'll be doing a lot of it. 

The definitive edition fixes some glitches from the original and looks and runs like an absolute dream with almost non-existent loading times. Recommended to anyone looking for solid, slow-paced hack-n-slash combat who doesn't mind shitty driving mechanics and retreading their route to complete missions.

This is an enjoyable first-person action game with Zombies in an open world. The wonderful setting is fitting and atmospheric. In my playtime it ran without any crashes under Linux with Proton 6.3-8. Aside from a few graphical glitches like weird looking glass surfaces and sometimes strange lighting the graphics are quite good looking. There are 4 characters to choose from for the main campaign. Each one mixes up the core melee combat gameplay loop a bit with their skill trees. Even though the story is a bit predictable and the voice acting is goofy, I would recommend this game if you like first person action and Zombies in your games.

Dead Island: Definitive Edition is a classic zombie game with intuitive mechanics. Kick. Slash. Run. Repeat.
It's nothing new especially for those who have a fair share of experience on the genre. The story is bland and fails miserably to make me take it seriously. If I had played the game upon release, I probably would have enjoyed it better. Another downside is I didn't have anyone to play with since most of my friends had finished it ages ago, so I didn't get to experience the co-op aspect all that much. Just get it on sale and kill those zombies alone if you are still interested.

Dead Island Definitive Edition is an action role-playing game developed by Techland and published by Deep Silver. Released for Linux, Microsoft Windows, OS X, PlayStation 3 and Xbox 360, the game is centered on the challenge of surviving a zombie-infested open world with a major emphasis on melee combat. The plot focuses on four playable survivors trying to survive and escape off the fictional island of Banoi.

🕘 Release Date: 31 May, 2016 
💯Game Size: 9.78 GB
✔ Decent PC Specs [Suitable For Low End Gamers]
✞ Recommended To Play with Friends, Solo Play Can Be Boring Sometimes

 [h1] THE STORY [/h1]

4 people from four different backgrounds find themselves on Banoi Island. An island country inspired by Papua New Guinea. When the outbreak begins by unknown methods those 4 people find themselves to be immune to the virus and they band together hoping for a way off the island.

ONLY BUY THIS GAME IF IT IS UNDER $10. 
This game is worth around 3 hours of fun if you have a friend to play with. I picked it up on sale because I remember playing it on the Xbox 360 when I was a wee lad, and I’m delighted to report it’s still a terribly buggy and broken video game. Don’t get me wrong, I love this game. It’s just terrible. 
Beyond the aforementioned 3 hours of fun laughing at how terrible the game is, you may have some fun with a save editor making terribly overpowered weapons. After that, fortunately, there isn't much more to the game. Again, I adore this game for how stupid it is and how god damn BRIGHT it is for NO reason. If this game is on sale, pick it up with a friend. Otherwise, pass.

I played the game when it released on the 360. I did not finish it and I finally came around to beating the game 11 years later.

I've noticed two things: 1 - The game shows its age and it has weird FPS drops and its noticeable even with V-Sync. Nothing game breaking but it is showing its age and how the game could use some more optimizations. 2 - You can see how this game inspired Dying Light. Its core elements are there.

I completed the main story and explored most of the game areas. The game includes a lot of references to pop culture and also plays on a lot of Zombie-Content stereotypes. The story is simple to understand yet familiar in the sense that it follows cliche zombie story. Its fun nonetheless.

If you are like me and picked up the game after playing Dying Light 2, it might be worth your time. If you get frustrated with clunky mechanics, then I would recommend watching a play-through on YT if you want to see the story and not deal with the quirks.

Played the original on PS3. Loved it the whole way through. Played this multiple times on PS4 and now on PC. Glitches happen, but not that often. Yet they are the sour cherry on top of the issues I have with this version.

1. Unnecessary changes to models - Normally I wouldn't give a damn about visual stuff, but there's enough symmetry going on with character models to make the developers behind the From Dusk Til Dawn game blush. Have you SEEN the back of Sam B's shirt?! And Jin constantly looks like she bathes in lotion.
2. Weapon mods with distinct visual designs replaced by generic Unity-tier assets - Find a photo of the original Phoenix axe mod, then find one in DE or make one. It's literally just a basic 3D fire effect you can get for free from anywhere now.
3. Rare yet extreme glitches - My friend especially encountered two instances, where in one, he continued his file and spawned miles above where he saved last. Another, he was just exploring around the jungles when it started lagging suddenly, then loaded a bunch of stuff, and the game thought he threw his weapon away, out of bounds. I have yet to encounter anything that wild, but I can believe it considering the closest I've come is getting stuck in the ground and being unable to get revived by my friend, or dropping items and being unable to retrieve them because... who even knows.

Buy this at your own risk, preferrably on heavy discount. Even more preferrably, track down a copy of the original version (AKA non-Definitive Edition). Get multiples. It's worth playing with friends that way, especially over LAN if you can manage. But this version is ANYTHING but "definitive".

The game is fun, but the port is so utterly terrible that I am having a terrible time actually playing it. It's a game where you're encouraged to make headshots (I mean, zombies), but you aren't allowed to aim at the head. There is a non-optional auto-aim that locks on to the torso. The best you can do is wait for the lock-on, then move your mouse up before you throw, but once the game is locked on, you lose your crosshair. That means you're aiming blind.

And I'm playing Logan, the thrower. He specializes in throwing knives and knife-like accessories. When you throw a weapon, it auto-equips the next weapon for you. The problem is that the game doesn't give them to you in equipped order (If you throw slot 1, it doesn't switch to slot 2 next.) Instead, it uses some screwy-ass logic that, if your quick bar isn't full, switches to your strongest weapon. And since you're throwing your weapons, your bar is almost never full. That means that if (as is the case with me), your second or third strongest weapon is your melee weapon you keep in reserve for when you run out of knives, you will throw one knife, then switch to your melee weapon. Every time. That means that you have to fire once, then manually open the wheel to switch weapons, then fire once, then switch, then fire once, etc. If you're faced with a bunch of zombies, you invariably end up throwing your backup melee weapon at them, leaving you helpless.

And when you're done, you have to scour the entire battlefield to find your weapons, one by one, before you can continue.

For such a fun game, these godawful design choices have absolutely ruined the fun for me.

It was fun beating, slashing, punching, shooting, burning, shocking and blowing up zombies while it lasted but now, after having beaten this game, everything has become so... boring even after I change to a new character.

I do not know where to start from...

I guess I will start with the story.

[h1] THE STORY [/h1]

Without giving any spoilers, you basically start of as an immune survivor. (A cliche that has been used way too many times by now.) And of course, people want to use you as you are the only immune person around. NO ONE in this game will EVER do something for you before you go around and kill some zombies for them. This gets so annoying after about 10-5 hours because you need to walk about 300 meters to kill 30 zombies and grab some thing and come back just to progress through the game. Yes, side quests are mandatory if you want to finish the game's story. Not like 100% or anything, just the story itself.

Some people might like this, but for me it gets exhaustingly overwhelming after some time. Since every quest basically asks for the same thing but on different locations and with different enemies. You go grab/do some stuff then return back to the mission giver. (No variety, at least I don't recall any fun side quests.)

Main quests are actually fun, except for when they aren't.

Later in the game, the main quests start to have same objectives as the side quests. Go grab this for me/escort me to here etc.

Also some of the quests actually force you to do side quests as I've said. "Go around the [Location] and help people." At the start doing one quest is enough and it doesn't really get overwhelming. But to the end it's just like this:

[i] You do a main quest, then you need to do 2-3 side quests to do an another main quest. [/i]

Do this about 5 times and then you move on out of that location.

I feel like I could go on, but I should move to the other aspects of this game.

[h1] THE GAMEPLAY [/h1]

The mechanics are overrall pretty good, the combat is pretty fun until it starts to become overwhelming. You can only use one type of melee weapon, and that is the one your character specialises in. Blades, blunts and so on. Though, you can use other categories of weapons but you won't get any bonuses because that isn't your character's weapon type. So it will attack really slow and get you exhausted really quickly. Talking about exhaustion, each time you perform an attack move, your stamina goes down and eventually it will empty. This is a good mechanic, this isn't what's so bugging about the combat or the game in general.

Aside from using the weapons that the game gives you, you can also add modifications to these weapons. It can range from burning the enemy to just increasing the weapon's DPS. This also allows you to create explosives and/or baits. 

Then you have the zombies. Because, well, it's a zombie game. If you are going to have a zombie game your zombies must be having good AI and are fun to fight against, right? I guess the developers though the answer is no because that's certainly how they implemented it to the game.

The zombies get stuck in places, they always follow you and there's about no way to run away from them without killing them all. (Except for the walkers, they move rather slowly.) I am not going to rant about how hard they are to kill, they aren't. It all requires skill. It's more so that they can hit you from far away and while you are running away from them. They can also kill you while you are climbing a ladder, which is infuriating sometimes. 

Then you got the special enemies. The game gives you no hint on how to fight them, except for the exploding one as it shows a cutscene of it exploding. Some of them are impossible to run away from. I personally don't like stopping every 2 minutes to fight a zombie so I tend to run away. But with some of these enemies that is not possible.

It's not that they have a lot of health and hit really hard. They just aren't fun to fight against. 

The thug (Some buff zombie) has a lot of health and knocks you out every time it hits you. Though, it moves pretty slow. Fighting it, though. It's pretty annoying.

Since it knocks you over everytime it hits you, you need to not get hit at all. That is achieved by jumping away every time you hit it. Do this in about every 10 minutes or so and you get bored quickly. As some of these guys aren't avoidable at all.  He also has a lot of health so you need to hit him like 10 times. 

The Ram, basically the stronger version of thug which has about 10 times more HP, is basically bulletproof, and run faster than anything else in the game, is even worse. 

You can kind of avoid this guy except for when you can't. You are forced you to kill him about a few times in the game. He runs slowly until he starts charging at you, so that's good.

Combine these enemies with constantly spawning zombies who never leave you alone in anywhere you go, and you got the streets, the beaches, and the jungles of banoi.

[h1] THE ENVIRONMENT [/h1]

The game is set on Banoi, a fictional island that is located in the Papa New Guinean islands, located south of equator, north of Australia. 

It is a good place, though since it's crawling with zombies it's basically hell.

The map is pretty good, there has been put a lot of effort into the environment of banoi. As this is not a real place I can't really compare it to it's nonexistent counterpart. But I guess I could say it certainly does fit the theme of pacific islands. With all the jungle and the exotic beaches. 

[h1] LEVEL DESIGN [/h1] 

Unfortunately, the level design can range from good to mediocre.

Usually it's just big open spaces, but indoors always crawl with zombies. Usually they are just full of zombies, a few weapons and or ammunition. Then after the room of zombies, there are always health pickups. This can go for outdoors as well, instead of rooms it's just sections. 

This repetitive design gets boring and overwhelming like everything else I've talked about so far. The combat, the story, the enemies and so on.

[h1] TRANSPORTATION [/h1]

The game actually allows you to quick travel between key locations. And [u] mostly [/u] you will have a car parked by these locations so you can travel easier. (Some locations just don't have cars so you need to walk.)

These cars are pretty fun to drive, I honestly feel like this game has better driving mechanics than gun mechanics. The cars have smooth controls and handle pretty well. They can also run over zombies, which will insta-kill them no matter what type of a zombie they are. (Use this to kill buff enemies.)


[h1] EXTRAS [/h1]

This game also has a co-op mode but I can't say much about it because my friends don't want to play with me.

I won't be talking about the graphics because I played at the absolute lowest, though I still doubt that there being giant square particles is due to low graphic settings.

I haven't experienced many bugs besides of zombies getting stuck like once or twice. Nothing game breaking. This game also works with the Dying Light engine so you will need DirectX11 or higher.

Quest givers literally yelling at me for 5 minutes pissed me off so early in the game. I take a quest from them, and before I leave to complete it, they ask if I have done what they wanted. And if I just ignore them, they will try to gain my attention by chatting about random stuff everytime I walk by them. An icon on their chest and a blip on the map is not enough apparently.

[h1] CONCLUSION [/h1]

This game is pretty mediocre. Though it is not THAT bad. I'd say you should buy this and riptide while they are on a sale.

This is my personal experience of the game, so I suggest that you read more reviews if you are really unsure.

[spoiler] Thank you so much for reading until the end. I hope you have a great day. [/spoiler]

Great game. Bad Definitive Edition. Weird community.

[u]First, about the game itself. [/u]It's 10 years old. But it still looks great, plays great and sounds great. I played original version a lot on release. And after so many years I launched it again after playing Dying Light 1 and was pleasantly surprised by it's quality - it's still cool. There is no parkour but that's not a bid loss. 15 minutes in and it was already hard to stop.

Key aspects of this game are setting and gameplay. What can be better, than brutally smashing zombie heads on the paradise island? And the scenery - scenery looks simply breathtakingly. I should also specifically mention music. Years ago I somehow didn't pay much attention to it, but today I can clearly state that it's great indeed.

Compared to DL, here you have 4 different characters to choose. And man, their playstyle differs significantly. At first I didn't pay much attention to this aspect. Years ago I played orignal as Purna, Riptide as Purna, and recently I played this version as well... as Purna. And at first I kinda thought that probably I'm fed up with the game for now. But than I checked other characters and simply rediscovered the game again for myself. It's really interesting to check different character. So if you are going to play, make sure to check at least 2 of them.

[u]Now let's talk about Downgrade Edition[/u]. Yeah, basically it's just a downgraded version of the original. Sure, there are some improvements, but I can't call them improvements as such. For example, there are some sporadical improvements of lighting and shadows. But such improvements often ruin initial concep rather than improve. 

Let's say, there is a scene in a Lifeguard Tower, where some huge zombie is eating up his poor victim. [b] Before[/b], this location was rather dark and had some weak and flickering lighting. Zombie had more sinister look as well and the whole scene was more spooky. [b] After[/b] they "improved" shadows and lighting - this location looks bright like some ballroom. And zombie looks so pale like some aristocratic lady from Middle Ages. Clearly these "improvements" were added just for the sake of improvements, simply to justify existence of this Downfall Edition. 

And that's not all. What's even more important - in the Defective Edition they carefully saved all bugs from the original and even added new ones! For example, chests in this game always contain some weapons. After you reenter certain location or reload the game - it's content should be refreshed. The problem is, lots of these chests are bugged forever: once you retrieveded some weapon from it, you won't find here anything ever again.

Bugged quest with Nikolai for example. I played it 5 times and 4 times I had a bug when Nikolay decides to go back to initial location after he almost reached final destination. Once he decided to go back twice! That's not critical but still annoying. If you meet zombies who are turnt back to you, almost in 100% cases they will run away from you right into the wall or even through the texture. In prison some guards are stuck in the wall, so you can see only their hands. And also the ball...  that damn ball... You can't kick the damn ball anymore! I know it's not a big deal, but still. Was it some complicated alien technology from 2011, so it is not awailable for developers anymore?

In the end, if you never played original game... I still recommend you to get this Disgrace Edition. Why? Because it's still that cool Dead Island in the core. And it's still very fun to play. If you never played original, chances are you'll never consider abovementioned problems as such.

[u]Now my favourite part - local community.[/u] And it's hard to call it sane. But I can already see your scepticism. Fair enough: you don't know me, you can't fully trust me. What if I'm just one toxic dude, who is blatantly slandering these fairy and innocent people? Come closer - I have little something to prove my words.

You see, just like many games on Steam, Dead Island also has achievements. And ve-e-ery rare ones as well. You are probably guessing right now what can it be? Maybe to kill hundred of zombies with bare hands? Hm... maybe to kill a final 100 lvl boss with 1 lvl weapon? Ah, maybe to survive 50 waves on arena, something like that, right? Ha! - wrong! One of the hardest achievements in this game is... to play 15 minutes with 10 random people. 15 damn minutes. With 10 random people.

Only 5,5% managed to finish Darkest dungeon. Only 3,2% managed to finish 5th pantheon in Hollow Knight. But little did they know that the hardest challenge is hidden here, because only mere 1.4% managed to spend pathetic 15 minutes with 10 random people. I mean "People person" achievement. You may check it. Just imagine this situation. Why it is so? Well, because the moment you try to join some public game - you will either be kicked in 5-10 seconds wtihout any reasons, or everyone will immediately rq the session. Yes, let me repeat it once more - it's year 2022 A.D. and people kick you from public game... for joining public game.

Keep in mind, the game is very generous with it's options. It lets you to make your game public, friends-only or even private. But it seems like such technologies are too complicated for these urban neanderthals, and they like to waste your time. The moment you join their game - everyone freeze in horror, as if you sneaked into their bedroom. They even stop fighting zombies and start convulsively communicate how to kick... ehm... intruder asap.

Nevertheless, for me it is also not a reason to ruin game's rating. I'm an old hag with saggy tits - meeting lunatics and sociopaths online is not something that could shock me. But it may be an issue for you and potentially ruin your experience. This is why, if you want to play coop - check Steam forum first. It has enough good guys or even entire group of people willing to help you.

Now let's make some conclusions. If you own original game, you really don't need this Disappointment Edition. But keep in mind, if your friends have this version and you have original - you can't play together. If you are a newcomer or only played Dying Light before - I still highly recommend to get even this Dishonored Edition because it still kicks. And if you plan to play coop - finding some good friends is not a recommendation, but a necessity.

If this 2011, the year when the game came out and in a world we’re dying light didn’t exist (yes I know they are the same developers and my god want an improvement) then I absolutely would’ve had more fun with this game. 

I always wanted to play this growing up but being a wee little lad when it came out I wasn’t allowed, but it always peeled my interest.

The Good

-Gore holds up incredibly well, as you chop off limb after limb until they die

-RPG mechanics, really enjoyed constantly leveling and getting new stuff no matter where I was in the game

-The Resort, Morsbey, and the jungle (start of act 3) amazing locations, varying in variety

-Character classes, above all else this is easily the best thing in the game, it’s actually fun to level up a character and use the skill tree and personalize the class to your play style

-New Game, Thank god that even after you beat the game you can keep going and make your character more badass

-weapons, all the melee weapons and even the guns are awesome

The Bad

- Solo play PLAY CO-OP AT ALL COST, I played this solo (all of my friends were playing dying light 2 at the time like I should’ve been) and my god it was so boring, game would’ve became 1000x better in co-op, the way it was intended to be played

-Amount of Zombies, if this was 2011 as previously stated this wouldn’t be a problem since we wouldn’t have known what the future holds, but the lack of zombies is kinda astounding 

-Guns, yea having aim assist on pc is the stupidest thing you could ever do 

-repairs, too much money for repairs since you’re  always breaking weapons

-story, wake up, non infected, get off island before monsoon rolls in ( story really isn’t that big a deal in a zombie game it’s a very minor complaint though)

-Halfway point of the game, after the act 3 opening when you obtain the boat, it becomes very apparent that Deep Silver rushed techland and didn’t give them enough funds to flesh out this last part of the game. Deep Silver is a complete joke for this and I still despise them for their shitty practices to this day

-Quest, go to x, grab y, then return it at, rinse and repeat

-movement, I didn’t expect the movement and just controls in general to be clunky as hell


Overall: 5.5/10

If played with friends: 7/10

I’d still recommend this because techland is great, and the foundation for a great RPG is thankfully in the game, Deep Silver on the other hand go suck a fat one

+ this game paved way to dying light so it is important.
- it is not dying light
- 1-2 act too long. it should have ended earlier. I have seen all long before the ending after that everything repeats unfortunetly.
Loads of content to play and explore, aswell as fun multiplayer, as well as side-quests.

As for the Original version of the game which has unfortunately been removed from the store: I recommend it. I have a lot of hours on the PS3 version and loved it, despite its numerous flaws. It still holds up as a solid game.

Do not buy Definitive Edition if you want a decent experience. If you can get a hold of the original, play that. Definitive Edition is a vastly inferior experience to the original game. Not only does it contain MORE bugs than the already buggy original, it seems to have appears it may have inherited the Dead Island: Riptide version of the engine, bringing even more bugs to the game. I absolutely hated Riptide and thought it was a serious downgrade to the series. Every single glitch I have encountered in the original game is still present in this version. I will be listing my observations.

The game looks good... sometimes. The contrast is incredibly messed up, making looking out from cars blinding, and interiors are pitch black. The new textures and high resolution are nice, but that hardly makes up for the problems with the game. If I recall correctly, I couldn't turn down the fullscreen resolution from 4k, so this game heated up my PC a lot.

Some characters, such as the security guard you need to look for in the hotel, have had models changed. He used to be black, now he's just a generic white guy.

The collisions on characters are messed up. Rams have collisions that make it hard to hit when using brass knuckles, and their reaction time is very slow now. They used to kick you as soon as they turned around, now they spend a few seconds standing there before attempting to kick.

The audio for many things is not synced up properly. The final level of curb stomp plays the sound at least 6 frames before the actual impact.

I have died at least 5 times by being placed in a wall or floor by the game. It may have happened once ever when playing the original, but right after Mike's cutscene when you bring him the gas, I was killed by being shoved in the floor. Then that happened frequently near the end of the game.

The Floaters used to pop when you killed them, changing to a model where their guts are spilled out. There is no new model for that, so they don't pop anymore.

Water in the sewers is the worst video game water I have ever seen. Its just a translucent turquoise plane, with water splashes that look like glitter.

Human enemies can't have their heads exploded like they used to. Another circumstance where a new model was not created.

You still cannot create custom binds for controllers. There is still only the outdated system of presets.

TL;DR
If you can find an original version of the game, play that. This version of the game is absolutely rancid and is the worst way to play it. Any minor improvements (such as graphics) are massively outweighed by the lack of bugfixing, and wave of new bugs brought into the game. This definitive edition must've been what Rockstar looked to for inspiration for their recent abomination.

A very nice remaster, you can feel the classic background and pace of days gone by, all with a really perfect graphic upgrade.
Scary monsters and hot girls with a great English soundtrack. I'm still at the beginning, but I don't think that major negative experiences will spoil this fun game.
One must perhaps mention the very well-functioning cooperative multiplayer mode. The interaction with several Steam friends is problem-free and the automatic saving of the scores and playing with different players with different progress is possible without the feared errors.
I'm just positively surprised, the game does much more than expected, the character development is "funny" and invites you to try a new game with a different character later.

This game has it's flaws. City is were the game gets so hard COOP play is need. You can get knocked of your shoes when stamina is empty or a big foe attacks you. Dying removes 25% or similar of your money and cheat engine is needed to get enough to enjoy mid game hell cause difficulty is super high alone. Enemies are scary due to good weapon and attack impact. Game has it's rules and physics established and will not break any. For a B-tier game it is really good. Dying Light 1 increased scarcity of resources and made hiding and running more important. Both games are traditional games in the year 2022. No big markers and only on minimap you'll see ? and !. Also NPCs will visibly tell you they need help.

In Dying Light 2, finding missions, NPCs, secrets.... are all marked on the big map when roaming around. No additional information and a failure of the whole gaming industry. A new low compared to the FREEDOM of Breath Of The Wild where you get no help except in hidden tricks and tips by cleaver programming and story telling. Also Dead Island has no forced press F to continue chatting to NPCs and no press Space to skip force door opening animations and squeezing through cracks in walls.

This game is now a 8/10. Dead Rising 1-2 a 10/10. Stalker SoC 9/10, Modded Stalker: Anomaly 10/10, Dishonoured  1 10/10. Prey 2016 11/10. Thief 1 and 3 9/10, Valheim 12/10, GTA till 4 9.5/10

I have mixed feeling on this game having played the original (no longer available).
The game play is still solid, missions are fun and you get to kill zombies, the game plays better as a co-op but totally fine solo also. 

Positives:
- Graphics are stunning, good quality water, blood and other stuff
- Missions are generally engaging
- Easy levelling 
- Adaptive Combat system
- Fun weapons and mods
- Not stuck with the usual american setting and accents
- Plenty of gore, blood and fun death animations for zombies

Negatives:
- They seem to have removed a lot of the expolarable buildings and easter eggs
- Movement can feel a bit laggy
- Can no longer kick the balls
- Co-op settings are limited and can be a bit weird
- When playing co-op it will not save your quests unless you are the host (but you will keep levels/items) which means same person must host always
- In Co-op it sometimes railroads you into doing the main quest and won't let you track the side quests
- While pretty the island no longer has that grungy feel it used to

Look overall if you already have the original don't bother unless you want to play with a friend, even then see if they can source the original. 
Otherwise its still an enjoyable game and the storyline is quite interesting if you like to get into the lore of things.

If you plan on only playing one zombie game this year, this is not that one game. Dying Light and Days Gone are far better games in just about every way. But if you have already played those games and really like a little mindless zombie bashing, this game is not bad. It just isn't great. 

As you would expect from an average game, this game has a lot of good points and bad points. Since I am giving this a thumbs up, let's start with the good stuff. There is plenty of loot. The game map is fairly large. Eventually you can drive vehicles over the walking dead. Driving over the walking dead. Fun. The game has a crafting system as well as a perk tree so you can build weapons and characters as you see fit. And your kills earn you points towards challenges. I am not sure what you get when you complete a challenge, but they are there nonetheless. 

The negative are as plentiful as the zombies. Unless you really enjoy combing beaches or ransacking vacation cabins, the game world is boring. Some of the game mechanics leave a lot to be desired. Melee weapons are plentiful, but break after less than a dozen uses. Saves are via a checkpoint system. So if you have to leave your game to go play adult games with your little woman, expect to lose a dozen minutes or more. Spending time with the game's living characters is as fun as hanging out at the local bus depot. None offer you help. Most want to turn you into their gopher. And the quests...go fetch this. Go fetch that. Kill zombies over here. Kill zombies over there. 

Still, I found my time with the game mostly enjoyable. In a mindless kind of way. The game isn't really too hard so it can be a calming experience after a day dealing with the mindless idiots of the real world.

This is a good game for survival.  There are four ACTS (different settings) that are progressively harder.  There is a wide variety of weapons available as the game progresses.  I have completed this game once, other tries 1/2 to 3/4 completed.  Each try was different as to difficulty.  The end of the game is very hard, or at least I thought until the last game played, going all over a town turning on speakers, the zombies kept coming, they would not stop, can not tell you how many times I died.  Be aware of the guys in straight jackets, it takes bombs to kill him, and he does not like to stand still, also there can be three, one after the other.  If you want a good, long, and frustrating game, this is it.  
The biggest drawback, besides dying allot, is the uncalled for language.  I am an ex-marine and the most I have ever cussed was playing this game.  Good luck.
12-20-21  There are problems and glitches in this game, but the game came out in 2016 so fixes will not be coming.  It is to bad the gamer can not save when they want to, this would help when there is a glitch.  When there is a glitch and you load last check point, the glitch is still there. If you load a particular act, the gamer looses the advancements, resulting in starting the game from scratch.  Two of the glitches are; some times gas cans and juice boxes can not be placed in the high lighted spaces. Some times items can not be picked up such as I.D. cards.  
This is a complicated game to make and would be my favorite game if it were not for the comments above.

It's a decent game, but has a lot of flaws. Let me name a few:

Driving is horrendous. When you first start the car and hold left or right, often it just goes straight. So you have to go forward (or backwards which means you turn the engine on) a little bit until you can turn. This can be annoying in certain scenarios. Also the terrain/maps have so many weird spots that can get you stuck. This may not be the case in he first act, but later on you can notice it a lot. For example in the second act in town (with the church), when you finally get the base with the car, it's literally trapped inside that base. A bunch of containers and other stuff blocks you from leaving and even if you do manage to leave somehow, the entire city has a bunch of crap on the streets which makes it pointless to go by car. Might as well just fast travel.

Combat is clunky. Sometimes you hit the zombies dead on and it doesn't register. On top of that the modifications are kinda pathetic. You would think after you modify your machete with fire, each and every zombie you hit will burn but that is not the case. It's pretty much random and doesn't happen a lot at all. Also throwing weapons can sometimes just make them disappear or get stuck in some wall.

Copy and pasted missions that waste your time. For example in the first act there is a guy who can make molotovs, but you need to bring him 5 alcohol bottles. You only get one molotov and shortly later on you meet another guy who makes them for three bottles of alcohol. Then you have the dude who needs food and barely gives you any exp or money. These kind of mission are never-ending and a total waste of time.

Guns feel extremly weak against higher level zombies. Even the regular ones need a bunch of bullets, but the big guys usually only take 1dmg. Even when modified you need to be lucky to set them on fire or shock them. I have to waste my entire bullet stash to kill one of those fat spitters with an assault rifle. Headshots sometimes do more damage, but it also seems random. 


Well, enough ranting. I'm sure there is more stuff I'll notice that bothers me, but overall I can recommend this game if it's on sale. It's still a lot of fun and if you just want to smash some zombies, it's pretty decent.

Never played Dying Light, so no frame of reference here. All of my issues with the game are also mostly present in the original non-remastered version.
What I hate in any game is animation p*rn i.e. animations that are overly realistic and/or too long for no reason and hinder the gameplay. In Dead Island there is a ton of them e.g. getting up after being knocked down, healing (this one actually got me killed several times), throwing (Molotovs and grenades), climbing ladders, picking up weapons, eating food, leaving and entering cars. Mind you, in Definitive Edition this has been toned down, but the stuff that remains is still annoying. There are also other quirks like climbing up steeper stairs also takes really long, your character has a short start up before running at full speed etc., but these are more physics based.
Other small nuisances include sometimes not being able to turn 1-2 seconds after starting the car or using the quick heal button which uses up Large Medkits first, before the Medium ones, completely backwards to what is the standard in other games.
Throw damage is insane on both the player's, and enemies', sides. So much so that generic Walkers with butter knives are infinitely more dangerous than boss enemies like Thugs, Butchers, or Rams, since none of these can literally ONE SHOT you from range. On any character, even Sam B, who is the tankiest of them all.

The game is surprisingly serious and includes stuff like implied r*pe, however it juxtaposes it with silly gameplay mechanics with challenge names like Ya Really referencing an age old meme or Sam B's character in its entirety. They do not mesh that well. No wonder Techland went with the fully serious approach in Dying Light. The only other way it could have gotten, is Dead Rising levels of humor.

What I do like:
The fact that headshotting humans even with the most crappy guns kills them instantly, unless they are boss characters.
Easiest collectible achievement and challenge I think I have ever done in a game with so many of them i.e. well over 100.
What I do love in the Definitive Edition, are the near instant loading screens, even between maps. The original had very long load times, even on good hardware, so this is a huge improvement.

Most importantly, the game is just a lot of fun, despite all of the mentioned jank, and is well worth the money.

I've heard Dead Island compared to Dying Light quite a bit in the past. There is this idea that Dead Island is Dying Light with a less complex system of combat and none of the platforming mechanics but I found it more like a Skyrim mod with zombies and a more modern setting. Just like I've always disliked archery and horse back riding in Skyrim because of its clunkiness I am equally dissatisfied with Dead Island's terrible gun battles and car driving mechanics which don't allow a third person view. If you've ever played Skyrim the combat is very similar with a few design departures to keep things fresh; the awesome weapon throwing mechanic and the fact that it normally takes one hit to kill an enemy and only takes a couple for an enemy to kill you. This makes combat both desperate and quick with a high emphasis on avoiding fights where possible, healing often, and generally being very careful when moving through the game world. Combat is no nonsense in Dead Island with each mistake being punished severely and I love this combat system it made me want to play more despite the incredible repetition of fighting through endless respawning enemies on the map. This games worst fault is platforming. Platforming in Dead Island is a thankless chore and while I don't think Dead Island should necessarily be compared to Dying Light I can't help but make that comparison when it comes to platforming because Dying Light's platforming is also first person but also a million times better. Another complaint would be that despite Dead Island being a horror game it doesn't feel like one nor does it act like one. It's closer to an action movie that is about a zombie apocalypse, don't go into this game expecting to get scared. Invisible walls really bother me in open world games especially ones that come out of nowhere with no explanation or a platform that looks like it can be jumped on but some invisible force stops you just before you can land and pushes you off. There are a ton of these invisible barriers in dead Island and it turns your open world gaming experience into an open world except whenever the game decides it isn't sort of experience. Despite my gripes and complaints I beat the game, thoroughly enjoyed it, and I bought it on sale for less than 10 dollars. Totally worth it.

MOTION SICKNESS WARNING. THIS GAME MAY CAUSE YOU TO THROW UP.

This is a warning I'm wishing I saw before I bought this edition of the game. I'm a first person Veteran. I have never gotten sick playing Half-Life, Apex Legends, or even VR Games. I've played countless games that have been known to cause motion sickness, but none of them have been on the level of this game.

It can't be me right? I've never had motion sickness before? That's how I felt, so I went scouring over on the internet and found old forum posts and threads of people getting motion sickness. It was usually either VR players, but then you would see Dead Island listed as one of the games that would cause people to throw up.

I tried a bunch of fixes from people screaming at me, telling me it's my fault, or that I didn't soldier on. I turned off Motion Blur, I turned off Chromatic Abberation, and I even widened the FOV as much as I could without breaking the game.T urns out there's an insane amount of Head Bobbing included with the game. Walking? Camera sway. Running? Camera bounce. Swinging your weapon? Camera jumps.

The camera motion cannot be modded out at this moment unfortunately. So as of this post, there's still no way to remove this head motion. On top of this I believe there are other issues with the way the game is rendered that adds to the jarring feeling, There's frame pacing issues, random stutters, and there's even input delay if you're using a mouse and keyboard. These are problems I've seen cause motion sickness in VR.

The Original Dead Island was a fun bit of mess I played back in the day, but it was removed from the store front to force people to buy this "Definitive Edition". I bought it to mess around with some friends just for the nostalgia, but I threw up today and powered through just to get my money's worth. Now if you have no attachments to this game, I wouldn't recommend that you touch it with a ten foot pole. There are bugs in here that weren't present in the original game. (Invisible walls, collisions with AI waypoints that you run into as a player for some reason, random deaths, untriggerable quest points???) But if you feel like these are things you can get over, the game is still the same fun mess it was, and the quests will give you a lot to do. Just don't play this game "for the story" because the story is a big fat mess as well.

Dead Island Definitive Edition (2011)

Dead island -  a lovely island paradise gone very, very wrong. You pick one of four characters to play as:

Sam B - The "tanky", lots of health blunt weapon expert who's job it is to keep surviving hits for the team and to make clearings open with his rage ability that knocks down zombies. Sam B focus on crowd control with his abilities.

Xian Mei - The "assassin" who focuses on bladed weapons and has a lot of stamina to keep attacking. Her fury ability attacks enemies with a short knife in a blinding frenzy of stabs and slashes. Her damage offset is that she has the lowest health of all the characters and can thus die easily if not careful.

Logan Carter - The "Jack of all trades" class who likes to fight with throwing weapons. His fury is unlimited throw weapons for a shot duration. His skills focus on damage, survival and throwing weapon retrieval. Just be careful as you can loose an extremely powerful weapon by throwing it at the enemy only for it to disappear. 

Purna Jackson - The "support" class who focuses on firearms. Her rage ability is a gun with unlimited ammo for a short duration. As it says on the tin, just focus on her firearm abilities and peel off zombies that pin down allies in tricky situations. Only negative she is has is firearms are rare and ammo even more so.

The overall story is broken down into 4 acts (a total of 16 chapters) with new game + once you complete it. The level cap is level 50. The gameplay is solid, you hack, slash and shoot zombies in a first person perspective. You complete quests for people who reward you with loot and better weapons. Your weapons can break so keep them in good conditions or els you might run into problems. You can craft special weapons with unique properties such as lightning damage that can shock zombies (and yourself if your not careful) or bleeding damage. Lots of unique crafts to look out for. The setting is good as all four acts have a unique location. Only the last act for me felt a bit rushed as many of the content just feels like timesink fillers at the end. The overall story is fun enough, but when it comes to killing zombies, people don't care too much.

There are still some bugs persisting today as the game doesn't receive any new updates but you should still be able to complete the game. Multiplayer is non exisiting as people went over to Dying Light. If you can get the game to work with a friend, its lots of fun for many hours. You can also look out for some collectables if you choose to do so. Graphical update and a much smoother gameplay experience is also in the updated version. 

8/10

Janky, buggy, clunky, poorly written, incredibly easy... and yet it's still a pretty good time. Melee-centric Zombie slaying in first person with map layouts and quest design clearly inspired by ARPGs such as Diablo. As we all know, Dying Light eventually did (quite literally) everything better, but the root of that addictive and fun gameplay loop is still here in Dead Island. Dead Island: Riptide is of course the better of the two games, but I suggest getting this one too if you can find them both on sale. Also, and it goes without saying, bringing a friend or three makes this game a blast. Not that I'd know, as I played through entirely solo.

[i]Entertaining but LOTS of annoying things, the worst one being that Deep Silver released a new incompatible update of the game and removed the previous version from the store, forcing us to buy their updated game in order to play with friends.[/i]

[b][u]THE GOOD[/u][/b]
[list]
[*]SOOOO satisfying to cut off limbs, throw large objects at zombies, run over zombies, kick zombies down for fall damage
[*]Level up new abilities can be fun, especially a few combo moves
[/list]

[b][u]THE BAD[/u][/b]
[list]
[*]Lazy spawning system: exactly the same zombies always spawn at the same place, gets repetitive
[*]Weapon durability is unrealistic and annoying, always spend too much time fixing weapons
[*]Lazy console port: clunky menu controls, especially equipping quick items, trading with other players, moving around feels floaty
[*]Guns feel so flimsy, sometimes 5-6 headshots to kill the bullet-sponge zombies
[*]Leveling up seems a bit pointless as zombies also level up and insta-kill you when throwing things
[*]Leveling up zombies makes fire/electricity/fall/drowning damage on them useless, which is fun at early stages
[/list]

[b][u]THE UGLY[/u][/b]
[list]
[*]Deep silver made us all buy the same game twice
[*]Lost all the DLCs I bought with the original game
[/list]

I felt like playing a game where you have to kill zombies and survive an zombie outbreak. Dead Island fullfilled this to some degree. What I loved about this game on the outset was the open world feel and the exploration. At one point, I was in a hotel waking up to an outbreak that happened overnight, the next I was on the beach slaughtering zombies and doing errands. However, the maps are diverse with a city, sewers and jungle to explore as well. The music in the game is fantastic and sets up the tone for the game. The gameplay is where it is at though! You can master many types of combat from melee to pistols and other weapons. On top of this you can modify your weapons to get more gruesome and epic kills in. The modding of weapons is diverse enough where eventually you will find a weapon you like and works for you which is amazing. 

Dead Island can also get repetitive as well at times. With familiar fetch quests and smashing the same button to kill zombies. For this reason, you can burn out easily. Luckily the main quest is not too long. 

Overall, Dead Island is a game you will either love or hate. For me I loved it and am excited to look into other Techland's projects.
