Janky but fun

originally played this on Xbox 360, it was fun on that console, but i found it hard to go back to, but when re-experiencing it on PC its a much more pleasant experience.

overall the game looks a lot less muddy than the Xbox and runs better. (the performance is dependent on what specs you have in your computer and the in game settings you have set)

i have all the settings cranked up as high as they will go, and set to my monitor's native resolution of 1920x1080 at 144hz.

the framerate maintains a steady 170 fps average with dips down to 154fps during certain situations.

there are still some problems in this version. but these were also in the Xbox 360 version as well.
these issues are as follows:

*abrupt pits that cannot be jumped out of or are difficult to get out of.

*throwing weapons near certain geometry and places causes them to go thru parts of the map.

*the auto save system is very Flawed/Broken and needs work. it often forgets to remember certain things i have completed.
---
the keyboard and mouse controls are nice to have especially when it comes to the gun play, and keeping compatibility with controllers is also very nice. i switch between both of them and i enjoy playing either way.

the vehicles are decently fun to drive but they get caught on a lot of geometry without explanation, things that look like a vehicle can clear it, are seemingly arbitrarily limited as to where you can drive your vehicle, the driving can come to a complete stop if you hit a railing on a long drive. or even slightly bump into it with the side of your vehicle. making 
traveling across the areas a lot more time consuming.

the missions feel just fine and are sometimes pretty fun, some are not so great but a good chunk of the missions are great to go thru.

there are some objectives that are always active, like fetch quests for specific items, these will give you money and xp and eventually level you up.

the upgrade system is very fun to mess around with and makes the games difficulty more easy to deal with as the zombie crowds get larger.

the voice lines for certain characters are shared across multiple npc's and can get very old. it allows you to skip voice lines. this also speeds up those continuing fetch quests.

i recommend this game for the mechanics of the game and also the awesome atmosphere. and because i just plain enjoy this game, i have yet to play dead island riptide because i wanna beat the first game before i move on.

It becomes a slog after the first act in the resort part of the island. Many of the side quests in the mid and late game are blantantly busy work. For example, in the second act, you have to run across a zombie-infested town to turn on four speakers. You then have to run all the way back to the quest giver, and they'll ask you go turn another four on. You run ALL the way across town and turn on another four and run ALL the way back to the quest giver. Then, they tell you there are a final three speakers. It could have just been one quest with eleven speakers, but they make you run back and forth and waste time. The enemy variety stagnates after act 2, and the gameplay in act 4 is largely the same as the gameplay in act 2, just with bigger level numbers above the zombies. The number of escort quests in act 3 is honestly rage-inducing, and I found myself not care AT ALL about the side characters.

Dead Island, no matter if Definitive Edition or not, is a complete mess of a game. 

It starts out okay enough: The beginning chapters in the island resort is a good way to introduce the mechanics, fight zombies, do a few quests and have some fun.
That completely goes down the drain in Act 2, one of the most boringly designed city levels I've ever seen in a zombie game. Furthermore, this Act suddenly ramps up the difficulty to a degree that it starts to annoy. And sadly, it never recovers from that part. In the final chapter I began running past groups of zombies because I only wanted it to end. Couldn't be bothered to fight any of them. 
Started to question how the mechanics work. The stamina system, regardless on how many point you invested into it, seems to work on its own set of rules. There is a crafting system, but you need so many ingredients, that it often becomes pointless. Also: Who came up with the idea to let your own status effects hurt you as well? 

Frequently I encountered zombies stuck in the environment, got crushed by a gas cylinder when I tried to throw it, got stuck myself. Bugs are plentiful.
Nobody is memorable in any way. Even the guy who is supposed to be the villain comes off as just another dude. Same goes for the story. Nothing interesting here.

Gonna need a loooooong break before I even consider starting Dead Island Riptide. This was a pain. No wonder I eventually just stopped playing when it first came out back in the day.

Perfect re-master of an already amazing zombie game. It is more of a first-person open world hack and slash than a shooter, and I love that about it. Even after completing it's amazing spiritual successor Dying Light, this game is still really enjoyable and this edition feels very polished. 

I finished the story mode and *most* of the side quests in about 15 hours and loved every second of it. Though I played the game almost entirely solo I love that they put in a co-op mode, I played with a friend a few times and had a blast!
With friends it can be fun. After a while, I think it gets boring, because you always do the same thing.

Dead Island: Definitive Edition is a remaster of the open-world, zombie action survival game made by Techland, who later makes a similar game, yet better-received Dying Light. I would describe the gameplay as a crossover of Left 4 Dead and Borderlands, because like L4D it's first-person, with you (or a team) fighting against numerous hordes of zombies. And like Borderlands, you choose one of the 4 characters, it's open-world, has vehicles, fast travel only from certain locations, and you lose money when you die, but not progress. And for the survival elements, you would have to constantly repair your melee weapons with money because they take damage after being used.

You will play as one of the zombie-immune survivors, as they try to help themselves and their friends from escaping the zombie-infested tourist spot Banoi Island, a fictional island located near Papua Nugini. Each character chosen will have slightly different abilities, but not really that distinct. You cannot change characters in one playthrough. The sad thing is that your chosen character will always be alone, but in the cutscenes the other 3 are always present. Would be cooler if they appear as AIs if you play without friends.

Story-wise, the game is... not so good. It's very generic, and for some reason I just cannot feel attachment or care about the characters, and the fact that many of them lack character depth and look similar doesn't help. Most quests are also just simple fetch quests, go here, get this item or kill this enemy, go back. Since fast travel is only available from very few areas and many places don't allow vehicle access, you'll end up running back and forth in many places while being chased by zombies.

This version contains the Ryder White's Campaign and Bloodbath Arena. Ryder White's story acts as a prequel and is started by choosing him in the character selection menu. You play as Australian soldier Ryder White, following his orders and trying to save his wife. Unlike the main game, his campaign is linear. However, there will be a lot more zombies, which would be very time and resource consuming to kill, so the best strategy is to run away when you can, and close the doors because they can't open doors. This DLC contains some spoilers for the final act, so keep that in mind if you wanna play this one first.

As for the Bloodbath Arena DLC, it is accessed from the fast travel map and is available from the start. You will be in a military bunker, and have access to 4 survival arenas. There is no extra story content here besides you meeting another group of survivors taking residence there. But it is recommended to start playing here after finishing the story once and starting New Game+, since you will be at a high enough level and have decent equipment to help tackle the enemies.

However, this game has a major issue with poor optimization. I have enough specs to run this game at high settings smoothly, but for some reason it performs very poorly and lags a lot, only getting 15-20 fps even after I lowered the graphics and resolution. The only way to get a decent framerate is by constantly plugging and unplugging my laptop charger, a fact I sadly learned when I'm nearing the end.

I would honestly give this game a mixed review, because despite the generic story, forgettable characters, repetitive quests, and very poor optimization, I still had some fun, and the first area, the Resort, is unique for me because I never seen any zombie story set in a beautiful beach resort in broad daylight. If you like L4D, Borderlands, or Dying Light you might enjoy Dead Island, but beware of the numerous issues this game has.

I bought this out of pure nostalgia but boy have I dived right back into it.

If you're looking for a zombie slasher/shoot em up this is the one for you. This game was ages ahead of it's time and Techland knew that. For me, I grew up (teenage years) playing this with a close friend from high school. Most of the school days after school were spent playing Dead Island on the 360 on coop. HOWEVER, solo is just as fun and worth it too.

PROS:
Custom weapons can be created with craft-able parts you find in the massive open world
The story line or campaign is timeless and a classic (no replay-ability however)
The combat system has been vastly improved

CONS:
Sometimes, you will spawn in with very low FPS so don't exitsave near a horde or a Ram, etc
The voice acting is still a bit cringy at times
The combat system with the specials isn't great but definitely still playable.

Overall, seeing this game gain some steam (no pun intended) especially in the shadow of the long awaited Dying Light sequel does my heart good. This game is a solid addition to your zombie game collection if you're an avid zombie fan like me. Definitely worth a buy. 9.5/10

Great open world zombie game with a pretty good story (with the dlc as added context). The combat loop is melee and guns, which is complemented by the skills you can unlock to gain certain finishers and generally improve your deadliness. Weapons, excluding guns, have a durability meter(which tbh is more annoying than anything), (now including guns) can be upgraded four times, and modified to have special affects(such as bleed, fire, lighting, etc). There are a multitude of minor bugs that rarely harm the experience, usually they are just funny to look at and then you can go on your way. (you can look at my recent screenshots for examples). Hit boxes in this game are either normal or terrible, both when interacting with items or prompts and you taking damage. As in sometimes I couldn't pick of items or put them in specific locations for a quest and when fighting zombies they will sometimes land throw or grab attacks even when they clearly missed. Additionally, the damage received from throw attacks do an insane amount of damage, which is cheap in the sense that the zombies that can throw their weapon do it before you can realize they have a weapon, they can do it off screen, they can hit you with a throw even with their back turned to you, and lastly even at level 50 I was still getting one shoted by their attacks. Other than these minor faults I recommend this game at full price or on sale, the experience it provides is well worth the price you pay.

-Edit Actually after playing it a second time this game isnt that good.
A-tier open world zombies experience

Definitely a game of its time and probably remembered more for the cinematic and disturbing trailer that was released. If you're looking for a co-op game, with zombies that is fun enough to lose a few hours in with your mates then you could do worse than Dead Island.

The graphics are dated by this point, but there are a couple of nice effects and there is enough variety in the environments to keep your interest. The large variety of weapons also helps to keeps things fresh; however, it is a shame that the weapon handling is sluggish and the less said about the gun combat the better as it often feels like an after-thought by the developers. There are a few different zombies that you will encounter throughout the game, but nothing too surprising or horrifying compared to other zombie games that are out there.

The storyline in the game is cliched and, for someone who loves well-written RPGs, is completely forgettable. The quests too can swing from fairly interesting to bland-go-there-fetch-this-bring-it-back-here quests.

Coming to this game really late, I have to also mention the elephant in the room which is Dying Light. I wholly recommend Dying Light over Dead Island if there was a choice. Dying Light does everything better than this game and you can see Dead Island as a stepping stone towards that.

So why in the world am I recommending Dead Island? Because despite the flaws, my brother and I had a good time playing through this game Co-op. I wouldn't touch this game if it was just single-player for all the detriments I've mentioned earlier; however, with a good buddy by your side this game can be much more enjoyable.

But if there was a choice - Dying Light over Dead Island hands down :)

This game was part of my childhood during the xbox 360 era, and tbh I always thought that this game was always better then dying light in terms of gameplay, story and character... until I played this game again with friends. This game imo has not aged very well and it becomes painfully obvious when you compare it to the spiritual successor of Dying Light (even though that game also had its issues).

Story
The story was just terrible LOL. Easily the most forgettable part of this whole game. Many of the actions the characters do are either painfully obvious, or painfully stupid. It didn't help that the mocap/animations for this game didn't age the best, so everyone seemed like they had a stick glued to the back of themselves, and did everything they could to make sure that stick never broke. The ending especially was just pretty bad, but around act I, act II, and a few moments of act III the story had many good moments. But act IV was just terrible and really ruined the story as a whole for me.

Characters
The characters for me are pretty recognizable as I used to spend hundreds of hours with them during the 360 era. However really looking into the characters and seeing them without the nostalgia goggles, they really sucked in terms of how they were presented. Many of them seemed so two dimensional, and would make poor decisions that was just so painful to sit through. Riptide def fleshed them out more, but the main cast was just way too stiff for my liking. The side characters that weren't in act I were just plain bad. They either had 0 character, or died after you left them for 10 minutes.

Gameplay
The gameplay for this game is honestly, still pretty good. However now that dying light is out which improved the game tremendously, the gameplay is just ok. I don't know if it was just me, but the zombies in this definitive edition just felt SOOO light, and I could kick them away for days without worry at all. Other aspects like no dropkick, and a meh skilltree led to the game just feeling like it was missing something that dying light filled. It's a shame cause this formula was where it all started, but newer games imo have just done it better now.

Tone
This is an extra point for this game, but the tone of this game was just all around the place. It seemed like it wanted to be taken seriously, but the poor animations, story telling and decision making just made this game a comedy instead. I know the developers changed the tone last minute cause it was supposed to be more comedy, but the dark tone just didn't work well for me and I love those types of story telling. Many of the moments in the story were too cliche for me to worth caring for.

Last notes
This game, playing it again, just showed me how painfully average it was. The endgame just seemed like it wouldn't be as fun as other games would be, and even though I have experienced maxing out my character in the 360, I just don't see myself doing it for this game. It really sucks because I held high praise for this game I used to play, and to realize just how PAINFULLY average it was, it really makes me wish I just didn't play it again.

Saving Grace
This game's coop mode is honestly pretty fun and the only reason why I would recommend this to anyone. The difficulty however is obvious that it wasn't scaled for coop, but the laughs you can get from this game makes up for the easy difficulty of this game. Death doesn't matter cause you respawn, zombies can easily be swarmed by the players and the 4 combined abilities makes this game a pretty easy cakewalk. So if you play this game solo, the difficulty is def much more fun in terms of gameplay, but the poor character, story and a bit poorly aged combat system compared to newer titles makes this really hard to recommend solo. But with coop I think it has its worth.

Conclusion
I am a bit disappointed to see just how average this game really was. Maybe it was due to my friends not caring for the story, so I was left with being rushed to do the story dialogue. However I do feel like if I TRULY invested into the story it still wouldn't be close to a memorable story as any other game I have played.

The game feels rushed and released too early. That's the main detraction.
The melee system is suprisingly deep, you must aim for pieces of the enemy, you have multiple damage types, you have stamina and the option to disable/stun or damage the enemy in that limited Energy. Combined with the well crafted gore system and hitting the enemy feels rewarding and damaging. It barely feels tedious to blend through fodder even.

So why is the game so bad if the core mechanic is so well crafted? Well the story's merely ok but the 2nd half of the game in level design and said story feels incredibly rushed. The Ending barely even makes sense.
The 1st area (Beach Resort) is finely crafted with level and world detail and little repetition. You spend the first 1/3rd of the game here. Pacing is fine, Enemies are fine, Story is fine, good Melee system.
But once you head into the 2nd area, the town, things start derailing. The plot starts to feel more arbitrary, the level more repetitive, and the pacing more annoying. There's one particular sewer path the main story forces you to take 3-5 times!

This only degenerates more as the game goes on, the 3rd area (Jungle) is there for barely 2 hours, and feels like parody/satire. At least the last area (Jail) is well plotted out and looks better but it's still repetitive, and the story seems non-sequitur so that I don't fully understand the ending even, which turns into a 10 minute boss arena and then game ends. So yeah, really rushed the dev cycle/release because the 1st area to the other ones feels like there were made by different devs.

The game used to be really buggy, but the devs went back and patched almost all of them, ragdoll physics were the worst thing we encountered. So that's nice at least.

The combat is very easy, most enemies can be easily kicked to the ground and those that can't have attack animations so slow you'd practically have to try and be hit.

Most quests (I'd hazard a guess of around 90-95%) are single phase fetch quests (e.g. follow marker, pickup item, come back and collect reward). The only enemies you have to kill are the ones marked as red skulls on your mini-map, you can just sprint past all others as they are much slower than you. Even the majority of the "main story" quests are like this.

The quests have ranked difficulties (using a skull rating system), however, this doesn't seem to reflect the difficulty of the quests at all (e.g. quests at opposite ends of the scale can have the same number and type of enemies).

Health items are everywhere, every few meters you'll find snacks and drinks to heal back up to full health after every minor inconvenience.

If you do die then you'll lose a negligible amount of money and likely respawn at a further along point in the quest.

The driving in the game is terrible. The maps are too tiny to warrant cars, you only need to drive for a dozen or so seconds to each marker. The cars instantly kill all enemies and you can only be hurt once inside of car if you come to a complete stop.

The game lacks any real story, I hope you read the short character bios on the selection screen because that's all you're getting! The "main story" quests are mostly about grabbing some supplies for people you've been given no reason to care about.

But it does look nice.

The game *looks* good, but there's no real fun to be had here. I completed the game rather quickly (a lot of the playtime displayed here was spent on pause), there's no character development or consistent story, and it just feels like once you've killed one enemy you've done everything you can with the combat system.

A fairly average "looter-shooter" styled game that can be a decent amount of fun with at least one other friend in CO-OP.

The combat system was neither bad nor exceptionally good, just at the right level of "average" that is still satisfying. Most of the combat in this game will be done up close with melee weapons. Enemies can be dismembered in various ways and bones can crack/break aswell. While there are guns in the game they usually don't do enough damage to justify using terribly often. Although I must mention there is a single player DLC character that has his own campaign (recommended to play after one non-dlc play-through) where the game balance is closer to an FPS style at which point firearms are fantastic there at any case. 

Dead Island has some of the standard RPG style mechanics, like leveling up and choosing skills, upgrading weapons and customizing them with a choice of a single elemental type from a pool of 3. Most skills are extremely basic "more inventory space" "more damage for a specific weapon type". Some enable a couple of new game mechanics, like one character can knock over enemies when he runs into them and each character has their own unique "Fury" mode that they can enable if they have recharged their fury-meter.

There is a standard set of 4 characters, each with their own skill-tree (with some crossovers) and some sort of combat-specialization. I don't think they actually play very differently from each other though, so ultimately each play-through the game experience doesn't change much at all. Unless you're a completionist I'd suggest just sticking with one character and enjoying a single play-through.

There is a level scaling system where the enemies and their possible loot will scale to match your player level. This typically means you won't feel insanely overpowered most of the time, although there are some very strong weapon upgrades that can result in some fun one-shotting times.

The story did not blow me away. There were a few scenes that were clearly made to be either "artistic" or "emotional" but they were merely "blah" instead. Plenty of fetch-quests, which can mostly be done along side others in a group so weren't too terrible. I don't know where to put this, but my favourite quote by far is during one of the escort missions where the NPC keeps repeating the same lines "We need to get going" with a really naggy kind of accent.

I thought the environments of game were reasonably good. I certainly enjoy the starter area, with the big beach featuring fairly bright lighting and of course sand-castles made of rock solid stone that can't be trampled on. There's also a sewers level which I think is a fan favourite. The dull and bleak corridors of concrete and pipes makes for a good time.

There is an older version of Dead-Island which is no longer sold and that has no upgrade-path to this new version. This separates the limited player-base and can make it awkward to play with friends that might have have the old version or the new version. While the game itself was a fun enough ride I don't actually recommend buying this title for any price due to this fact alone.

The game allows for selection of Playable Characters with different Skill Sets and Background Stories. This allows for an immersive component in that the Character you choose is someone you can likely embody in your mind. The Infected are varied, and many.  The uninfected NPCs are believable, and worthy of your respect and concern. it's a Good Time.

Much like its original incarnation 10 years ago, this game still finds ways to disappoint. The first act while not perfect at least has much more charm and inspiration than the three other acts that follow. The beach side section of the game that was advertised so heavily quickly gives way to another generic city section with enough sewer portions to make any zombie video game player sick to their stomach. Which is then followed by an uninspired jungle sequence which ends with a prison finale that can be rushed through in record breaking speeds without much effort. 

Combat is somewhat enjoyable at first but that gives way to multiple enemy types that rely on knockdown and insta-kill mechanics to one up the player no matter their adjustment to the sluggish way of fighting. Not to mention the amount of times players will have to fight all of these variants at once in cqc environments. Natural flow does not exist once the running infected types are introduced, and it only gets much worse from there. 

The story itself is quite forgettable, not that it needed to be legendary but since so much attention is given to completing it there leaves much to be desired. Characters are no different, the main crew is serviceable and not exactly altruistic but they do not grate on the nerves. Side characters on the other hand range from forgettable to downright obnoxious in their actions and motivations. Much more so when at times you have to escort them from point a to b while they are hounded by the hordes of the undead all the while. 

And don't forget all the bugs, glitches, and lack of time spent on the actual character models that leaves them laughable for all the wrong reasons. A decade onward and this game still manages to be underwhelming even with all the new content added with the remaster. Even for $5 I still feel cheated.

Dead Island has special place in my heart, but now playing it for the first time with friends. The whole game is just so underwhelming and way too fast. First Act will take you on a joy ride. You get to explore characters with developing personalities and favorable traits. Not until you hit the 2nd act. During the first act, the game mechanic has a level system for enemies. Kinda like borderlands, but with a catch. Instead of providing a way to elevate into weapons, you'll basically stuck with shitty weapons that barley scratch the zombies. Then they send special infected that basically overpowered as shit when paired up with regular infected. Some hitboxes make no sense and some of the landscape does even work with the mechanics of this game. Also when hitting into the 2nd act, you meet characters that are just unfavorable, boring, and completely make no fucking sense. It makes you want to cause international war crimes. The game is way too fast to even be played and they make you go through a whole campaign just to be dropped off because of it's plot. You begin to realize that half of the characters that you love are just dropped off into space bruh. Short summary: not worth more than 5$. So much fun in the first quarter, then gets worse through the end. AND I REPEAT, DO NOT PLAY BY YOURSELF. FUCKING YOU WILL BE BORED OUT OF YOUR LIFE. This is a coop game.

Undying classic. Still looks very good. Very nice combat system. It's never gets old to cut the lims of another zombie. Nice crafting system. Interesting skill system with 4 different (really different) classes (characters) to develop. Even basic zombies are dangerous in packs.
It has several very large maps with vehicles to travel. Zombies and loot respawn and level up with you. Lots of side quests. You can connect and play coop with your friends or other players. So basically it has never ending replayability. I played it several years ago and I still play it.

Absolutely great game still today! Had to get it on Steam to show support. Graphics are amazing in comparison to Xbox 360/PS3. Very enjoyable experience whether playing single player or co-op. Up to 4-player open world survival style as well as pit in an arena with waves of zombies (DLC). Craft your own weapons from loot you accumulate, mow down the enemies in vehicles, or slaughter zombies how you desire. Rough estimate, 50 main quests, 100 side quests... give or take. 4 Playable characters (not including Ryder White with DLC) with their own respective skill trees. Unlike some games, this one allows you to be able to retain items and levels once game is complete and start again. Multiple saves allowed.

I played through the original and it was great.
The definitive edition truly didn't bring much.
It pretty much is just the exactly same game.
Sure, some visuals got an upgrade, but yeah.
This wasn't a free upgrade, It was expensive. 
I bought the collection with riptide included.
The original owners had a discount for that.
It was around 9€ in total, I don't remember.
The level of improvement is very small, tho.
You could get mods for the original games.
Those mods also improved the visual style.
But unlike this, they were free to download.
Was this definitive upgrade worth it? Nope.
I just do not think it was a worthy upgrade.
It feels more like a cash-grab to be honest.
Nowadays you can't buy the originals, tho.
Therefore: It's great for all the new players.
Paying for the same games twice isn't fun.
Especially if there isn't anything truly new.
It is like paying for some cool visual mods.
But I really won't give it a negative review.
As I already said: It's nice for new players.
Only for that: I'm giving a positive review.

I played the original version of this game when it came out in 2011. I ran it back then on my old Intel Q6600 system with 4gb of DDR2 and an HD4870. It ran great in 1680x1050. The game had a few bugs, but was overall very fun. The platforming was a bit funky but reliable once you learned it, and the guns sucked, until you got to the very end, where they still sucked, just slightly worse. I played it through twice and then set it down. I would definitely recommend that version of the game.

Nowadays i'm playing on a 5600x, 1660 Super, 16 gigs of DDR4, and a 4k monitor. I bought the game for a lark and decided to replay through it. That was about when i noticed that they had redone the original game in a new engine. The new engine is objectively worse in almost every way than the old one. While they did patch out a few funny exploits (such as the ability to break bones multiple times using broken brass knuckles) they made just about every other aspect of the game worse.

From a performance perspective, the game runs terribly. Even with all effects off and all settings at low, I still encounter stuttering and framedrops in 1440p, even while running at a solid 90-120fps at all time. Vsync doesn't resolve the issue, and 4k becomes unplayable because despite maintaining a solid 60-75fps, the framedrops are even worse. The animation of the jump kick just becomes a slide show. Whatever is going on with the "improved" engine, it's optimization is hot garbage. On top of that, there are a host of bugs and collision issues that often result in your character dying at random. When running into an object such as a beachball, or a door. Your thrown blunt weapons sometimes randomly disappear through floors/walls; Enemy thrown objects do massively increased damage compared to the original. (often enough to one hit the player if not at full health) and the head/limb targeting has been completely broken. Even the gunplay is worse, as if that was possible!

As far as gameplay, i really do enjoy the core gameplay loop, best described as a "Zombie Looter Shooter". You open chests and kill bosses to get tiered loot, it's a very common idea that was a lot more groundbreaking in 2011. The execution is lackluster, and that's not new to the remake. The first act really is by far the best part of the game. It is very dense with collectables and little side quests that reward exploration and make it fun for the player. The zombies can be a challenge at times, but they never feel unfair. As soon as you begin the second act, the game completely throws the design principles of the first act out of the window, as well as attempts to change the story from the original light hearted camp fest, to something much more dark. As well, exploration becomes both less rewarding and much more challenging. On top of that, there are some very, VERY bad platforming sequences that had me absolutely pulling my hair out.

At the end of the day this is a classic game that like so many before it was butchered by a bad port. If only the "remaster" had only improved upon the original, this could have been such a better experience.

The months leading up to this game's release date had me so excited for it. The first main trailer for Dead Island made it seem like it was going to be some interesting story-driven game. Me and my friends were anticipating the day of getting our hands on this. Release day comes, get the game... a buggy piece of trash.

TL;DR This is one of the most repetitive, buggiest & disappointing games I have ever played to date. Avoid the headaches and frustration and play something far superior like Borderlands.

[b][u]STORY[/u][/b]
Dead Island offers barely any story. You play 1 of 4 forgettable characters that are immune to the virus that are trying to work their way off of the island of Banoi. You will visit 4 different settings throughout gameplay, but everything after the beach isn't worth visiting. Most environments are horribly designed and severely disappointing in comparison to the starting area.

Aside from the story missions there are side missions. These side missions are pointless fetch quests, don't waste your time unless you need to experience gain (as if that is really going to help).

[b][u]GAMEPLAY[/u][/b]
The gameplay for Dead Island is buggy, annoying, and so stale that the 4-year-old piece of popcorn under your couch tastes fresher in comparison. Sure, beating the shit out of zombies is fun and all at first, but once you get through the first handful of quests you will realize that there is nothing better coming along. Quests are ridiculously boring because you are fetching something 98% of the time.

You are going to quickly realize how horribly executed every mechanic in this game is. Fast stamina depletion extend playtime WAY too much. Driving is fun at first as you get to ram zombies to the ground, but then you will start to see that you will ram every invisible wall and horribly placed obstacle in your path. Weapons purposely break after 20-30 swings. Don't be surprised that you are constantly backtracking to a safehouse to fix your weapons. Repairing your busted up weapons requires [b][i]money[/i][/b] instead of resources. You will lose all of your money you just earned from missions and exploration.

The weapon mods are as follows: Shock, Acid, Fire & Bleeding damage. You get more powerful variations of each as you progress, but then the old weapon mods become pointless as you go.  Skill tree design is actual trash and barely helpful for your character. Also, don't get me started on the gunplay. All I will say is the guns in this game are pellet guns with inferior ammo reserves (I think your max ammo capacity is 3-clips worth - THATS IT).

The zombies can be so frustrating. Normal zombies chucking weapons like boat paddles at you is probably the most infuriating thing in the game. The damage stats on the weapons they throw are extremely low, yet they knock you down and take 75% of your health in one hit. "Thugs" and "Tanks" knock you down and deplete your health drastically with every hit. You will find yourself avoiding them when you can rather than taking them down.

Please note that collectibles are a waste of time and provide nothing as a reward, don't waste your time even as a completionist. Do not bother trying to get 100% on this horrendous game.

[b][u]SOUND[/u][/b]
The ambient music is decent but bland. The best track in the game is Sam B's "Who Do You Voodoo?" from the intro. Zombie sounds get repetitive fast. Voice acting is horrendous aside from Sam B and Sinamoi. I'm surprised Phil LaMarr (Sam B) touched this project with a 10-foot pole. The voice actress for Xian Mei is purposely stereotyping herself, providing some of the worst lines in the game.

[b][u]GRAPHICS/VISUALS[/u][/b]
Presentation improved with Definitive Edition, but the character models are still choppy polygons. Starting beach area looks great. The other areas look horrendous. The jungle area is absolutely terrible to navigate through, and it is a big portion of the game.

[b][u]OVERALL[/u][/b]
It's a waste. Not worth more than playing past the first act but not solo. The only redeeming quality is playing with friends online and doing stupid things together while making fun of the game.

[i]Story Length: 28 Hours (All Side Missions)

Completionist Stats: 
Banoi Heralds - 34/40
ID Cards - 76/100
Audio Tapes - 11/12
Sections Explored - 70/72
Experience Level - 37/50
Achievements - 33/57
[/i]

Before I start my review I want everyone to know that I have only seen small clips of game play of the original Dead Island but haven't played it. Dead Island Definitive Edition definitely steps the game up graphic wise and looks like it fixes a few small bugs. That's pretty much it however as the story and game mechanics are still all the same. While playing this game I ran into a ton of bugs and felt like I was playing Bug Hunt: The Game. Some of these bugs included floating zombie parts, Infected that have the brain of chickens as they'd run into a wall while trying to get to me and get stuck, or zombies clipping through walls (Mainly infected). The game itself felt very static as you knew where pretty much everything was going to spawn if you went back to an area. That is one thing they should add is more of an RNG based factor for spawns for both items and zombies. I've played through the main campaign twice and after playing through it once with the blunt weapons expert and sharp weapons expert I can tell you the zombies and items will always be in there respective positions. Even once they respawn they go back to their positions. 

About the characters the game has decent replayability due to having four different characters with different skill trees and fun weapon areas to specialize in. Character development wise? God no. There's nothing much there except in the cutscenes. The cutscenes were pretty much the only area that showed character development at all. The story was pretty decent and was a standard zombie story on a tropical paradise which I felt was intriguing. The character models, voice acting and character expressions could either be good or terrible. I felt like I began to see a repeat in the same character model over and over again. The character models made VERY LITTLE TO NO EXPRESSION at all. I felt like I was staring constantly into a dolls face as they'd always keep the same expression no matter if they were injured, dead, or crying and happy. Some of the voice acting can be good as in the case of Ryder White or Sinamoi and the main characters. The side characters have pretty meh to terrible voice acting though and it felt laughable sometimes. This game is pretty much dead for the online factor so if you want to get some achievements or play with others I recommend getting a group of friends or find a community online. I felt like the camera movements and controls could be a little wonky and sometimes bugged. The thing I'm probably the most disappointed in was the death mechanic. All that happens when you die is that you lose some money and respawn to the last checkpoint. I never really had a money problem due to all the side quests and the amount of money I was given doing the main quests. It felt like the death mechanic was built for CO-OP play and I was stuck in a timer for 10 seconds to wait to respawn. Once that fear of death leaves you however that really diminished the horror of the game for me, mostly knowing that I could just respawn myself at the next checkpoint. 

The reason why I've rated this game positively however is due to the nostalgia factor it gives off when playing it. It reminds me a lot of Left 4 Dead franchise with all the different zombie types. I also still did get scared sometimes by the zombies that would appear silently around a corner as I was sprinting down it. I'd jump at that because I was startled and scream. That's pretty much it for the scare factor though. The atmosphere was FANTASTIC! I really felt like I was traversing through a zombie infested tropical paradise in the aftermath in the infection and the scenery was just a beautiful pair to the dark atmosphere. The story, sometimes cheesy, can at some times be a little emotional at least for me. All in all, I think this game was a nostalgic trip for me and I'd suggest playing with some friends or others. Fun game overall and I'd also recommend getting it on sale since it seems to go on sale all the time. I'd rate it a 7/10 and a fun experience.

P.S: I highly recommend playing the Ryder White Campaign as it expands a lot more upon what was happening behind the scenes. Challenging but fun as well.

New and better textures.
Better graphics and you can always deactivate ambient occlusion and motion blur, I personally don't like that kind of think but I was coming to that subject, I'm more of an old school gamer, I prefer old games, I also prefer old school and retro graphics, Yeah, I love 8bit, 16bit, retro looking games, I love how Doom or even how The Elder Scrolls II: Daggerfall look like, of course, there are a few exceptions, some just hurt the eyes and some games are better to be played with better graphics, games such as Civilization even though I must admit that Civilization II was one of a beautiful game for its time.
So now that's where I was coming to, graphics aren't important to me and it shouldn't be to people, maybe, perhaps a little but not much more than the gameplay.
I personally would have prefer a new and better loot system with more sort of weapons something like Dying Light has but even better, more weapons, more guns, better gameplay, I never liked to use the guns in Dead Island, I prefer when it's realistic than arcade but in thise case, It's just too arcadish, It's even worse but that's my opinion, it would have been great if they could have made it better, perhaps not realistic since this is not a simulation game but they could have enhance it.
I won't complain though, It only cost me 10$ for both the new definitive edition plus the retro game.
But it would have seriously been awesome if there would have been more to this.
So my point is, It is good, It is worth it but they could have done so much more by enhancing the gameplay too and perhaps adding a new character with its own new skills.
Other than that, the game is great as always, It is not perfect, the gameplay still feel weird to me at least but it's not the worse thing ever neither, It can be beautiful if you play with some of the settings that's of course if you do not like some things such as motion blur and/or for example if you want to change the fov.
It's still has the crappy auto aim and slow motion that Dead Island had.
Still can't deactivate those.
Physics were bad back in Dead Island right? You'll be happy to know that they're even worse in the definitive edition.
Containers doesn't respawn, at least, not right away, the one who thought it would be a good idea to implent this is one heck of a dumbass but coming from Deep Silver or even the modern gaming industry, it's nothing special, pretty common actually.
It's supposed to be a loot game.
The zombies and the items respawn even though the containers doesn't, makes sense right?
Perhaps for a bunch of brainless incompetents such as those in Deep Silver but normally, it doesn't.

I don't care if dying light is superior in most aspects, this game is pure nostalgia. I finished it years ago on PS3, back in those innocent times when wacking zombies with makeshift blunt weapons and stomping their brains out was enough to bring me joy. Looking back at its development and release, it ended up being a classic despite failing to meet the trailer's expectations. If you want some emotional crap with your zombies just go play last of us. 

The characters are terrible and the plot and writing are straight out of a scyfy movie, but that adds to it in a way. You're not playing this to get emotionally invested in Sam's failed career as a rapper, but to satisfy your sadistic urges to rip off people's limbs and explore some cool environments. Worth noting the graphics still look good for its age, and the enemy design is pretty great.

So I rate it 7.5/10.

Not a lot to say about this game really. 
In terms of the story and plot, there wasn't anything new or different. Just a typical zombie virus outbreak and you as the player are immune and are trying to get help/escape the island 
Characters weren't memorable (i couldn't remember any names)
Graphically it holds up in some places and in others it can be a little underwhelming 
Side missions can resort to "retrieve item for npc" or "do job for npc" etc
This may not sound that great from what i have written however, the gameplay is solid
Weapons are well executed with the wear system and have a weight to them when being used against enemies
There are many ways to customise weapons to make them more powerful
Skill trees are decent enough to satisfy the player and show change in their gameplay
The use of cars is decent (and is a one hit machine when it comes to killing enemies)
Settings work and are a big enough change to make the game have a smooth flow rather than having one setting completely stale
There is some replay ability with the option to select a different character however it wouldn't make a big enough difference in my opinion
Overall, Dead Island is a fun experience. It may not be the strongest in terms of narrative or characters, but gameplay is great and is a solid experience

[h1]Disclaimer[/h1]
2 things:
1. Trigger warning for those of you who are delicate flowers or young.
2. If you suffer motion sickness from low FoV - the default FoV is tiny and changing it can be done in configuration files (google it, not hard to do), but it affects other things like decreasing your firearm accuracy. There is a decent mod on Nexusmods called "improved movement" that modifies some variables, including the FoV. The negative impact of this mod on accuracy is not high, so you can use that as a starting point for your FoV value and then decide if you are willing to sacrifice more accuracy or lower FoV to increase it.

Onto the review.

[h1]TL;DR[/h1]
This game is "definitive" in name only. Not worth upgrading from original. Is it a good game? Eh... If you, like me, like zombie games - I can recommend it. Just know that this is a Diablo clone, not a survival game. It's nothing like the later Dying Light.

[h1]Description[/h1]
Dead Island is a first-person Diablo clone set in zombie apocalypse on a tropical island. You will start at a vacation resort infested with zombies, helping survivors find a way out off the island. Slowly you will uncover the source of the virus and possibility for a cure.

You have 4 different characters or "classes" with specializations: Sam B (blunt melee), Xian (cutting melee), Purna (guns), Logan (throwing).

Each character has their own skill, similar to how Borderlands did it, as well as access to passive talents that increase different attributes or modify said skill.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
[b]+ Crafting[/b]
There are several upgrade paths with increasingly better versions unlocked by finding blueprints that are located at different areas in the game. Some of them are hidden, some of them are placed in plain sight and some are awarded by completing main/side quests. Upgrades also change the looks of the weapon you apply them to.

[b]+ Visual design[/b]
From the aforementioned weapon upgrades, to the design of zombies and how they visibly take damage as you hit them with their body aprts getting breken or cut off. The island itself is beautiful and the resort looks like somewhere you might like to spend a nice weekend at if not for the zombies.

[b]+ Passable combat[/b]
You can swing your melee weapon and while you aim at an enemy - a small reticle appears on their body indicating where your melee strike will land. Mostr weapons feel similar though.

There is a decent amount of zombie variations. For example, you have slow-moving walkers who can grab you in melee. You have the running infected, who are fast and attack quick, but have low HP. There are big zombies that can knock you down with a single hit and take a lot of punishment, but are very slow and telegraph their attacks. Then you have special zombies that appear very rarely, like huge, tied-up ramming-zombies that charge at you at high speed and must be dodged so they smash into a wall, or exploding zombies that must be killed from range.

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
[b]- Poor writing[/b]
A lot of characters have very bad dialogue lines. There is one scene in particular that's handled in an idiotic way and it's clear to me that the writers have bitten off more than they could chew with that. I will put the following in spoiler tags for 2 reasons:
1 - it's a main plot-point spoiler
2 - it could be triggering to people

[spoiler]There is a point in the story where you are tasked with finding a bunch of food supplies for the survivors. You and other main characters head out accompanied by a girl-mechanic Jin, who you earlier rescue from zombies (a simplification, but explaining everything would take too much time). This takes you to a whole new area of the island where you meet 3 other survival groups, 2 of them being friendly and 1 of them being very hostile 'bandit' type group who took over a police station (implying they are criminals from before the zombie outbreak). All of the groups are low on supplies too and also need food badly. After many quests you finally find a food stash. Jin then says that there's enough food for every survivor group out there, including the violent group mentioned earlier. Main characters rightfully say something like "fuck those guys, they shot at us multiple times, we are not helping them, we are just going to share among the 'good' survivor groups". After some other quests that involve you moving the food to your truck the Jin takes off without you with the intention of sharing the food as she proposed earlier, ignoring main character's opinions - including going to the bandit camp, who are barricared up in a police station.

I'm sure you know where this is going.

When you get back to the survivor camp it appears that the Jin did not return for a while. As you go out in search for her, a different survivor who was with her as she drove off to share the food basically tells you that she got captured and the bandit guys are going to rape her. You launch an attack on the police station and find the girl after she clearly got raped already (although nothing explicit is shown - no bruises or marks on her, not even torn clothes, she has the same character model as always). The scene is handled poorly in and of itself, with Sam B immediately accusing the clearly abused girl of betraying them and the girl main characters shoving men out of the room. However, the entire plot point just feels off like it does not belong here.

I think a rape-plot could be handled well and be a strong motivator for player characters if written better. Maybe if those assholes at the police station had some kind of leverage that made the girl go there other than the fact that she wanted to share food out of kindness? The aftermath is likewise, handled badly as no effort is put to make the character model stand out. I mean she clearly got sexually abused - why on earth is her character model looking like normal with same clothes, etc? If you want to handle a serious, triggering topic like this you can't half-ass it - it just makes it seem like you've put it in there for shock value. If the motivation behind her going to that clear trap was better and the consequences were shown appropriately I would probably feel sick to my stomach (as I can't handle rape scenes in anything), but at least it would have done it's job of giving context as to how fucked-up the world has quickly became once zombies destroyed the society. For "good" depictions of rape in media look no further than Berserk anime, where the rape in itself is horrible, but there is a very long buildup and a logical explanation for why it happened and when it does - it serves a purpose other than shock value alone.[/spoiler]

[b]- Characters[/b]
Aside from Sam B being an idiot at a scene described in the spoiler, Purna is a sexist. Shitty people like Purna do exist in real life, so this could be seen as a good thing that assholes are represented in the main cast.

Xian is the most level-headed of the group. She is honest, but considerate and stands as the best character out of the main cast. Logan is lacking in the personality department and is usually the least interesting.

Other than that we have many supporting heroes, with lifeguard Sinamoi as a positive standout - he is the first helping hand as well as the main driving force behind quests for the majority of the game.

[b]- FoV[/b]
Already described.

[b]- No cool loot[/b]
All loot is just a bunch of stats. There's no cool stuff that completly changes the gameplay like in Diablo.

[h1]Lowdown[/h1]
A mediocre game that does what it set out to do, which is a simple Diablo clone in a zombie outbreak situation viewed in first-person. It can be a bit heavy-handed with it's themes and bad writing, but the gameplay itself is what I expected.
I'd give Dead Island a
[h1]6/10[/h1]
It provides just enough fun to be recommended for zombie-game fan. Just don't expect a survival horror, because it's not one - just a hack'n'slash with a horror theme.

Techland's Dead Island caught a fair bit of reviewer flack on its original release in 2011 - but I remember finding it tons of fun. After the zombie apocalypse strikes a tropical island resort, the player character embarks on a light but compelling RPG, zapping zombies in innumerably diabolical ways whilst pursuing simple fetch quests over a series of respectably large and varied levels. After two complete playthroughs of the original edition, I snagged the Definitive Edition in a Steam sale a few years ago and relived the fun with nicely upgraded graphics. I write this review at the start of a 4th playthrough, so Techland must have done something right.

Compared with the incomparably more finished and much darker Dying Light, Dead Island certainly has its rough edges. The game's various attempts at edginess and pathos are often unintentionally hilarious - when they don't simply fall flat. But the core business of dispatching the undead is solid enough. Perhaps it's just me, but compared with spending a month researching, installing and tuning mods for a fresh playthrough of something like Fallout 4, the ability to almost immediately start playing Dead Island's undemanding and relaxing fare has considerable appeal. Undemanding and relaxing, that is, unless, one gets mobbed by zombies, in which case the intensity level can spike abruptly!

All this said, out of the box, DIDE does require some tweaking to be playable. First, go to PCGamingWiki, https://www.pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Dead_Island:_Definitive_Edition, and apply the recommended fixes for increasing FOV, and removing Chromatic Aberration and the immersion-breaking crosshair.

Then, go to this topic on the Steam Forums titled 'Control delay/lag?' https://steamcommunity.com/app/383150/discussions/0/364043054119097520/?ctp=2; look at the last post by D.A.R.K. that details how to modify the MoveAcceleration and MoveDeceleration parameters. Setting these both to ~20 virtually eliminates the annoying (in fact, almost game-breaking) 'inertia' effect on the movement of the player character.

As a final touch, I recommend disabling vsync (both in-game and via any 3rd party software like the Nvidia control panel) to reduce mouse lag to a bearable level.

I've got mixed feeling about this game. At my 7th hour in game I started do a scratch of my review as Not Recommended. Everything about this game was wrong. Slow combat, all based on hit-and-dodge 1vs1 fights (more zombies can instantly kill). Silly quests (bring me my teddy bear / get me champagne so I can get racked), reckless weapon repair system (you can fix them yourself at any workbench, but you must pay to use it, even if it is a stranded one) and car behaviour on the road (it kinda "swims" on the road) made me feel like I'm playing in a higher budget indie game.

So my problem was I was playing it solo and it's a co-op game and this is where all the fun is. Fighting groups of zombies is way much easier with one friend already, not mentioning gathering full set of four. You have to have your friends though, most of the cases when you try to join a public game gonna gets you being kicked out. Or get blown out and then kicked.

My change of mind took place after finishing the first act. I realised the main story isn't that silly like all the side-quests and I find it maybe not very amusing, but pleasant. Story mode gave me around 20h+ of fun, but the true maple syrup is in the Bloodbath Arena. After hitting lvl 50 you can gather your friends and play together on Very Hard arena against hordes of zombies. And as the name say, it's a real bloodbath. Every wave spawns more and more zombies and they become more and more powerful. Game is awarding you for getting thru waves by spawning zombies carrying special weapons you can loot. I only wish there was more bloodbath zones, it's only four in game and they are different difficulty levels, so you ends up playing only Very Hard map.

Dead Island Definitive Edition is an enormous and densely packed zombie adventure that often left me completely awestruck with both its visual spectacle and excellent combat. By steadily introducing new abilities instead of stat upgrades, its combat manages to stay challenging, rewarding, and fun throughout the entire 40 to 50 hours that it took me to beat the campaign. One thing worth mentioning is the gunplay. The gunplay is just so absolutely stunning, I really couldn’t believe it! It kept me engaged the whole time, trying to get all the headshots and shooting the limbs off the zombies, it was really fun! The environment is so well put together, it really sends chills down your spine in some areas. The sewer missions are especially well done. I really enjoyed my time creeping through the sewers, shaking in my boots as I’m hoping the zombies won’t jump out of the shadowy crevices and attack me. The mission variety is incredible, not like most open world games with a few different kinds of missions, in Dead Island Definitive Edition, there are barely any repeated objectives. Another thing worthy of mentioning is the absolute polish in this game. The developers really seem like they care about this game, and spent a lot of time ironing out any bugs before the release of the Definitive Edition. It may actually be the most polished game I have ever played. I have greatly enjoyed this game in the time I have played. The characters are beautifully put together, the animations are gorgeous, and the scenery is breathtaking. I wouldn’t trade the time I have spent in this masterpiece of a game for anything in the world. Dead Island Definitive Edition is more than a step up from the original. I wouldn’t even call this a “Definitive Edition”, I would consider it more of a “Masterpiece Edition”. I would try to find anything bad about this game, but all I can think of is that I get so engaged I forget how long it’s been since I started. The multiplayer in this game is also very good, and surprisingly challenging. You may think that because you have four people you would just breeze through the game, but the difficulty scaling is very well done, and you can’t really just team up on all of the zombies. You have to go in with a strategy, not just run in blindly swinging your weapons. It really makes the multiplayer a hugely enjoyable aspect to the game. Overall, I would give this game a perfect score, 100/100!

There were a few instances that were fun, maybe I haven't played enough yet but this game is just kind of boring. I can see how Dying Light is, in a way, a spiritual successor to this game combat wise, but without the movement there really isn't much going for it. The story is pretty good so far, but some side missions are basically just an easy way to make cash without it really going anywhere. A guy asking for alcohol or a woman asking for a water which can be repeated several times. It doesn't really matter what you pick up, because everything is turned into cash which is turned into upgrades and repairs for weapons. Fighting zombies can be fun, sometimes, but fighting anything other than a runner or a normal zombie is basically just hit them and hope they go down first. It's boring and bland, but the game looks nice and the story is good. I haven't touched the Co-Op but I'm sure it would be much more fun with friends.

I know a few of my friends will see this review and get mad at it being negative but I need to be honest about Dead Island especially the "definitive edition". Back in 2011 I was but a young idiot that ignored how outdated the original was (I played it on a PS3) and saying it was outdated is putting it lightly it was more obsolete than outdated. When I heard that this was coming out especially hot off the heels of Dying Light I didn't know what to expect. And honestly this game is a prime example of the misuse of the subtitle "definitive edition". Whats so definitive about this re-release? Nothing. Absolutely nothing. It still feels like I'm staring through a camera lens that was smeared with vaseline and the "new" weapon models are literally ripped straight from Dying Light. This is the laziest remake or re-release I have ever seen. If you're expecting perfection and refinement you will not find it with this game because it still plays like it was released 10 years ago and says a lot.

This game is comparable to 2 other games: Left For dead, and Dying light. while i like Dying light over this (due to the Focus on movement) this game has different focus's and you may like this better. Dead island Definitive edition (DIDE) is like L4D2 but you're in an open world with quests, fast travel, vehicles, and an actual story line with some quirks. DIDE has a focus on combat, and the styles within it. each character has a specific set of skills tailored to a specific weapon type, Blunt, Sharp, Throwing, Guns. the story isn't perfect but serves to motivate you to move forward, though the side quests are the meat of this game and consist of you going around solving others problems for money because you are immune/very resistant to the virus for some reason (no spoilers). However, there is one problem that plagues the story game. The end boss. The end boss is poorly made and a bad experience. he's nearly as fast as you, insanely tough, the explosives meant to damage him take too long to set off. he never stays still long enough to be attacked. he also packs huge knockback, which is the only good thing. it gives you distance to him, but you take damage. its a horrible experience to fight, and maybe I'm just bad but i spent a long time in this game, i shouldn't have this much trouble with it when playing a style that's notorious for being the easy way to play. The only bugs I've encountered are good ones that have helped me, and for the sake of keeping the experience pure i will not explain the glitches i used to progress faster and avoid grinding for money. overall 8/10 alone and 9/10 with others

Dead Island Definitive Edition is the re-release of the original Dead Island that released on 6 September 2011, and this version has all of the downloadable content included.

[h1]Characters[/h1]
—There are four people to choose from and they have their strengths and their own special "fury" ability: Sam B. with his fists, Xian Mei with her blade weapons, Logan Carter with throwing weapons, and Purna with her pistol. Ryder White is a character choice; he's the main character in the Ryder White DLC and uses his pistol for fury.

—There are other characters you interact with, but mostly they are part of the story and are kind of forgettable.

—There's one NPC that helps you store items, so cool, I guess?

—NPC repeatable quests? Annoying as hell. Ex: "OH THANK GOD!"

[h1]Atmosphere/Environment[/h1]
—The environments are a wide variety: wide-open, tropical-vista views of the ocean and sunshine; cramped, desolated, blood-ridden areas inside tunnels; and dark, creepy houses and closets. Oh, also, there's a lighthouse.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
—There are so many zombies and so many ways to dispatch them: beat them, kick them, stomp them, shoot them, chop their heads off, throw weapons at them, blow them up with explosives, throw Molotov cocktails at them, use your special ability, electrocute them—SO MANY WAYS, GO F*CKING CRAZY!

—This game is fun exploring and killing zombies alone, but with more people involved it is a BLAST to play through!

—Crafting is amazing in this game; there are so many combinations and types of weapons to craft that can really knock zombies off of their own feet. There are secret blueprints hidden around the world to find, and those are worth the price of discovery and crafting

—You have a skill tree—fury, combat, survival—with lots of new abilities, and the best ones that I recommend are anything that gets you cash, more stamina, durable weapons, and the execution-style head smash. Two feet is the best!

—Ryder White's DLC has a BIG problem with infected zombies; there are so many that appear and chase you that you are placed into a position where you have to get lucky and throw grenades and run away. Despite having effective medkits, health, and stamina, you cannot upgrade Ryder's stats. Thankfully this DLC is shorter than the main game.

—NPC's are kind of helpless when they get surrounded; be sure to throw weapons at the zombies.

[h1]Enemies/Allies[/h1]
—Your zombie rundown is as follows: walkers move slow; infected move fast; straightjacket ones charge you; thin-skinned bubbly ones explode at close range; floaters that move slow and puke on you from a distance; butchers that are a pain to fight and dispatch; and humans that wield pistols, rifles, and shotguns.

—There are a couple of boss fights, one being towards the end of the campaign before [spoiler] you board the helicopter with Charon [/spoiler]

[h1]Story[/h1]
—Beginning intro of someone getting drunk makes no sense character-wise; you just wake up disoriented—probably from too much drinking or someone slipped you a roofie or something—to find that the entire island has been riddled with human-craving zombies due to a mass virus. Surprisingly, you and y our acquaintances are somehow immune. [spoiler] Your crew must then make your way off of the island because it's about to be destroyed by a nuclear strike. [/spoiler] 

[h1]Boss(es)[/h1]
—There are small mini-bosses known as thugs. Each one may have a weakness in their arm, leg, or torso where a critical hit is possible. Be sure to attack those weak points for an easy kill.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
—As previously mentioned in the Atmosphere category, the visuals in the sunlight on beaches is very pleasant to look at, even on HDR monitors. Everything else that's shot in the dark seems to be low-textured and were meant to be there.

[h1]Music[/h1]
—The music in this game is not memorable, but kind of smoothing as background noise; the menu music is self-explanatory, the ambiance in safe zones are appropriate, and of course the action sequences. The lighthouse one is somber yet peaceful—my second favorite. The main trailer music by Giles Lamb is the most memorable out of all of them.

I originally played this game on the 360. I initially hated it but then after a few hours of understanding the mechanics it finally  reached the top ranks of my zombie game collection. EG: Resident Evils, Dead Risings etc.

This game is an open world sandbox experience that is not too overwhelming. I don't know about you but I prefer my sandboxes to be large but not too large. This is so if I return to this game months later it will be simple to pin point where I was in the game. 

The graphics to me are still very beautiful. Especially the PC version (Definitive Version) compared to the 2011 version on Xbox 360 there is no comparison.

One of the things that might put people off in Dead Island is the stamina bar. If you're used to action games like Dark Souls this shouldn't be a problem. 

Quests can be on the repetitive side but the fact that you can really customize your talent trees make for a nice goal to work towards.

If you're into using firearms vs melee Dead Island might disappoint. My first playthrough i went to 80% completion using melee. Guns are pretty rare. 

Dying/Upgrading/Repairing weapons is very expensive in this game. When you die you lose a fuck ton of money. 

OVERALL ~ GET THIS GAME
8.5/10

Graphics +++
Sound Design +++
Customization of Char Stats +++

Cons
Repetitive Questing
Upgrading/Repairing Weapons is expensive
Dying in the game is EXPENSIVE
Money is a huge part of this game. Less money = Not as fun. More Money = Super fun

I wasn't sure to review this version or the original; but I guess this is the one people will buy, so it makes more sense to review the Definitive Edition.  Between this version, original (steam), and my first copy on PS3; I probably have around 500 hours invested.  (And to be clear, 0 of those hours are multiplayer : this review focuses on single player only)

This is a very fun game, with great melee combat.  It is fun to just waste an afternoon running around this island resort, leveling up your character (grinding) and eviscerating the undead.  It is very zen.  The 4 maps are all great, very detailed, and provide plenty of incentive for exploration.  There are tons of weapons, and very simple crafting system.

The story is typical zombie fare, and a single playthrough with one character will probably take around 40 hours.

I wish that one day we would get a true sequel to this (NOT Dying Light; this game is superior to that, and a different type of game; IMHO).  And no; riptide does not count either.  I would honestly avoid that title, unless you get a package deal or something in which case you can import your original character.

The only real difference between this version and "original" is now you can not kick zombies into shallow pools and watch them suffocate.

Pros: 
- First person perspective
- The story is ok
- Map Size
- Visuals look decent for a game that'll run on an 8 year old gpu

Cons:
-Bugs and Combat bugs
-Poor design in some areas
-Melee combat (the wrong skill tree will make this boring and frustrating)
-Health is plentiful when you need it, and non-existent when you do.
-Annoying, screaming zombies that spawn every few minutes (typically 50ft away in a bush)

-Death costs a % of your money.
Unlike Borderlands, money doesn't come quite as easily and there are no 2nd winds in singleplayer.

-Just like Dying Light, there's a problem with factory OC'd video cards that will cause an occasional crash.
The solution is to de-tune your card a bit before you start the game.

-By far one of the worst parts of this game is that weapons can disappear if they're thrown.
You know, one of the core gameplay mechanics of the game?
This forces you to pick between holding onto your rare machete or sacrificing it to Dev-Hell.

At this point I'm just trying to finish the game to get it over with.
I'd recommend this game if it's on sale for 5$.

Things Required to play DEAD ISLAND:

1) Actually only a few bucks, very cheap when on sale
2) Desire to see many people in serious need of a dentist (and hear them roar when they don't get help)
3) Time to get used to the post apocalyptic controls
4) All Love in your heart for humans and animals must be surrendered
5) It's best if you work at a crematorium, as this will prepare you for "DEAD ISLAND"  dun dun dun...

BUT, What does DEAD ISLAND GIVE YOU? (If you gotta give all that up, then it must give somethin' back right?  dun dun dun....   here is the list.  I promise you will get all of these things but perhaps not necessarily in the order in which they were written (dun dun dun....) :

1) NEW DIRECTION IN LIFE:  This game gives you new direction in life by instilling you with an insatiable desire to slice off heads of zombies, men, and women, and even stuffed animals (although no animals were actually hurt during the production of this video game) .  You do this with cycles, kitchen knives, cleavers, electric knives, and many other sharp objects. The "one slice off the head shots" will give you addictive pleasant memories and fantastic dreams and a super real reason to wake up in the morning... to play again and again and slice off more heads (of course).  Parents. teachers, siblings, friends, church friends, boy scout leaders, brownie group leaders, and pastors should be REAL proud of us all.  Afterall, no one ever said it's easy being a zombie demon slayer.  

2) A NEW SUPER POWER and PASSION that will get everyone's attention:  A new ability to make all friends and pastor folk sincerely concerned about you and give you an amazing amount of attention.  I mean, attention in a way where they will call you daily end even multiple times a day just to make sure you are - uh, alright.  Simply tell them you found a new passion.  Tell them (squint your eyes and lower your voice as much as possible and let the words come out slow and scratchy) that in all  your spare time you are, uh - slicing off heads by the thousand and love watching the blood come from peoples neck. And as the heads tumble to the ground you soak it all in as if it is in slow motion. Tell them you love shooting your pistol to blow out brains, and of your love for the crunch of the hammer on the back of "human skull" calls your name at night.  Follow that up with your admission of a new taste for kicking women in the prone position in the crotch, and men that are in the prone position in the crotch, well... until they die. Tell them kicking people on the ground in their crotch until they die is your new THANG!  Your thang man! Your thang!  I GAR-A-NTEE you will have more attention than flies on fresh crap in the middle of a hot summer day in Missouri.  Yeee-hah!!!!

3) ENDLESS MEANS OF KILLING and KILLER MUSIC SCORE:  You will be granted by Dead Island and associates (except camels and lamas who did not agree to this),  access to an endless supply of new ways to kill people (dead and alive) while listening to theater quality music scores.  Not sure why the camels did not like this idea so they were sent back to the farm. The lamas were given pajamas and a salty pacifier.  Which helped keep them quiet long enough to publish the game.

4) VISITATION RIGHTS TO PEOPLE WITH SERIOUS DENTAL ISSUES: Endless supply of people that have a need to visit the dentist more than you do. Which if you are like me, is  a huge huge plus because I hate feeling self conscious about those types of things!  Once you realize that you have the Tom Cruise smile in the room, the rest is all down hill!

5) LOOTY FROM THE BOOTY! Last but not least: You will find that you can take amazing amounts of money, batteries, and wire from an endless stream of bikini bottoms.  Just one pull (or maybe several kicks or slices) on their strings and out comes the booty prize!  Where do the ladies actually put that loot anyway? I guess the folks at Dead Island know me better than I do, cuz it never gets old taking the loot from bikini bottoms... it just doesn't ever get old.  It seems like it should, but nope, it doesn't.  Guess that is why they made endless amounts of bikini bottom zombie x-barbie chicks for me to slice and kick.

(FUN an ENERGETIC GAME with rpg elements and story ... fun to play with a friend or alone!  Get it now or get eaten by a score of zombies!  Seriously... Buy it... what are you waiting for? Quit reading this... stop it!  I am waiting for you to go buy it and stop reading this and am not going stop writing until you do... well,  there you go again reading this sentence.  Oh well, buy it on sale or whenever then... but don't blame me if you are not prepared for your new life mission or if you miss out on your true passion in life!)

Feels very unfinished. Pretty much all (not even most) collisions with melee and ranged weapons result in no sound and no visual effects. Quests are pretty surface level. The driving controls terribly (some inputs will not read, if you crash the car simply gets stuck in place instead of bouncing or powering through, even if you're held back by a pebble's length of a collider). Basically, it is a "complete" game, but only by the bare minimum.
