I've put hundreds of hours into Dead Island over the years and it's one of my favorite games of all time.  The last time I played was a couple years ago before I bought this version and I thought, "Man this game is still so much fun, I just wish the graphics were updated."  Well, that's what this is.  The game is exactly the same in every way except the graphics, complete with frustrating bugs and movement issues.  I may be biased by my unreasonable enjoyment of the game but I never found those things to be game-breaking or enough to dim my joy.  Honestly, I'd rather the bugs stayed than have the devs tinker with programming and end up breaking something else, though they are talented programmers as made clear by the fantastic Dying Light.  Because there's so little difference this is functionally a review of both the old and new version.

I always loved the environment and aesthetic of the game, especially the dichotomy of being in a beautiful resort filled with aggressive zombies.  When it first came out, the concept of sprinting, screaming zombies wasn't common and it was intimidating.  It still is once you're at a higher level and the zombie levels scale with (and surpass) you.  Mismanage three runners on their approach and you're probably dead but it's so satisfying to dispatch them with style.  A bullet in the leg of one, a thrown hatchet in the forehead of another, kick one off its feet, cut the other's head off with an electrified machete, and end the last one with a jumping head-stomp and tell me you don't feel like a boss.  Weapon modding and skill trees are a great part of the game, with different weapon preference and skill trees for each of the main characters.  If you don't aim for the jumping head-stomp move as early as is reasonable you're going to have a hard time at higher levels because weapon degradation takes its toll and repairing high-end weapons isn't cheap, plus you lose a big chunk of cash when you die.  The co-op is also good if you can find a person/people around your level (to preserve the level-scaling) and it's fun driving over zombies in a truck with two people in the bed and one in the passenger seat.  Having all four characters in-game with their strengths overlapping means you get to absolutely slaughter the dead.

Unfortunately all the old issues persist but are easily avoided if you stay aware of them.  For example, there's a glitch where a weapon in your inventory will just *poof* disappear when you mod them, which sucks when you just dropped a bunch of money upgrading the strength of a top-line machete, then apply the mod and it's gone.  This is avoided by putting the weapon you want to mod in your hot-bar/quick-select and equipping it before modding, works every time.  Similarly, be careful with thrown weapons because they have a habit of disappearing as well, especially if you throw one in a panic and get killed anyway.  When you respawn the weapon will be gone, guaranteed.  I just avoid throwing my primary weapons in general, and only throw my secondaries (modded knife or hatchet) if I'm certain I'm not about to get swamped and killed.  Third thing is, it's still kind of ridiculous that being inside of an armored truck gives you no protection whatsoever.  Zombies will punch you through the door no problem and I've been one-shotted by a high-level knife-throwing zombie directly through the front window despite the metal bars over it.  I can only assume he was an expert marksman in his past life.  The last complaint is the movement, arguably the most frustrating thing in the game.  Gaps that appear big enough to pass through quickly become a death-trap as the dead surround you from behind and you jump impotently trying to escape.  Your movement can stop cold running into the wrong six-inch tall curb, stuff you should be able to jump over resists your efforts and occasionally a jump-kick looks spot-on and upon landing you get your head knocked off.

Like I said, none of this is game-breaking.  Losing a good weapon sucks but there will be more and money lost getting killed by the movement issues will quickly be replaced.  It's not the greatest game in the world but it's good, stupid fun, far more fun than anyone should expect a five dollar game (on sale) to be.

Dead Island Definitive Edition is a really good co-op focused game. With teammates, you can do missions and unlock new things. It's a great experience for anyone who's looking for a new co-op game to play! I would also recommend the sequel to this game, Dead Island Riptide Definitive Edition. Both are very great games to play with friends! With how open and diverse each setting is (island, city, jungle, prison) it helps make the game a new experience wherever you go. Each setting comes with an open terrain for you to travel and find new weapons to upgrade, repair, or create. All in all, I would recommend this game to anyone who enjoys zombie games and co-op games.

I have played this game almost since its release on other platforms before Steam,so I guess I should give my honest opinions about this game and the future of this franchise.

1.Introduction:
Dead Island 1 (2010) fresh off the heels of the recently released Borderlands (2009) is a hack and slash/semi open world/cookie cutter zombie game with a slight hint of tropical paradise gone wrong game.The first time I played this game I was captivated by the stunning scenery and well rendered zombies,almost every piece of elements in the game were well done for their time.
2.Game design and gameplay:
Like I said Dead Island is beautifully done for its time.However what displeases me is the recent HD improvement theyve done with the definitive edition,the water physics and look are absolutely ugly compared to the original.Who thought it was a good idea to turn the beautiful blue water in Banoi into some jello sea.The ammount of glitches I also had to deal with and which are present even today in the definitive edition,such as zombies running into invisible walls or clunky AI which cant decide on killing you or getting angry at some rubble in the road.And dont even get me started on the NPC faces,even young women in this game look like withered hags for some reason.I think the designers at deep silver need to look at how women look like and take some drawing classes.

The gameplay is very formulaic and clunky in some places,one could notice the very ankward motion of the characters arms when they attack something/the air.What is fun about the gameplay however is the ammount of weapons and their rarity (an element borrowed from Borderlands) one could use to dismember and kill zombies/humans.Legit the best thing about this game is the possibility of modifying already good orange tier legendary weapons into death machines and I'm stunned other games havent copied this.Imagine if in Borderlands you could modify a rpg to shoot both fire and electricity or increase splash damage by finding schematics with parts.

3.Story:
The story is typical to the zombie genre,pretty sure there are other zombie games which are similar and escape my memory at the moment which have done the same thing.The story however has its highlights but like I said its basically the tropical paradise gone wrong scenario,the good elements of the story I'd say are the following:
-the "zombie" virus is a mutated version of the very real and ugly K'uru disease from papua new guineea.They tried hard and somewhat succeeded into making the way this thing spreads and affects people very credible.So I'll give them props to that a very good idea.
-the whole idea of escape from Banoi is premeditated on the idea of some random millitary dude giving you the ok and sending a helicopter for you.Thus giving you the false sense of security only to realise the further you go in the story that the more screwed you are.This entire story makes you feel like youre the pawn of different factions furthering their own ends.Theres alot of plotwists which are genuinely cool,such as Charon the hacker posing as Rider White and tricking you into believing the real White is the bad guy screwing everything up.
-the idea of 4 playable characters still being present in cutscenes and having an impact in the story,a thing even borderlands wasnt capable of doing right.Some of the best parts of this game is the interaction between the 4 characters or the main characters with npcs.Like when Sam B commenting how that was some "night of the living dead type of shit going on".
Now for the bad parts of the story:
-the idea of 4 characters being immune to the disease is such a deus ex machina element that it begs belief how these people with 0 negative blood wont be zombified even if theyre killed.
-the end of the story is retarded in many ways.Many of the characters that have stuck with you from the beginning end up being dead because of ridiculous writing,like Jin dying because the writers decided she has to annoy the secondary "villain" of the game.And all the side missions youve done to ensure their wellbeing like the Church sanctuary,the jungle village and the lifeguard sanctuary end up being useless because at the end you leave everything behind Banoi before a fucking thermonuclear bomb annihilates everyone on the island.So all the stuff youve done in game and all those people youve met,its all pointless.Somehow Sinamoi and a couple others didnt end up radioactive BBQ because Deep Silver realised how stupid the end of D I is.
-many side missions that are semi related to the main story are either fetch quests or some npc being a retard and forgetting something in some house they lived in.I hope that Dead Island 2 will have better side quests than the first one.Some story elements of this game from sidequests dont go anywhere ,like Nikolai and his russian buddies coming to help us.You end up running in circles doing nothing.

4.Sound effects and music:
Another good element of this game is probably the ammount of effort that went into sound design and bringing to life this island.The way the zombies groan,roar or pant when they run is done well.One could hear sometimes the hordes of zombies clatter far away in the background or how certain zombie sounds indicate a special type of infected.Its really spooky if its your first type playing it and you hear a Ram infected in the background.
The ambient soundtrack is also beautifully done in this game.Some of my favourite ambiental tracks in this game are the Overpass camp and Jungle Danger ones.The tracks really do immerse you into the game and set the tone from the start.

5.Conclusions and future:
Overall Dead Island,for me atleast,is well worth it (especially now thats 5 euros on steam for the definitive edition).The game may not be the best installment in the zombie genre but theres something about it thats endearing and fun to play,whether its the island itself or the pretty innovative gear/weapons system (when you have a baseball bat which literally throws zombies 100 meters away then you know its fun) its worth it.
One will wonder what the new developers will do with Dead Island 2 after Riptide was basically an expansion pack for Dead Island.The future seems very uncertain for this franchise,with so many ideas being thrown around and so much time passing away,one would wonder if they will manage to recapture that magic the original game had.

STABILITY ISSUES
Games saves became corrupted after about two months of playing. I'm on a modern PC, 32GB RAM, Intel/Nvidia, 3 HDD... I lost over a week of grinding and completed missions, and it's been tough trying to get back into it.

I'd recommend backing up your saves every few plays, because otherwise you will get stuck and demotivated to continue. This is a known issue I wish they would patch since the game is still being sold.

The game up to that point was honestly pretty phenomenal. It's not too easy, not too difficult. I like the open world feel to it. I was completely surprised that the action and story were that good... I thought it was going to be a really dumb game tbh. There's a lot of depth to the missions and inventory. Upgrading weapons is useful. One of the grinding aspects is that you have to constantly repair your weapons--even strong, "durable" upgraded ones.

It's hard to find any big complaints gameplay-wise, other than maybe some missions are dumb and tedious, and the travel around can be slow at times.

The other glitchy issue I ran into was that sometimes a completed mission would reset when you left that area. I understand enemies respawning, but when you play a scavenging game like this with scarce resources, it's not fun to have to continually face the same area a few times before the game registers the mission completed... because of a game glitch.

Definitely a game that could have benefited from more QA testing prior to launch.

I got it on a good sale so I can't complain too much for being an unexpected hit. Just a big let down that the saves don't stick.

To put it shortly, the game Dead Island is a fun romp through a decently fun game world with plenty to do, engaging combat, and pretty well implemented dark tone. The graphical touch ups are greatly welcome and help update the mid-7th generation muddy textures to something more presentable. In that sense, it's a very faithful adaptation of the original game for modern audiences.

On the flip side however, this remaster fails to update the game's sluggish/stiff movement or limited FOV for modern expectations. While I understand the Dev team behind this remake likely didn't have a particularly long time to work on the game, nor did they have the clearance to overhaul such systems, it's disappointing to see an otherwise solid experience like Dead Island not be better polished aside from a spit shine. 

I wouldn't say this kills any enjoyment you could have with the game, but understand that you have to accommodate the game more than it's willing to accommodate you. If you want to give this game another try after playing it before, this is certainly a good way of doing so. But if you're looking to dive into the Techland FPS RPGs, I would recommend playing Dying Light first.

I haven't played the original game, but I grew up watching my dad play it. For new players unaware of the original: this is an okay game, was better during its first release. The plot is generic, a couple interesting side missions among average ones. I would say either map design or the hack-and-slash melee is the best thing about the game. Character models are meh, but forgivable due to an old engine. I never thought I would hate driving in a game as much as I do. Many bugs, too. I feel this game will run poorly on lower-end computers. If you find an incentive to play the game past Act I, then you 𝘮𝘪𝘨𝘩𝘵 enjoy it. Playing with friends will make the experience much better.
However, I think I would have had a similar (/𝘣𝘦𝘵𝘵𝘦𝘳) experience if I just went out of my way to find the original. From what I can tell (+ what other reviews say), pretty much 𝘯𝘰𝘵𝘩𝘪𝘯𝘨 was actually improved from the original. The developers just changed the graphics and made it more content-friendly in attempts for more sales. I cannot even play this game with my dad because they have made the two versions incompatible with each other. I have no reason to replay the game from this.
Overall, if you're still interested despite the reviews, wait for a sale. I wouldn't recommend spending over 5$. Or go find the original.

I love this game. It catches the shambling zombie style of the original Romero movies well, with a holiday resort island full of zombies who will overwhelm you with numbers and relentlessness rather than aggression. There ARE faster zombies as well as other types as well. Nice weapon/skill progression but the real star is simply the atmosphere, of post apocalyptic emptiness, coupled with endless (and re-spawning)  hoards of zombies. You'll progress to different maps as well as venturing into the sewers. The game has been surpassed by its successor and Dead Light now, but if you need an additional zombie fix, you could do worse.
BTW, ignore the playtime indicator. I've put in well over 100 hours.

First off all, half of this review is sarcastic. I could not take this game seriously, at all. And the only way i can describe how bad it is is to use sarcasm. I will spoil the living 𝐬𝐡𝐢𝐭 out of this game. But i really doubt someone actually cares much about the story. 
I wanted to buy this game for a pretty long time. Mostly after i became addicted by Dying Light and heard it was a game developed by the same people, Techland. Well, and Deep Silver, but we don't talk about them. And oh, boy, was i disappointed when i first played it. The movement felt so slow, even though i use a pretty high DPI, it felt like i was actually lagging the whole time. My game only went below 40FPS in some areas, but all the time it was above 60. Yet, it always felt like i'm playing at 40 or even lower. It never felt like i played this game smoothly, at 80fps. But i'll get into that in a second. First things first, i'll start with what i like about the game, because it's a short list. lol.


Pros:

You can choose between 5 playable characters. Each with their ups and downs, one's a blunt weapon expert, one guns expert, one sharp weapons expert, etc. I cannot talk too much about the other characters, as i always played with Xian Mei, the sharp weapons expert. I don't like the rest of 'em. But the game gets a few extra points for having more playable characters.

You can play as the same character in co-op. I never knew that, and its a really great feature. When i first played this game, i let my ex use Xian, and i used Logan, because i thought it wouldn't be possible to play as the same character. But turns out you can have a fully lobby of Xian or Logan, or Sam B. lol. It's quite neat, if you ask me. 

The combat mechanics and the gore are quite satisfying. Each weapon is moddable with different effects, toxic, electricity, fire, etc. And you can even mod the guns. Explosive rounds for the rifles, or electrical bullets for the pistol. 
The game has a vast variety of weapons, from what i've seen. Hammer, machete, katana, axe, knife, pipe. shovel, etc.
I only used sharp weapons like knives and katanas, because Xian is the best with them. 
Cutting a zombie from legs to the head is quite fun. Such a shame their head automatically turns bald after you cut it off, lol. Who thought this was a good idea? 

My favorite thing so far about this game is the "Fury" ability. Basically, you go Berzerk on everyone, not matter the size. With Xian, i was able to kill about 14-16 zombies in a matter of seconds. And the more you kill, the bigger the XP bonus is. But be aware, the Fury goes quite fast, so make good use of it. And don't try to rush a whole are of armed humans. I tried and it didn't went quite well. 

The game offers a quite diverse variety of locations. You have the beaches, that is an actual dead paradise. You have the slums, a quite depressive area, with junk and blood, and bodies all around the place. Kinda like a normal city from Pakistan. 
You have the Church, that's quite beautiful, even though the uh.. nun, looks like an old, retired pornstar. 
There is also the jungle, which is by far my favorite location in the game. In that location we meet the Butcher, personally, my favorite kind of infected from this game. Also the jungle is by far the most immersive area in the whole game. From the ambient noises, to the environment, and the enemies. You get to fight Native zombies. It's pretty cool. 

Money actually are useful in this game, as you'll need plenty to repair your weapons and buy materials and medkits. The better your weapon is, the more it will cost you to repair it. It's quite fair, to be honest, because you can easily farm money. Especially in co-op. Have a friend play as Sam B, (or more) and you'll get a crapload of money, because Sam B gets bonus cash, and the money your co-op partner gets, counts for you as well. 


Alright, we're done with the good things about the game. Now let's discuss about the bad things, shall we?

I'll start with my OWN problems that i had during this amazing game. 
First of all, the game gave me really bad headaches, that lasted of hours. I have motion sickness. First time i played this game, in 2019, was vanilla, without mods. Never got such a bad headache, especially from a video game. And i know for a fact a lot of other players have this issue as well. 
I have fixed the problems a bit. I mean, i still get a bit dizzy at times, but hey, no headaches. You have to mod your game a bit. Edit some .ini files, increase the FOV, disable the blur, chromatic abberation, depth of field, use a reshade to tone down that damn brightness that burns your eyes. 
Here's the guide i used to fix most of the problems. https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1713802838
Cons:

The incredible story, filled with heartbreaking moments, amazing writing. Half-Life 2? Bioshock 1? Nah, screw those games. Dead Island's plot is really complex, and only a genius could fully comprehend it. 
The side characters that give you quests? So relatable. I mean.. i always send people looking for my Teddy bear, or for champagne bottles during the outbreak. 
For real, the story, if you can even call it that, its the most cliche, terrible, cringey, 𝐬𝐡𝐢𝐭 out there. And it's not even "so bad that it's good" bad, like The Room, it's "so bad that it makes me wanna stab myself with a spoon" bad. 
The main characters barely talk in-game, they only talk during the cutscenes. And oh boy, the cutscenes are something aren't they? Each character feels so dead inside. They're eyes are dead and dull, their facial animations, especially Puma's are just.. ew. EW. When they talk, they move their entire face, not only the lips. 
The cutscenes look like they were made by an amateur or indie developer, but in today's age, even indie devs make better cutscenes. I'm not going to lie, i've seen SFM porn with better animations. I'll just put this one here. 
All the characters in this game have the personality of a rock. Xian is the only one that looks and talk like a normal human being. 
The side quests are just as bad, but some, only a few, are better than the main story itself. Won't talk too much about the side-quests, because i've skipped each and every dialog, and they were too damn bad memorize any of them. 
You reach the end-game, right? The man that was supposed to save us all, turned out to run away with the antidote and nuke the island, along with all the remaining survivors there! Oh my, who would've gussed that! Bad guy gets bitten by his zombie waifu, injects himself with the antidote, and becomes the strongest living being! I one-hit killed him with a developer weapon. Our characters leave the island and they all lived happily ever after. 

The movement in this game is one of weirdest stuff i ever seen. You're so slow, like the moving animations were slowed down. It feels so clunky just to walk around. Game runs above 60FPS, but it feels like its on 40. There is mouse lag, as well. And when you try to drive, your camera just becomes SLOW af. I've set my DPI to max when driving only to get a less terrible experience. Climbing stuff is also pretty terrible, because the game has a LOT of invisible walls. Wanna try to get up on that box? Or wanna jump on that roof that's only two feet away from you? Well good luck trying to make that jump with the invisbile Ice Berg right in front of you. 
Thankfully, again, there is a mod that increases the mobility and the speed. Makes the game actually playable. https://www.nexusmods.com/deadisland/mods/26

The game also doesn't have a day and night cycle. It's always day. It's always sunny. The only time when it rains is when you go into the Old Town, Act 2. And ONLY in that location. Amazing.

Before ending this amazing 10/10 review, i have to thank my co-op partner, Natteee for making this game less tedious. 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2297929919

Overall, my final verdict is... buy Dying Light.

 Back in the days I enjoyed this game but I didn’t know any better. Now, I see clearly. This game isn’t something I would recommend to others.
-) Side quests make you go back and forth, or go off the rail, which you must stay put if you’ve understood any of the situations you are in.
-) Not only that, you can definitely feel this chore-like “back and forth” design is on purpose. Diminishes the immersion.
-)  This game is mainly designed for sharp weapon class, which is Xian? Yes. Blunt weapons aren’t bad, it has its own “way of use”, but it is definitely inferior to sharp weapons.
-) Besides, most of the rewards are sharp weapons. You do get blunt weapons time to time but they are subpar compared to its counterpart.
-) Speaking of which, Sledge hammer? What is wrong with that weapon? It’s as if developers raised the damage of overall weapons except that one. It is a two-handed weapon and yet its damage is disastrously low. Even lower than a one-handed weapon, that has a lower item level.
-) Oh, yes, They should indicate if an weapon is two-handed or one-handed. You can use it, swing it in the air and find out but come on. Don’t be like that. Hehe
-) Zombie respawn time is too fast from time to time. One particular zombie kept respawning everytime I came out of a container. It was horrible.
-) And since we are going back and forth, seeing the same type of zombies, same number of them, at the same area again and again was chopping my buzz.

Dead Island is one of those games I remember playing for hours on end back on the PS3. Being terrified of the game while also amused by the sheer graphic fidelity. I beat it multiple years ago and here I am beating it once again. 

To put it short this game has aged fairly well at least in my opinion. The graphics still look fantastic all these years later, the zombies scared me multiple times through my playthrough, and overall the enviroments were diverse and helped the game not feel too bland. All of the melee weapons feel satisfying to use. The weapon mods look and help the "tankiness" of certain mobs. The hidden objectives scattered throughout the map are a fun addition to the game. The lighting is mesmerizing. 

The zombie AI is wonderful. Each zombie has its strength and weakness and I can see how each character (in a co-op) setting would have something unique to counter said zombies. Multiple times throughout the game I would be doing something just to be ambushed by the running infected zombies. Fantastic. 

Now onto the bad portions of the game. The music. Jesus Christ, the music has to be the biggest short coming of this entire game. The games soundtrack consists of the same four songs it feels like. The combat music is even worse. It got to the point where I just turned the music down due to sheer repetition. 

The overall sound of the game is bad too. Multiple times throughout the game where the sound would bug out and I would have to reload my save. The ambient sounds in certain areas was fantastic meanwhile in places like the city you could go to edges of the map and hear where the "ambient" sounds were originating from. 

The game ran flawlessly at first, however, once I made it to the city portion of the games -multiple- times the game was just take a dump and drop from 144 FPS to 15-20 FPS. I would either have to stop and hope the game adjusted itself or just completely quit the game and relaunch. ( At the time of playing this game my rig has a 3900x, 2080 Ti, and 32gb of 3600 DDR4 ram. Well over the recommended specs). I am playing on 21:9 instead of 16:9, however, I don't believe this to be the issue. 

The AI... for humans anyway, is awful. Really. No other terms can begin to describe how pitiful the human AI is. Multiple times the AI would just freeze and not even attempt to shoot in my location if I "broke" LOS. (I say broke loosely because I would be hiding behind a pole or something). Thankfully you don't deal with humans too often so that is a bonus. 

Guns are a complete joke and I believe they are there only for novelty sake. Ammo is scarce and to make matters worse guns do next to no damage. Even if you were to play as Purna (the gun chick) I believe they would still be mediocre. One change from the original Dead Island to Definitive Edition is that they have completely ruined shotguns. They used to be a guaranteed critical if aiming at the head, this feature is completely gone and now you have to pump shells into mobs. I just ditched the shotgun after the city due to this. I am also pissed that they ditched the original gun models in favor of the dying light models. In the original game you had the M4, M16, and AK. Now you have this weird AR, a sig 556 clone (that may I add is shared between the single and burst variant) and it leaves you wondering why except for sheer laziness. Also the animations for most of the guns in the game simply do not line up with the new models they have brought from Dying Light (looking at all of the rifles). 

The story is lackluster at best. The voice acting is horrendous and the accents do not help in the slightest. This gets progressively worse the further you progress through the story. The final boss battle is one of the most anti climatic moments in recent gaming history and the side quests can be frustrating (especially the ones that send you back to a location you just came from). 

Finally, the game is extremely short. I played the game solo, took my time doing every side quest and looting -everything-, and still managed to beat it in 18 hours. This game was obviously intended for new game+ and co-op play. For me I just wanted to replay it after all of these years, I just couldn't imagine sinking more time into multiple playthroughs. 

To conclude, despite my many criticisms of the game I still believe it is a gem. The game overall has aged well and the combat is enjoyable enough to make up for the shortcomings of the game. Multiple times through my playthrough I was genuinely scared and the atmosphere of the game is eerie throughout. Don't go into this expecting AAA title quality, however, I would -only- recommend this game if it is on sale.

How do you mess up an otherwise FANTASTIC zombie game?

It's easy!  Just give EVERY zombie a six foot reach!  

Seriously, there is NO REASON a zombie should be able to swing and hit me with bare fists at distances where i can't hit them with my arm and a F**KING SWORD!  It doesn't start out as more than an annoyance, but it quickly magnifies as the difficulty curve goes upward.

First time I played this game was on an old computer and it was lagging the entire time. Yet, I finished it until the end, because I loved it so much. The contrast of light and darkness just appealed to me: sun, beaches, cocktails, zombies, limbs and death everywhere. I have been fortunate enough to spent some time in a luxurious hotel in Cancún, Mexico, so I could easily place myself in the game, amidst the sunny beaches, blue ocean and rotten girls in bikinis ('rotten', in this case, referring to their personality, lol).

The game itself is very violent, bloody, disturbing and definitely not for kids. It also has a lot of bad language (which I am not a fan of, because I find it unpleasantly distracting and unnecessary). The wailing of the undead is unsettling and that makes entering a safe zone even more relieving. There, you can take a breather and safely upgrade and modify your weapons, before heading out again. If you have a car at your disposal, you may as well take it with you, as some of the undead aren’t quite as dead and tend to be a little more aggressive...

With the exception of Xian Mei, I found the other main characters very unlikable. [spoiler]There was one scene in particular that was very traumatizing (like a zombie apocalypse isn’t traumatizing enough), where I was put off by the lack of compassion by Sam B and Logan. Sadly, this is a scripted event and there is no way to prevent it.[/spoiler] Apart from that, each character has three unique skill trees. You can improve the skills of your character by gaining experience points (XP). You gain XP by killing zombies and completing quests. I found it very enjoyable to see my character adapt to the zombie apocalypse, by becoming a better and stronger survivor.

Lastly, I want to give Paweł Błaszczak, the composer of the Dead Island soundtrack, some love. We should never underestimate how important music is for a game and I think Paweł did an excellent job on this, as well as Giles Lamb, who composed a beautiful, award-winning piece for the trailer.

Now, I am well aware the game has its flaws. Even though this is the Definitive Edition (also including all the DLC), it still has its fair share of bugs and glitches. One Steam Achievement is virtually impossible to get (“Gotta find'em all”) and weapons tend to vanish from your inventory after you mod them. But let this not distract you from the fact that this is one hell of a great and terrifying zombie game!

Having just finished off the laborious Zombie Army Trilogy, I looked through my library for a better undead masher.  Did not have much fun with the overwhelming odds of Dead Rising 2, but I was pleasantly surprised by this oldie but goodie.

The good: 
Nice perk trees encourage progression and aggression.
Weapons are also upgradable, and degrade slow enough so as not to be distracting.
Rarely frustrating level of difficulty.
Generally responsive combat. Zombies are fun to curbstomp.
Nice mix of environments.

The bleh:
Story's okay, but a maybe a bit too serious.
Awkward racial stereotypes with sometimes unintentionally goofy voice acting.
Annoying protagonists (but luckily you don't have to listen to your 'team' often).
Just a serious of fetch quests with zombies in the way.
Some minor glitches where quest objects need to be looked at at just the right angle to register as usable.

Verdict: A solid B. PIck it up on sale if you like a rather easygoing zombie kill-fest.
very good game

Overall the game is decent but it has major downfalls that need to be noted. Co-op logic is buggy meaning sometimes zombies are dead for one party but not another, and head stomping a zombie already being head stomped by another player resets the head stomp. In terms of content the game is very lacking, in almost 24 hours of gameplay i've been 90% of the game story and side quests. Car logic is absolutely horendous being right hand drive. What the game has for content though is solid content a lot of unique quests combined with boring fetch me this and come back. If you just want a fun hack and slash zombie killer this game is definetly for you. Joining a co-op session is as easy as can be as well.

Dead Island Definitive Edition is a open world zombie survival. You can play one of four characters with their own unique play styles and abilities. The story is about your character being on vacation to Banoi, waking up one morning to the zombie apocalypse, and start to help people on your way off the Island...kind of. The plot is meh. The games' graphics are very pretty and I wish the game took place more on the beach side than where else. Although, this is the first game to give me motion sickless from their driving mechanics. Most of the missions is ether fetch quests or escort. The game has co-op, which is the only way this is kind of fun to play. Having said that, you better off playing another co-op zombie game The NPCs are all stupid, and it tries to make you feel for them, but I just don't care about any of them. There couple of bugs still, like missions not starting or working right. If you really want to play this, wait for a steam sale and drag a buddy or two with you. And I give this a 5.5/10.
